text: 2.0 SITE CHARACTERIZATION
label: HH1

text: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) uses the performance assessment (PA) methodology
label: BODY

text: described in Chapter 6.0 to demonstrate that the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) disposal
label: BODY

text: system will meet the environmental performance standards of Title 40 of the Code of Federal
label: BODY

text: Regulations (CFR) Part 191 Subparts B and C.  In order to effectively use PA, three inputs are
label: BODY

text: necessary: What can happen to the disposal system? What are the chances of it happening? What
label: BODY

text: are the consequences if it happens? The answers to these questions are derived from many
label: BODY

text: sources, including field studies, laboratory evaluations, experiments, and, in the case of some
label: BODY

text: features not amenable to direct characterization, professional judgment.  The information used in
label: BODY

text: PA is described in terms of features of the disposal system that can be used to describe its
label: BODY

text: isolation capability, events that can affect the disposal system, and processes that are reasonably
label: BODY

text: expected to act on the disposal system.
label: BODY

text: The DOE selected the Los Medaños region and present site for the WIPP based on certain
label: BODY

text: defined siting criteria.  The site selection process, which was focused on sites that contained
label: BODY

text: certain favorable features while other unfavorable features were excluded, was applied by the
label: BODY

text: DOE with the intent of finding the area that best met the siting criteria.  The siting process is
label: BODY

text: discussed in CCA Appendix GCR.  Chapters 3.0, 4.0, and 6.0 and several appendices provide
label: BODY

text: additional information supporting this chapter.
label: BODY

text: Conceptual models of the WIPP disposal system simulate the interaction between the natural
label: BODY

text: environment (described in this chapter), the engineered structures (described in Chapter 3.0) and
label: BODY

text: the waste (described in Chapter 4.0).  One starting point in developing conceptual models of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP disposal system is an understanding of the natural characteristics of the site and of the
label: BODY

text: region around the site.  Site characterization and model development is an interactive process
label: BODY

text: that the DOE has used for many years.  Basic site information leads to initial models.  Initial
label: BODY

text: model sensitivity studies indicate the need for more detailed information.  More site
label: BODY

text: characterization then leads to improved models.  In addition, an assessment of the impacts of
label: BODY

text: uncertainty inherent in the parameters used to numerically simulate geological features and
label: BODY

text: processes has also led the DOE to conduct more in-depth investigations of the natural system.
label: BODY

text: These investigations generally proceeded until uncertainty was sufficiently reduced or to the
label: BODY

text: point where no further information could be reasonably obtained.
label: BODY

text: The discussion of conceptual models and initial and boundary conditions is in Section 6.4 and
label: BODY

text: Appendix PA, Attachment MASS.  Conceptual models implement scenarios about the future.
label: BODY

text: Scenario development is discussed in Section 6.3.  Scenario development requires as inputs
label: BODY

text: information about the natural features, events, and processes (FEPs) that can reasonably be
label: BODY

text: expected to act on the disposal system.  While the list of possible FEPs is derived independently
label: BODY

text: of the disposal system, their screening (in Section 6.2 and Appendix PA, Attachment SCR) is
label: BODY

text: based on an understanding of the geology, hydrology, and climatology of the region and the site
label: BODY

text: in particular.  The screening methodology follows U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
label: BODY

text: criteria on the Scope of Performance Assessments (40 CFR § 191.32).  This basic understanding
label: BODY

text: is provided in this chapter and its associated appendices.
label: BODY

text: Table 2-1 shows the tie between the list of natural FEPs that were identified and screened for the
label: BODY

text: WIPP and the sections of this chapter or Appendix PA, Attachment SCR.  Those FEPs that have
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: been retained for inclusion in the modeling are shown in bold in Table 2-1.  These generally
label: BODY

text: receive a greater level of detail in the following discussions and are supported by additional
label: BODY

text: discussion in Chapter 6.0, Appendix PA, Attachments MASS and SCR.  In addition, parameter
label: BODY

text: values that have been derived for these FEPs are included in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR.
label: BODY

text: In this chapter, the DOE describes the WIPP site geology, hydrology, climatology, air quality,
label: BODY

text: ecology, and cultural and natural resources.  This chapter’s purpose is to (1) explain
label: BODY

text: characteristics of the site, (2) describe background environmental quality, and (3) discuss
label: BODY

text: features of the site that might be important for inclusion in a quantitative PA.  The DOE has used
label: BODY

text: this information to develop and screen FEPs and to develop conceptual, mathematical, and
label: BODY

text: computational models to evaluate the efficacy of natural and engineered barriers in meeting
label: BODY

text: environmental performance standards (Chapter 6.0).  Results of these predictive models are used
label: BODY

text: by the DOE to demonstrate that the DOE has a reasonable expectation that compliance with
label: BODY

text: applicable regulations will be achieved.  This chapter has been prepared to describe the site prior
label: BODY

text: to excavating the repository.  Excavation of the repository and its associated effects, such as the
label: BODY

text: disturbed rock zone (DRZ), are discussed in Chapter 3.0.
label: BODY

text: The DOE located the WIPP site 42 km (26 mi) east of Carlsbad, New Mexico, in Eddy County
label: BODY

text: (Figure 2-1).  Additional details related to the location of the WIPP site can be found in Section
label: BODY

text: 2.1.4.2 and in Figure 3-1 (see Chapter 3.0).  The latitude of the WIPP site center is 32E22' 11" N
label: BODY

text: and the longitude is 103E47' 30" W.  The region surrounding the WIPP site has been studied for
label: BODY

text: many years, and exploration of both potash and hydrocarbon deposits has provided extensive
label: BODY

text: knowledge of the geology of the region.  Two exploratory holes were drilled by the federal
label: BODY

text: government in 1974 at a location northeast of the present site; that location was abandoned in
label: BODY

text: 1975 as a possible repository site after U.S. Energy Research and Development Administration
label: BODY

text: (ERDA) 6 borehole was drilled and unacceptable structure and pressurized brine were
label: BODY

text: encountered.  The results of these investigations are reported in Powers et al. (1978, 2 – 6;
label: BODY

text: included in CCA Appendix GCR).  During late 1975 and early 1976, the ERDA identified the
label: BODY

text: current site, and an initial exploratory hole (ERDA-9) was drilled.  By the time an initial phase of
label: BODY

text: site characterization was completed in August 1978, 47 holes had been or were being drilled for
label: BODY

text: various hydrologic and geologic purposes.  Geophysical techniques were applied to augment
label: BODY

text: data collected from boreholes.  Since 1978, the DOE has drilled additional holes to support
label: BODY

text: hydrologic studies, geologic studies, and facility design.  Geophysical logs, cores, basic data
label: BODY

text: reports, geochemical sampling and testing, and hydrological testing and analyses are reported by
label: BODY

text: the DOE and its scientific advisor, Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), in numerous public
label: BODY

text: documents.  Many of those documents form the basis for the DOE’s positions in this application.
label: BODY

text: As necessary, specific references from these documents are cited to reinforce statements being
label: BODY

text: made.
label: BODY

text: Biological studies of the site began in 1975 to gather information for the Environmental Impact
label: BODY

text: Statement (DOE 1980).  Meteorological studies began in 1976, and economic studies were
label: BODY

text: initiated in 1977.  Baseline environmental data were initially reported in 1977 and are now
label: BODY

text: updated annually by the DOE.
label: BODY

text: *NOTE: Additional information for FEPs N1-N72 is located in Appendix PA, Attachment SCR.
label: BODY

text: The DOE located the WIPP disposal horizon within a rock salt deposit known as the Salado
label: BODY

text: Formation at a depth of 650 m (2,150 ft) below the ground surface.  The Salado is regionally
label: BODY

text: extensive, includes continuous beds of salt without complicated structure, is deep with little
label: BODY

text: potential for dissolution in the immediate vicinity of the WIPP, and is near enough to the surface
label: BODY

text: to make access reasonable.  Particular site selection criteria narrowed the choices when the
label: BODY

text: present site was located during 1975 and 1976, as is discussed in CCA Appendix GCR and
label: BODY

text: summarized by Weart (1983).
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.1 Geology
label: HH2

text: The DOE and its predecessor agencies determined at the outset of the geological disposal
label: BODY

text: program that the geological characteristics of the disposal system are extremely important
label: BODY

text: because the natural barriers provided by the geological units have a significant impact on the
label: BODY

text: performance of the disposal system.  Among the DOE’s site selection criteria was the intent to
label: BODY

text: maximize the beneficial impacts of the geology.  This was accomplished when the DOE selected
label: BODY

text: (1) a host formation that behaves plastically, thereby creeping closed to encapsulate buried
label: BODY

text: waste, (2) a location where the effects of dissolution are minimal and predictable, (3) an area
label: BODY

text: where deformation of the rocks is low, (4) an area where excavation is relatively easy, (5) an
label: BODY

text: area where future resource development is predictable and minimal, and (6) a repository host
label: BODY

text: rock that is relatively uncomplicated lithologically and structurally.  Therefore, a thorough and
label: BODY

text: accurate description of the WIPP facility’s natural environmental setting is considered crucial by
label: BODY

text: the DOE for a demonstration of compliance with the disposal standards and is an EPA
label: BODY

text: certification criterion in 40 CFR § 191.14(a).  The DOE is providing the detail necessary to
label: BODY

text: assess the achievable degree of waste isolation.  In this chapter, the DOE addresses
label: BODY

text: environmental factors and long-term environmental changes that are important for assessing the
label: BODY

text: waste isolation potential of the disposal system.  The first of these environmental factors is
label: BODY

text: geology.
label: BODY

text: Geological data have been collected from the WIPP site and surrounding area to evaluate the
label: BODY

text: site’s suitability as a radioactive waste repository.  These data have been collected principally by
label: BODY

text: the DOE, the DOE’s predecessor agencies, the United States Geological Survey (USGS), the
label: BODY

text: New Mexico Bureau of Mines and Mineral Resources (NMBMMR), and private organizations
label: BODY

text: engaged in natural resource exploration and extraction.  The DOE has analyzed the data and has
label: BODY

text: determined that the data support the DOE’s position that the WIPP site is suitable for the long-
label: BODY

text: term isolation of radioactive waste.
label: BODY

text: Many issues have been discussed, investigated, and resolved in order for the DOE to conclude
label: BODY

text: that the site is suitable.  The DOE discusses these issues in the following sections.  Most of the
label: BODY

text: data collected have been reported or summarized in CCA Appendices GCR, SUM, HYDRO, and
label: BODY

text: FAC.  These appendices represent the majority of the site characterization results for the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site which ended in 1988.  A number of more focused geological and hydrological studies
label: BODY

text: continued after this date.  These latter studies provided detailed information needed to construct
label: BODY

text: the conceptual models for disposal system performance that are discussed in Section 6.4.  An
label: BODY

text: example of these studies is the H-19 multiwell tracer test that was completed in early 1996.
label: BODY

text: Results of this test were incorporated into the discussions in this chapter and into the conceptual
label: BODY

text: models described in Section 6.4.6. Model parameters derived from the data are displayed in
label: BODY

text: Appendix PA, Attachment PAR.  A discussion of the data is included in CCA Appendix MASS;
label: BODY

text: and Appendix PA, Attachment MASS.
label: BODY

text: Geological field studies designed to collect data pertinent to the WIPP PA continue. The Culebra
label: BODY

text: Dolomite Member and Magenta Dolomite Members are the two carbonates in the Rustler
label: BODY

text: Formation, the youngest evaporite-bearing formation in the Delaware Basin.  Geologic data
label: BODY

text: related to the Culebra and Magenta remain of particular interest, as these members are the most
label: BODY

text: significant transmissive units at the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: The EPA’s December 19, 1996 letter (A-93-02, Docket II-I-01) made a request to the DOE for
label: BODY

text: recent studies that had provided detailed information used in developing conceptual models for
label: BODY

text: disposal system performance. In a response letter to EPA dated February 26, 1997 (Docket A-93-
label: BODY

text: 02, Item II-I-10), the DOE cited Holt (1997) for detailed information on the recent enhancement
label: BODY

text: of the conceptual model for transport in the Culebra.  Holt (1997) discusses interpretation and
label: BODY

text: conceptual insights obtained from field and laboratory tracer tests and core studies that support
label: BODY

text: the double-porosity conceptual model of the Culebra, in which Culebra porosity is divided into
label: BODY

text: advective and diffusive components.
label: BODY

text: Geological data provide the basis for a different approach to estimating the transmissivity field
label: BODY

text: for modeling fluid flow and transport in the Culebra (Beauheim 2002). Geological data correlate
label: BODY

text: strongly with Culebra transmissivity (Holt and Yarbrough 2002), and they are available from
label: BODY

text: many more locations, such as industry (oil, gas, potash) drillholes, than are transmissivity data.
label: BODY

text: With this correlation, Culebra properties can be inferred over a wide area, leading to an
label: BODY

text: improved computational model of the spatial distribution of Culebra transmissivity.  Initial
label: BODY

text: results from this computational model of the spatial distribution of Culebra transmissivity have
label: BODY

text: been incorporated in the PA; they are discussed in more detail in Section 2.2.1.4.1.2, and are
label: BODY

text: incorporated in Appendix PA, Attachment TFIELD.  Additional data in support of this modeling
label: BODY

text: are being collected through field activities, including drilling and testing of new wells, to
label: BODY

text: improve understanding of the Culebra and to assess the causes(s) of rising water levels (see
label: BODY

text: 2.1.1 Data Sources
label: HH2

text: The geology of southeastern New Mexico has been of great interest for more than a century.  The
label: BODY

text: Guadalupe Mountains have become a common visiting and research point for geologists because
label: BODY

text: of the spectacular exposures of Permian-age reef rocks and related facies (see Shumard 1858,
label: BODY

text: Crandall 1929, Newell et al. 1953, and Dunham 1972 in the CCA bibliography).  Because of
label: BODY

text: intense interest in both hydrocarbon and potash resources in the region, a large volume of data
label: BODY

text: exists as background information for the WIPP site, though some data are proprietary.  Finally,
label: BODY

text: there is the geological information developed directly and indirectly by studies sponsored by the
label: BODY

text: DOE for the WIPP project; it ranges from raw data to interpretive reports.
label: BODY

text: Elements of the geology of southeastern New Mexico have been discussed or described in
label: BODY

text: professional journals or technical documents from many different sources.  These types of
label: BODY

text: articles are an important source of information, and where there is consistency among the
label: BODY

text: technical community, the information in these articles is referenced when subject material is
label: BODY

text: relevant.  Implicit rules of professional conduct for research and reporting have been assumed, as
label: BODY

text: have journal and editorial review.  Elements of the geology presented in such sources have been
label: BODY

text: deemed critical to the WIPP and have been the subject of specific DOE-sponsored WIPP studies.
label: BODY

text: The geological data that the DOE has developed explicitly for the WIPP project have been
label: BODY

text: produced over a 25-year period by different organizations and contractors using applicable
label: BODY

text: national standards (Quality Assurance Program history is described in Section 5.1.2).  During a
label: BODY

text: rulemaking in 1988 related to the underground injection of hazardous wastes, the EPA addressed
label: BODY

text: the use of older geological data in making a long-term demonstration of repository performance.
label: BODY

text: In response to comments on a proposed rule regarding the permitting of underground injection
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: wells, the EPA concluded that “[e]xcluding historical data or information which might have been
label: BODY

text: gathered off-site by methods not consistent with certain prescribed procedures may be
label: BODY

text: counterproductive.”  The EPA further stated that such data should be used as long as their
label: BODY

text: limitations are accounted for.  In the final rule, the EPA stipulated “that only measurements
label: BODY

text: pertaining to the waste or that result from testing performed to gather data for the petition
label: BODY

text: demonstration comply with prescribed procedures.”  Further, the EPA stated that “the concerns
label: BODY

text: about the accuracy of geologic data are addressed more appropriately by requiring that the
label: BODY

text: demonstration identify and account for the limits on data quality rather than by excluding data
label: BODY

text: from consideration” (EPA 1988).
label: BODY

text: As site characterization activities progressed, the DOE, along with independent review groups
label: BODY

text: such as the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), the Environmental Evaluation Group (EEG),
label: BODY

text: and the state of New Mexico acting through the Governor’s Radioactive Waste Consultation
label: BODY

text: Task Force, identified natural  FEPs that required additional detailed investigation.  Because
label: BODY

text: these investigations, in many cases, were to gather data that would either be used in developing
label: BODY

text: conceptual models or in the prediction of disposal system performance, the quality assurance
label: BODY

text: (QA) standards applied to these investigations were more stringent, thereby ensuring accuracy
label: BODY

text: and repeatability to the extent possible for geologic investigations.
label: BODY

text: Geological data from site characterization have been developed by the DOE through a variety of
label: BODY

text: WIPP-sponsored studies using drilling, mapping or other direct observation, geophysical
label: BODY

text: techniques, and laboratory work.  Most of the techniques and statistics of data acquisition will be
label: BODY

text: incorporated by specific discussion.  The processes used in deriving modeling parameters from
label: BODY

text: field and laboratory data are discussed in records packages which support the conceptual models
label: BODY

text: in Section 6.4 and the parameters in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR.  Pointers to these records
label: BODY

text: packages are provided principally in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR.  Records packages are
label: BODY

text: stored in the Sandia WIPP Records Center in Carlsbad.  Access to review of these records
label: BODY

text: packages can be obtained by contacting the person designated in Table 1-10.  Borehole
label: BODY

text: investigations are a major source of geological data for the WIPP and surrounding area.
label: BODY

text: Borehole studies provide raw data (for example, depth measurements, amount of core,
label: BODY

text: geophysical logs) that support point data and interpreted data sets.  These data sets are used in
label: BODY

text: developing other analysis tools such as structure maps for selected stratigraphic horizons or
label: BODY

text: isopachs (thicknesses) of selected stratigraphic intervals.
label: BODY

text: The borehole data set that was used specifically for obtaining WIPP geologic information is
label: BODY

text: included as reference information in CCA Appendix BH. A map of some borehole locations in
label: BODY

text: the data set is provided in Figure 2-2.  Figure 2-3 shows Culebra monitoring wells within the site
label: BODY

text: boundary as of December 2002, including well C-2737, which was drilled and completed in
label: BODY

text: 2001 (Powers 2002c).  Figure 2-4 shows Culebra monitoring wells outside the WIPP site as of
label: BODY

text: December 2002; plugged and abandoned wells formerly monitored are not included in this
label: BODY

text: figure. Figure 2-5 shows the locations of wells configured to monitor the Magenta, including
label: BODY

text: well C-2737.  Other hydrostratigraphic units are monitored in wells shown in Figure 2-6,
label: BODY

text: including well C-2811, which was drilled and completed in 2001 to monitor a shallow saturated
label: BODY

text: zone developed since the WIPP surface structures were constructed (Powers and Stensrud 2003).
label: BODY

text: Other holes are not shown because they were not of sufficient depth, were not cored, or were not
label: BODY

text: drilled for purposes of site characterization.  A more comprehensive drillhole database of the

text: 2.1.2 Geologic History
label: HH2

text: In this section, the DOE summarizes the more important points of the area’s geologic history
label: BODY

text: within about 320 km (200 mi) of the WIPP site, with emphasis on more recent or nearby events.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-7 shows the major elements of the area’s geological history from the end of the
label: BODY

text: Precambrian Period.
label: BODY

text: The geologic time scale that the DOE uses for WIPP is based on the compilation by Palmer
label: BODY

text: (1983, pp. 503 – 504) for The Decade of North American Geology (DNAG).  There are several
label: BODY

text: compiled sources of chronologic data related to different reference sections or methods (see, for
label: BODY

text: example, Harland et al. 1989 and Salvador 1985.  Although most of these sources show generally
label: BODY

text: similar ages for chronostratigraphic boundaries, there is no consensus on either reference
label: BODY

text: boundaries or most-representative ages.  The DNAG scale is accepted by the DOE as a standard
label: BODY

text: that is useful and sufficient for WIPP purposes, as no known critical performance assessment
label: BODY

text: parameters require more accurate or precise dates.
label: BODY

text: The geologic history in this region can be conveniently subdivided into three general phases:
label: BODY

text: • A Precambrian Period, represented by metamorphic and igneous rocks ranging in age
label: BODY

text: from about 1.5 to 1.1 billion years;
label: BODY

text: • A period from about 1.1 to 0.6 billion years ago, from which no rocks are preserved.
label: BODY

text: Erosion may have been the dominant process during much of this period; and
label: BODY

text: • An interval from 0.6 billion years ago to the present represented by a more complex set
label: BODY

text: of mainly sedimentary rocks and shorter periods of erosion and dissolution.
label: BODY

text: This latter phase is the main subject of the DOE’s detailed discussion in this text.
label: BODY

text: Only a few boreholes in the WIPP region have bored deep enough to penetrate Precambrian
label: BODY

text: crystalline rocks, and, therefore, relatively little petrological information is available.  Foster
label: BODY

text: (1974, Figure 3) extrapolated the elevation of the Precambrian surface under the area of WIPP as
label: BODY

text: being between 4.42 km (14,500 ft) and 4.57 km (15,000 ft) below sea level; the site surface at
label: BODY

text: WIPP is about 1,036 m (3,400 ft) above sea level.  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2)
label: BODY

text: projected a depth of about 5,545 m (18,200 ft) from the surface to the top of Precambrian rocks
label: BODY

text: in the vicinity of the WIPP.  The depth projection is based on the geology of the nearby borehole
label: BODY

text: in Section 15, T22S, R31E.
label: BODY

text: Precambrian rocks of several types crop out in the following locations:  the Sacramento
label: BODY

text: Mountains northwest of WIPP; around the Sierra Diablo and Baylor Mountains near Van Horn,
label: BODY

text: Texas; west of the Guadalupe Mountains at Pump Station Hills; and in the Franklin Mountains
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: near El Paso, Texas.  East of the WIPP, a relatively large number of boreholes on the Central
label: BODY

text: Basin Platform have penetrated the top of the Precambrian (Foster 1974, Figure 3).  As
label: BODY

text: summarized by Foster (1974, 10), Precambrian rocks in the area considered similar to those in
label: BODY

text: the vicinity of the site range in age from about 1.14 to 1.35 billion years.
label: BODY

text: For about 500 million years (1.1 to 0.6 billion years ago), there is no certain rock record in the
label: BODY

text: region around the WIPP.  The most likely rock record for this period may be the Van Horn
label: BODY

text: sandstone (McGowan and Groat 1971), but there is no conclusive evidence that it represents part
label: BODY

text: of this time period (CCA Appendix GCR, Section 3.3.1).  The region is generally thought to
label: BODY

text: have been subject to erosion for much of the period until the Bliss sandstone began to
label: BODY

text: accumulate during the Cambrian.
label: BODY

text: There is additional geologic history information contained in the EPA Technical Support
label: BODY

text: Document for Section 194.14: Content of Compliance Certification Application, Section IV
label: BODY

text: (Docket A-93-02, Item V-B-3).

text: 2.1.3 Stratigraphy and Lithology in the Vicinity of the WIPP Site
label: HH2

text: The conceptual model of the disposal system uses information about the geometry of the various
label: BODY

text: rock layers as a model input as described in Section 6.4.2.1.  This means that stratigraphic
label: BODY

text: information (thickness and lateral extent) provided in the following sections are important inputs.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-6.  Locations of Monitoring Wells Completed to Hydrostratigraphic Units Other
label: HH2

text: Than the Culebra and Magenta Dolomite Members (See also Figure 2-39).
label: BODY

text: In addition, less important features such as the lithology and the presence of geochemically
label: BODY

text: significant minerals are provided to support screening arguments in Appendix PA, Attachment
label: BODY

text: SCR.  Consequently, this discussion has focused on the general properties of the various rock
label: BODY

text: units as determined from field studies.  Specific parameters used in the modeling described in
label: BODY

text: Sections 6.4.5 and 6.4.6 are summarized in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR.  Stratigraphy-
label: BODY

text: related parameters are input as constants.  Stratigraphic thicknesses of units considered in
label: BODY

text: modeling are compiled in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR, Table PAR-49.
label: BODY

text: This section describes the stratigraphy and lithology of the Paleozoic and younger rocks
label: BODY

text: underlying the WIPP site and vicinity (Figure 2-8), emphasizing the units nearer the surface.
label: BODY

text: After briefly describing pre-Permian rocks, the section provides detailed information on the
label: BODY

text: Permian (Guadalupian) Bell Canyon Formation (hereafter referred to as the Bell Canyon)—the
label: BODY

text: upper unit of the Delaware Mountain Group—because this is the uppermost transmissive
label: BODY

text: formation below the evaporites.  The principal stratigraphic data are the chronologic sequence,
label: BODY

text: age, and extent of rock units, including some of the nearby relevant facies changes.  For deeper
label: BODY

text: rocks, characteristics such as thickness and depth are summarized from published sources, and
label: BODY

text: for shallower rocks, they are mainly based on data sets presented in CCA Appendix BH (above
label: BODY

text: the Bell Canyon).  The lithologies of upper formations and some formation members are
label: BODY

text: described.  A comprehensive discussion of stratigraphy in the WIPP area is presented in CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix GCR.  Detailed referencing to original investigations by the USGS and others is
label: BODY

text: included.

text: 2.1.3.1 General Stratigraphy and Lithology below the Bell Canyon
label: BODY

text: As stated previously, the Precambrian basement near the site is projected to be about 5,545 m
label: BODY

text: (18,200 ft) below the surface (Keesey 1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2), consistent with information
label: BODY

text: presented by Foster in 1974.  Ages of similar rock suites in the region range from about 1.14 to
label: BODY

text: 1.35 billion years.
label: BODY

text: A detailed discussion of the distribution of Precambrian rocks in southeastern New Mexico and
label: BODY

text: Texas can be found in CCA Appendix GCR.  Figure 3.4-2 in CCA Appendix GCR provides a
label: BODY

text: structure contour map of the Precambrian. The basal Paleozoic units overlying Precambrian
label: BODY

text: rocks are clastic rocks commonly attributed either to the Cambrian Bliss sandstone or the
label: BODY

text: Ellenberger Group (Foster 1974, p. 10), considered most likely to be Ordovician in age in this
label: BODY

text: area.  The Ordovician System comprises the Ellenberger, Simpson, and Montoya Groups in the
label: BODY

text: northern Delaware Basin.  Carbonates are predominant in these groups, with sandstones and
label: BODY

text: shales common in the Simpson Group.  Foster (1974, Figure 4) reported 297 m (975 ft) of
label: BODY

text: Ordovician-age rocks north of the site area and extrapolated a thicker section of about 396 m
label: BODY

text: (1,300 ft) at the present site (Foster 1974, Figure 5).  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2)
label: BODY

text: projected a thickness of 366 m (1,200 ft) for the Ordovician System within the site boundaries.
label: BODY

text: Silurian-Devonian rocks in the Delaware Basin are not stratigraphically well defined, and there
label: BODY

text: are various notions for extending nomenclature into the basin.  Common drilling practice is not
label: BODY

text: to differentiate, though the Upper Devonian Woodford shale at the top of the sequence is
label: BODY

text: frequently distinguished from the underlying dolomite and limestone (Foster 1974, p. 18).  Foster
label: BODY

text: (1974, Figure 6) showed a reference thickness of 384 and 49 m (1,260 and 160 ft) for the
label: BODY

text: carbonates and the Woodford shale, respectively; he estimated thickness of these units at the
label: BODY

text: present WIPP site to be about 351 m (1,150 ft) (Foster 1974, Figure 7) and 52 m (170 ft) (Foster
label: BODY

text: 1974, Figure 8), respectively.  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2) projected 381 m (1,250 ft)
label: BODY

text: of carbonate and showed 25 m (82 ft) of the Woodford shale.
label: BODY

text: The Mississippian System in the northern Delaware Basin is commonly attributed to
label: BODY

text: Mississippian limestone and the overlying Barnett shale (Foster 1974, p. 24), but the
label: BODY

text: nomenclature is not consistently used.  At the reference well used by Foster (1974, 25), the
label: BODY

text: limestone is 165 m (540 ft) thick and the shale is 24 m (80 ft); isopachs at the WIPP are 146 m
label: BODY

text: (480 ft) (Foster 1974, Figure 10) and less than 61 m (200 ft).  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No.
label: BODY

text: 2) indicates 156 m (511 ft) and 50 m (164 ft), respectively, within the site boundaries.
label: BODY

text: The nomenclature of the Pennsylvanian System applied within the Delaware Basin is both varied
label: BODY

text: and commonly inconsistent with accepted stratigraphic rules.  Chronostratigraphic, or time-
label: BODY

text: stratigraphic, names are applied from base to top of these lithologic units:  the Morrow, Atoka,
label: BODY

text: and Strawn (Foster 1974, p. 31).  Foster (1974, Figure 13) extrapolated thicknesses of about 671
label: BODY

text: m (2,200 ft) for the Pennsylvanian at the WIPP site.  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2)
label: BODY

text: reports 636 m (2,088 ft) for these units.  The Pennsylvanian rocks in this area are mixed clastics
label: BODY

text: and carbonates, with carbonates more abundant in the upper half of the sequence.
label: BODY

text: The Permian is the thickest system in the northern Delaware Basin, and it is divided into four
label: BODY

text: series from the base to top:  Wolfcampian, Leonardian, Guadalupian, and Ochoan.  According to
label: BODY

text: Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2), the three lower series total 2,647 m (8,684 ft) near the site.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Foster (1974, Figures 14, 16, and 18) indicates a total thickness for the lower three series of
label: BODY

text: 2,336 m (7,665 ft) for a reference well north of WIPP.  Foster’s isopach maps of these series
label: BODY

text: (Foster 1974, Figures 15, 17, and 19) indicate about 2,591 m (8,500 ft) for the WIPP site area.
label: BODY

text: The Ochoan Series at the top of the Permian is considered in more detail later because the
label: BODY

text: formations host and surround the WIPP repository horizon.  Its thickness at DOE-2, about 3.2
label: BODY

text: km (2 mi) north of the site center, is 1,200 m (3,938 ft), according to Mercer et al. (1987, p. 23).
label: BODY

text: The Wolfcampian Series is also referred to as the Wolfcamp Formation (hereafter referred to as
label: BODY

text: the Wolfcamp) in the Delaware Basin.  In the site area, the lower part of the Wolfcamp is
label: BODY

text: dominantly shale with carbonate and some sandstone, according to Foster (1974, Figure 14);
label: BODY

text: carbonate increases to the north (Foster 1974, p. 36).  Clastics increase to the east toward the
label: BODY

text: margin of the Central Basin Platform.  Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2) reports the
label: BODY

text: Wolfcamp to be 455 m (1,493 ft) thick at a well near the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: The Leonardian Series is represented by the Bone Spring Limestone or Formation (hereafter
label: BODY

text: referred to as the Bone Spring).  According to Foster (1974, pp. 35 - 36), the lower part of the
label: BODY

text: formation is commonly interbedded carbonate, sandstone, and some shale, while the upper part is
label: BODY

text: dominantly carbonate.  Near the site the Bone Spring is 990 m (3,247 ft) thick, according to
label: BODY

text: Keesey (1976, Vol. II, Exhibit No. 2).
label: BODY

text: The Guadalupian Series is represented in the general area of the site by a number of formations
label: BODY

text: exhibiting complex facies relationships (Figure 2-9).  The Guadalupian Series is known in
label: BODY

text: considerable detail west of the site from outcrops in the Guadalupe Mountains, where numerous
label: BODY

text: outcrops are present and subsurface studies have been undertaken.  (See, for example, King
label: BODY

text: 1948, Newell et al. 1953, and Dunham 1972 in the CCA bibliography.)
label: BODY

text: Within the Delaware Basin, the Guadalupian Series, known as the Delaware Mountain Group,
label: BODY

text: comprises three formations:  Brushy Canyon, Cherry Canyon, and Bell Canyon, from base to
label: BODY

text: top.  These formations are dominated by submarine channel sandstones with interbedded
label: BODY

text: limestone and some shale.  The Lamar limestone generally tops the series, immediately
label: BODY

text: underneath the Castile Formation (hereafter referred to as the Castile).  Around the margin of the
label: BODY

text: Delaware Basin, reefs developed when the Cherry Canyon and Bell Canyon were being
label: BODY

text: deposited.  These massive reef limestones, the Goat Seep and Capitan Limestones, are equivalent
label: BODY

text: in time to the basin sandstone formations but were developed topographically much higher
label: BODY

text: around the basin margin.  A complex set of limestone-to-sandstone and evaporite beds was
label: BODY

text: deposited further away from the basin, behind the reef limestones.  The Capitan Reef and back-
label: BODY

text: reef limestones are well known because numerous caves, including the Carlsbad Caverns, are
label: BODY

text: partially developed in these rocks.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.2 The Bell Canyon
label: BODY

text: As will be discussed in Section 2.1.3.3, the Castile is a 427-to-487m (1,400-to-1,600ft) thick
label: BODY

text: layer of nearly impermeable anhydrites and halites that isolate the Salado from the

text: deeper water-bearing rocks.  This notwithstanding, the DOE is interested in the Bell Canyon
label: BODY

text: because it is the first laterally continuous transmissive unit below the WIPP repository.  The
label: BODY

text: significance of this unit is related to the FEP in Table 2-1 for deep dissolution.  In evaluating this
label: BODY

text: FEP, the DOE considers the potential for groundwater to migrate from the Bell Canyon or lower
label: BODY

text: units into the repository and cause dissolution.  The following discussion summarizes the basic
label: BODY

text: understanding of the Bell Canyon lithology.  Dissolution is discussed in Section 2.1.6.  Bell
label: BODY

text: Canyon hydrology is presented in Section 2.2.1.2.  A thorough discussion of dissolution is in
label: BODY

text: CCA Appendix DEF.
label: BODY

text: The Bell Canyon is known from outcrops on the west side of the Delaware Basin and from
label: BODY

text: subsurface intercepts for oil and gas drilling.  Several informal lithologic units are commonly
label: BODY

text: named during such drilling.  Mercer et al. (1987, p. 28) stated that DOE-2 penetrated the Lamar
label: BODY

text: limestone, the Ramsey sand, the Ford shale, the Olds sand, and the Hays sand.  This informal
label: BODY

text: nomenclature is used for the Bell Canyon in some other WIPP reports.
label: BODY

text: The Clayton Williams Badger Federal borehole (Section 15, T22S, R31E) intercepted 961 feet
label: BODY

text: (293 meters) of Bell Canyon, including the Lamar limestone, according to Keesey (1976, Vol. II,
label: BODY

text: Exhibit No. 2).  Reservoir sandstones of the Bell Canyon were deposited in channels that are
label: BODY

text: straight to slightly sinuous.  In their 1988 paper, Harms and Williamson proposed that density
label: BODY

text: currents flowed from shelf regions, cutting channels and depositing the sands.
label: BODY

text: Within the basin, the Bell Canyon (Lamar limestone) Castile contact is distinctive on
label: BODY

text: geophysical logs because of the contrast in low natural gamma of the basal Castile anhydrite
label: BODY

text: compared to the underlying limestone.  Density or acoustic logs are also distinctive because of
label: BODY

text: the massive and uniform lithology of the anhydrite compared to the underlying beds.  In cores,
label: BODY

text: the transition is sharp, as described by Mercer et al. (1987, 312) for DOE-2.  A structure contour
label: BODY

text: map of the top of the Bell Canyon is shown in Figure 2-10.  Also see CCA Appendix MASS,
label: BODY

text: MASS Attachment 18-6, Figure 5.3-3.  According to Powers et al. (1978) (CCA Appendix GCR,
label: BODY

text: 4–59), this structure does not reflect the structure of deeper formations, suggesting different
label: BODY

text: deformation histories.  The rootless character of at least some of the normal faulting in the lower
label: BODY

text: Permian suggests these are shallow-seated features.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.3 The Castile
label: BODY

text: The Castile is the lowermost lithostratigraphic unit of the Late Permian Ochoan Series (Figure 2-
label: BODY

text: 11) and is part of the thick layer of evaporites within the WIPP disposal system.  It was
label: BODY

text: originally named by Richardson (1904, p. 43) for outcrops in Culberson County, Texas.
label: BODY

text: The Castile crops out along a lengthy area of the western side of the Delaware Basin.  The two
label: BODY

text: distinctive lithologic sequences now known as the Castile and the Salado were separated into the
label: BODY

text: Upper and Lower Castile by Cartwright (1930).  Lang (1939) clarified the nomenclature by
label: BODY

text: restricting the Castile to the lower unit and naming the upper unit the Salado.  By defining an
label: BODY

text: anhydrite resting on the marginal Capitan limestone as part of the Salado, Lang in 1939
label: BODY

text: effectively restricted the Castile to the Delaware Basin inside the reef rocks.

label: BODY

text: Through detailed studies of the Castile, Anderson et al. (1972) introduced an informal system of
label: BODY

text: names that is widely used and included in many WIPP reports.  The units are named from the
label: BODY

text: base as anhydrite I (A1), halite I (H1), anhydrite II (A2), etc.  The informal nomenclature varies
label: BODY

text: through the basin from A3 up because of complexity of the depositional system.  The Castile
label: BODY

text: consists almost entirely of thick beds of two lithologies:  (1) interlaminated carbonate and
label: BODY

text: anhydrite, and (2) high-purity halite.
label: BODY

text: In the eastern part of the Delaware basin, the Castile thickness ranges from about 299 to 616 m
label: BODY

text: (980 to 2,022 ft) (derived from Powers et al. 1996, Figure 5.3-1; see also Borns and Shaffer
label: BODY

text: 1985, Figures 9, 11, and 16 for an earlier range based on fewer drillholes).  At DOE-2, the
label: BODY

text: Castile is 301 m (989 ft) thick.  The Castile is thinner in the western part of the Delaware Basin,
label: BODY

text: and it lacks halite units.
label: BODY

text: Anderson et al. (1978) and Anderson (1978, Figures 1, 3, 4, and 5) correlated geophysical logs
label: BODY

text: throughout the WIPP region, interpreting thin zones equivalent to halite units as dissolution
label: BODY

text: residues.  Anderson et al. (1972, p. 81) further attributed the lack of halite in the basin to its
label: BODY

text: removal by dissolution.  A structure contour map of the top of the Castile is reported in Figure
label: BODY

text: 4.4-6, CCA Appendix GCR based on seismic data gathered for site characterization.  In addition,
label: BODY

text: Borns et al. (1983) prepared a seismic time structure of the middle Castile for identifying
label: BODY

text: deformation.  This map is shown in Figure DEF-2.2 in CCA Appendix DEF.  Powers et al.
label: BODY

text: (1996; Figures 5.2-1, 5.2-2, and 5.2-3) provide comparative figures of the elevations of the top of
label: BODY

text: the Bell Canyon, top of Anhydrite 2 (of the Castile), and top of Anhydrite 3 (of the Castile),
label: BODY

text: respectively, based on geophysical log data from oil and gas wells.
label: BODY

text: For borehole DOE-2, a primary objective was to ascertain whether a series of depressions in the
label: BODY

text: Salado 3.3 km (2 mi) north of the site center was from dissolution in the Castile and related
label: BODY

text: processes, as proposed by Davies (1984, p. 175) in his doctoral thesis. Studies have suggested
label: BODY

text: that these depressions were not from dissolution but from halokinesis in the Castile (see, for
label: BODY

text: example, Borns 1987).  Robinson and Powers (1987, pp. 22 and 78) interpreted one deformed
label: BODY

text: zone in the Castile in the western part of the Delaware Basin as partly caused by synsedimentary,
label: BODY

text: gravity-driven, clastic deposition and suggested that the extent of dissolution may have been
label: BODY

text: overestimated by previous workers. No Castile dissolution is known to be present in the
label: BODY

text: immediate vicinity of the WIPP site. The process of dissolution and the resulting features are
label: BODY

text: discussed later in this chapter. See CCA Appendix DEF, Section DEF.3 for a more in-depth
label: BODY

text: discussion of the study of dissolution in the Castile.
label: BODY

text: In Culberson County, Texas, the Castile hosts major native sulfur deposits.  The outcrops of
label: BODY

text: Castile on the Gypsum Plain south of White’s City, New Mexico, have been explored for native
label: BODY

text: sulfur without success, and there is no reported indication of native sulfur anywhere in the
label: BODY

text: vicinity of the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: In part of the area around the WIPP, the Castile has been significantly deformed and there are
label: BODY

text: pressurized brines associated with the deformed areas; borehole ERDA-6 encountered both
label: BODY

text: deformation and pressurized brine.  WIPP-12, 1.6 km (1 mi) north of the site center, revealed
label: BODY

text: lesser Castile structure, but it also encountered a zone of pressurized brine within the Castile.
label: BODY

text: Castile deformation is described and discussed in Section 2.1.5 and in CCA Appendix DEF,

text: which detail structural features.  Pressurized brine is described in Section 2.2.1, which details the
label: BODY

text: area’s hydrology.
label: BODY

text: Where they exist, Castile brine reservoirs in the northern Delaware Basin are believed to be
label: BODY

text: fractured systems, with high-angle fractures spaced widely enough that a borehole can penetrate
label: BODY

text: through a volume of rock containing a brine reservoir without intersecting any fractures and
label: BODY

text: therefore not produce brine.  They occur in the upper portion of the Castile (Popielak et al.
label: BODY

text: 1983).  Appreciable volumes of brine have been produced from several reservoirs in the
label: BODY

text: Delaware Basin, but there is little direct information on the areal extent of the reservoirs or the
label: BODY

text: interconnection between them.  The presence of a pressurized brine pocket is treated in the
label: BODY

text: conceptual model of WIPP as discussed in Section 6.4.8.
label: BODY

text: The Castile continues to be an object of research interest unrelated to the WIPP program as an
label: BODY

text: example of evaporites supposedly deposited in deep water.  Anderson (1993, pp. 12-13)
label: BODY

text: discusses alternatives and contradictory evidence.  Becker et al. (2002) presented a data set
label: BODY

text: yielding a total Pb/U isochron age of 251.5 ± 2.8 million years (Ma) for calcite from the Castile
label: BODY

text: and inferred that the Permo-Triassic boundary could be younger than this date.  This discussion
label: BODY

text: contrasts with other data regarding age of the Salado, Rustler, and Dewey Lake Formations (see
label: BODY

text: later sections), including evidence that later formations yield slightly older radiometric ages.
label: BODY

text: Although these discussions and a resolution might eventually affect some concepts of Castile
label: BODY

text: deposition and dissolution, this issue is largely of academic interest and bears no impact on the
label: BODY

text: suitability of the Los Medaños region for the WIPP site.  Additional discussion of Castile
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: of importance for this unit.  Important hydrological parameters are discussed subsequently.

text: 2.1.3.4 The Salado
label: BODY

text: The Salado is of interest because it contains the repository horizon and provides the primary
label: BODY

text: natural barrier for the long-term containment of radionuclides.  The following section provides
label: BODY

text: basic information regarding the genesis and lithology of the Salado.  Subsequent sections discuss
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Salado deformation, Salado dissolution, and Salado hydrology.  CCA Appendix GCR provides
label: BODY

text: detailed information about the Salado from early site characterization studies.
label: BODY

text: The Salado is dominated by halite, in contrast to the underlying Castile.  The Salado extends well
label: BODY

text: beyond the Delaware Basin, and Lowenstein (1988, p. 592) has termed the Salado a saline
label: BODY

text: “giant.”
label: BODY

text: While the Fletcher Anhydrite Member, which is deposited on the Capitan Reef rocks, is defined
label: BODY

text: by Lang (1939; 1942) as the base of the Salado, some investigators consider that the Fletcher
label: BODY

text: Anhydrite Member may interfinger with anhydrites normally considered part of the Castile.  The
label: BODY

text: Castile-Salado contact is not uniform across the basin, and whether it is conformable is
label: BODY

text: unresolved.  Around the WIPP site, the Castile-Salado contact is commonly placed at the top of a
label: BODY

text: thick anhydrite informally designated A3; the overlying halite is called the infra-Cowden salt and
label: BODY

text: is included within the Salado.  Bodine (1978, pp. 28 - 29) suggests that the clay mineralogy of
label: BODY

text: the infra-Cowden in ERDA-9 cores changes at about 4.6 m (15 ft) above the lowermost Salado
label: BODY

text: and that the lowermost clays are more like Castile clays.  At the WIPP site, the DOE recognizes
label: BODY

text: the top of the thick A3 anhydrite as the local contact for differentiating the Salado from the
label: BODY

text: Castile and notes that the distinction is related only to nomenclature and has no relevance to the
label: BODY

text: performance of the WIPP disposal system.
label: BODY

text: The Salado in the northern Delaware Basin is broadly divided into three informal members.  The
label: BODY

text: middle member is known locally as the McNutt Potash Zone (hereafter referred to as McNutt) or
label: BODY

text: Member, and it includes 11 defined potash zones, 10 of which are of economic significance in
label: BODY

text: the Carlsbad Potash District.  The lower member and the upper member remain unnamed.  The
label: BODY

text: WIPP repository level is located below the McNutt in the lower member.  Figure 2-12 shows
label: BODY

text: details of the Salado stratigraphy near the excavated regions.  Elements of this stratigraphy are
label: BODY

text: important to the conceptual model.  The conceptual model for the Salado is discussed in Section
label: BODY

text: 6.4.5.  The thicknesses used in the model are given in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR, Table
label: BODY

text: PAR-49.
label: BODY

text: Within the Delaware Basin, a system is used for numbering the more significant sulfate beds
label: BODY

text: within the Salado, designating these beds as marker beds (MBs) from MB 100 (near the top of
label: BODY

text: the formation) to MB 144 (near the base).  The system is generally used within the Carlsbad
label: BODY

text: Potash District as well as at and around the WIPP site.  The repository is located between MB
label: BODY

text: 139 and MB 138.
label: BODY

text: In the central and eastern part of the Delaware Basin, the Salado is at its thickest, ranging up to
label: BODY

text: about 600 m (2,000 ft) thick and consisting mainly of interbeds of sulfate minerals and halite,
label: BODY

text: with halite dominating.  The thinnest portions of the Salado consist of a brecciated residue of
label: BODY

text: insoluble material a few tens-of-feet thick, which is exposed in parts of the western Delaware
label: BODY

text: Basin.  The common sulfate minerals are anhydrite (CaSO4), gypsum (CaSO4 • 2H2O) near the
label: BODY

text: surface, and polyhalite (K2SO4 • MgSO4 • 2CaSO4 • 2H2O).  They form interbeds and are also
label: BODY

text: found along halite grain boundaries.  Isopach maps of various intervals of the Salado above the
label: BODY

text: repository horizon have been provided to assist in understanding regional structure.  These are
label: BODY

text: Figures 4.3-4 to 4.3-7 in CCA Appendix GCR.  A structure contour map of the Salado can be
label: BODY

text: found in CCA Appendix GCR (Figure 4.4-10).

text: In the vicinity of the repository, authigenic quartz (SiO2) and magnesite (MgCO3) are also
label: BODY

text: present as accessory minerals.  Interbeds in the salt are predominantly anhydrite with seams of
label: BODY

text: clay.  The clays within the Salado are enriched in magnesium and depleted in aluminum (Bodine
label: BODY

text: 1978, p. 1).  The magnesium enrichment probably reflects the intimate contact of the clays with
label: BODY

text: brines derived from evaporating sea water, which are relatively high in magnesium.
label: BODY

text: Powers et al. (Chapter 7 of CCA Appendix GCR) studied the geochemistry of the rocks in the
label: BODY

text: vicinity of the disposal system.  A partial list of minerals found in the Delaware Basin evaporites,
label: BODY

text: together with their chemical formulas, is given in Table 2-2.  The table also indicates the relative
label: BODY

text: abundances of the minerals in the evaporite rocks of the Castile, Salado, and Rustler.  Minerals
label: BODY

text: found either only at depth, removed from influence of weathering, or only near the surface, as
label: BODY

text: weathering products, are also identified.

label: BODY

text: Although the most common Delaware Basin evaporite mineral is halite, the presence of less
label: BODY

text: soluble interbeds (dominantly anhydrite, polyhalite, and claystone) and more soluble admixtures
label: BODY

text: (for example, sylvite, glauberite, kainite) has resulted in chemical and physical properties of the
label: BODY

text: bulk Salado that are significantly different from those of pure halite layers contained within it.
label: BODY

text: In particular, the McNutt, between MB 116 and MB 126, is locally explored and mined for
label: BODY

text: potassium-bearing minerals of economic interest.  Under differential stress, interbeds (anhydrite,
label: BODY

text: polyhalite, magnesite, dolomite) may fracture while, under the same stress regime, pure halite
label: BODY

text: would undergo plastic deformation.  Fracturing of relatively brittle beds, for example, has locally
label: BODY

text: enhanced the permeability, allowing otherwise nonporous rock to carry groundwater.  Some
label: BODY

text: soluble minerals incorporated in the rock salt can be radiometrically dated, and their dates
label: BODY

text: indicate the time of their formation.  The survival of such minerals is significant, in that such
label: BODY

text: dating is impossible in pure halite or anhydrite.
label: BODY

text: Liquids were collected from fluid inclusions in the Salado halite and from seeps and boreholes
label: BODY

text: within the WIPP drifts.  Analysis of these samples indicated that there is compositional
label: BODY

text: variability in the fluids that shows the effects of various phase transformations on brine
label: BODY

text: composition.  The fluid inclusions belong to a different chemical population than do the fluids
label: BODY

text: emanating from the walls.  It was concluded that much of the brine is completely immobilized
label: BODY

text: within the salt and that the free liquid emanating from the walls is present as a fluid film along
label: BODY

text: intergranular boundaries, mainly in clays and in fractures in anhydrites.  Additional information
label: BODY

text: can be found in CCA Appendix GCR, Sections 7.5 and 7.6.
label: BODY

text: Early investigators of the Salado recognized a repetitious vertical succession or cycle of beds in
label: BODY

text: the Salado:  clay - anhydrite - polyhalite - halite and minor polyhalite - halite.  Later investigators
label: BODY

text: described the cyclical units as clay - magnesite - anhydrite or polyhalite or glauberite - halite -
label: BODY

text: argillaceous halite capped by mudstone.  Lowenstein (1988, pp. 592 - 608) defined a
label: BODY

text: depositional cycle (Type I) consisting of (1) basal mixed siliciclastic and carbonate (magnesite)
label: BODY

text: mudstone, (2) laminated to massive anhydrite or polyhalite, (3) halite, and (4) halite with mud.
label: BODY

text: Lowenstein also recognized repetitious sequences of halite and halite with mud as incomplete
label: BODY

text: Type I cycles and termed them Type II cycles.  Lowenstein (1988, pp. 592 - 608) interpreted the
label: BODY

text: Type I cycles as having formed in a shallowing upward, desiccating basin beginning with a
label: BODY

text: perennial lake or lagoon of marine origin and evaporating to saline lagoon and salt pan
label: BODY

text: environments.  Type II cycles are differentiated because they do not exhibit features of
label: BODY

text: prolonged subaqueous deposition and also have more siliciclastic influx than do Type I cycles.
label: BODY

text: From detailed mapping of the Salado in the air intake shaft (AIS) at WIPP, Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (1990a, pp. 2-26) interpreted depositional cycles of the Salado in terms of modern features such
label: BODY

text: as those at Devil’s Golf Course at Death Valley National Monument, California.  The
label: BODY

text: evaporative basin was desiccated, and varying amounts of insoluble residues had collected on the
label: BODY

text: surface through surficial dissolution, eolian sedimentation, and some clastic sedimentation from
label: BODY

text: temporary flooding caused from surrounding areas.  The surface developed local relief that could
label: BODY

text: be mapped in some cycles, while the action of continuing desiccation and exposure increasingly
label: BODY

text: concentrated insoluble residues.  Flooding, most commonly from marine sources, reset the
label: BODY

text: sedimentary cycle by depositing a sulfate bed.
label: BODY

text: The details available from the shaft demonstrated the important role of syndepositional water
label: BODY

text: level to water table changes that created solution pits and pipes within the halitic beds while they
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: were at the surface.  Holt and Powers (1990a, Appendix F) concluded that passive halite cements
label: BODY

text: filled the pits and pipes, as well as less dramatic voids, as the water table rose.  Early diagenetic
label: BODY

text: to synsedimentary cements filled the porosity early and rather completely with commonly clear
label: BODY

text: and coarsely crystalline halite, reducing the porosity to a very small volume according to Casas
label: BODY

text: and Lowenstein (1989).
label: BODY

text: Although Holt and Powers (1990a) found no evidence for postdepositional halite dissolution in
label: BODY

text: the AIS, dissolution of the upper Salado halite has occurred west of the WIPP.  Effects of
label: BODY

text: dissolution are visible in Nash Draw and at other localities where gypsum karst has formed,
label: BODY

text: where units above the Salado such as the Rustler Formation, Dewey Lake Redbeds, and post-
label: BODY

text: Permian rocks have subsided.  Dissolution studies are summarized in CCA Appendix DEF,
label: BODY

text: Section DEF.3.  The dissolution margin of upper Salado halite (see Figure 2-13), based on
label: BODY

text: changes in thickness of the interval from the Culebra dolomite to the Vaca Triste Sandstone
label: BODY

text: Member of the Salado, has been interpreted in detail by Powers (2002a, 2002b, 2003a), Holt and
label: BODY

text: Powers (2002), and Powers et al. (2003).  Powers (2002a, 2002b, 2003a) examined data from
label: BODY

text: additional drillholes and noted that the upper Salado dissolution margin appears relatively
label: BODY

text: narrow in many areas, and it directly underlies much of Livingston Ridge.  The hydraulic
label: BODY

text: properties of the Culebra correlate in part with dissolution of halite from the upper Salado (Holt
label: BODY

text: and Yarbrough 2002; Powers et al. 2003), and the relationships are further described in Section
label: BODY

text: Within Nash Draw, Robinson and Lang (1938, pp. 87-88) recognized a zone equivalent to the
label: BODY

text: upper Salado but lacking halite.  Test wells in southern Nash Draw produced brine from this
label: BODY

text: interval, and it has become known as the brine aquifer.  Robinson and Lang (1938) considered
label: BODY

text: this zone a residuum from dissolution of Salado halite (see Section 2.1.6.2).  Jones et al. (1960)
label: BODY

text: remarked that the residuum should be considered part of the Salado, though in geophysical logs
label: BODY

text: it may resemble the lower Rustler.  The approximate eastern limit of the residuum and brine
label: BODY

text: aquifer lies near Livingston Ridge (the eastward margin of Nash Draw) and is marked by a
label: BODY

text: thickening of the Salado (see Section 2.1.6.2.2).
label: BODY

text: At the center of the site, Holt and Powers (1984, pp. 4-9) recognized clasts of fossil fragments
label: BODY

text: and mapped channeling in siltstones and mudstones above the halite; they considered these beds
label: BODY

text: to be a normal part of the transition from the shallow evaporative lagoons and desiccated salt
label: BODY

text: pans of the Salado to the saline lagoon of the lower Rustler.  Although some Salado halite
label: BODY

text: dissolution at the WIPP may have occurred before deposition of the Rustler clastics, this process
label: BODY

text: was quite different from the subsurface removal of salt from the Salado in more recent time that
label: BODY

text: caused the residuum and associated brine aquifer in Nash Draw.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Geochronological investigations provide a means to confirm the physical evidence indicating
label: BODY

text: that little or no rock-water interactions have occurred in the Salado at the WIPP since the Late
label: BODY

text: Permian Period.  Radiometric techniques provide a means of determining the approximate time
label: BODY

text: of the latest episode of regional recrystallization of evaporite minerals, which can be inferred as
label: BODY

text: the approximate time of the latest episode of freely circulating groundwater.  Radiometric dates
label: BODY

text: for minerals of the Salado are available from mines and boreholes in the vicinity of the WIPP
label: BODY

text: (Register and Brookins, 1980, pp. 30-42; Brookins, 1980, pp. 29-31; Brookins, et al. 1980, pp.
label: BODY

text: 635-637; Brookins, 1981; and Brookins and Lambert, 1987, pp. 771-780).  The distribution of
label: BODY

text: dates shows that many of the rubidium-strontium (Rb-Sr) isochron determinations on evaporite
label: BODY

text: minerals, largely sylvite (214 ± 14 million years ago), are in good agreement with potassium-
label: BODY

text: argon (K-Ar) determinations on pure polyhalites (198 to 216 million years ago).  (Potassium-
label: BODY

text: argon ages for sylvite are significantly younger than Rb-Sr ages for the same rocks because of
label: BODY

text: the loss of radiogenic argon.  Radiogenic strontium, as a solid, is less mobile than argon and
label: BODY

text: therefore the Rb-Sr isochron method is preferred for sylvite.)  Renne et al. (1998) sampled
label: BODY

text: langbeinite crystals from the Salado and obtained Ar-39/Ar-40 plateau ages of 251 ± 0.2 Ma and
label: BODY

text: 251 ± 0.4 Ma.  Clay minerals have both Rb-Sr and K-Ar ages significantly older (390 ± 77
label: BODY

text: million years [Register, 1981]) than the evaporite minerals, presumably reflecting the detrital
label: BODY

text: origin of the clays.
label: BODY

text: One significantly younger recrystallization event has been identified in evaporites in the WIPP
label: BODY

text: region and is a contact phenomenon associated with the emplacement of an Oligocene igneous
label: BODY

text: dike (see Section 2.1.5.4).  Polyhalite near the dike yields a radiometric age of 21 million years,
label: BODY

text: compared to the 32- to 34-million-year age determined for the dike (Brookins, 1980, pp. 29-31;
label: BODY

text: and Calzia and Hiss, 1978, p. 44) (this number was recalculated to 34.8 ± 0.8 million years; CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix GCR, pp. 3 - 80).  This exception notwithstanding, the results of radiometric
label: BODY

text: determinations argue for the absence of pervasive recrystallization of the evaporites in the Salado
label: BODY

text: in the last 200 million years.  This conclusion is supported by the number of replicate
label: BODY

text: determinations, the wide distribution of similarly dated minerals throughout the Delaware Basin,
label: BODY

text: and the concordance of dates obtained by various radiometric methods.
label: BODY

text: The notion of extensive recrystallization of Salado evaporites has been raised again since the
label: BODY

text: CCA was submitted.  Hazen and Roedder (2001), reiterating some arguments presented by
label: BODY

text: Roedder (1984) and O’Neill et al. (1986), suggested that halite has been extensively
label: BODY

text: recrystallized by water moving through the Salado at unknown times.  Stable isotope data from
label: BODY

text: fluid inclusions within coarse, clear halite crystals were interpreted as signifying that modern
label: BODY

text: meteoric water constituted part of the fluid inclusion.  O’Neill et al. (1986) noted as well that the
label: BODY

text: stable isotope data are consistent with meteoric water falling on a desiccated Salado salt pan
label: BODY

text: surface.  Powers and Hassinger (1985) and Holt and Powers (1990a, 1990b) interpret
label: BODY

text: syndepositional dissolution pipes as a common feature of the Salado, with coarse, clear halite
label: BODY

text: with large fluid inclusions formed on a desiccated salt pan.  Powers et al. (2001) summarized the
label: BODY

text: arguments against extensive recrystallization of Salado halite.  Stein and Krumhansl (1988)
label: BODY

text: found variable compositions of large fluid inclusions, and show that inclusion chemistry differs
label: BODY

text: significantly from intercrystalline brines, indicating that fluid movement is very limited.
label: BODY

text: Satterfield et al. (2002) also concluded that the coarse halite cements found in certain beds of the
label: BODY

text: Salado are synsedimentary, based on ionic concentrations in fluid inclusions.  Moreover,
label: BODY

text: Beauheim and Roberts (2002) find extremely low permeability in Salado halite, showing that
label: BODY

text: fluid movement, especially vertically, through the Salado is too limited and slow to create the
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: purported recrystallization.  These findings are also consistent with indications that salt pan
label: BODY

text: deposits are cemented quickly and thoroughly at shallow depths of burial (Casas and Lowenstein
label: BODY

text: 1989).  The conclusion that Salado halite has not been pervasively recrystallized remains sound.
label: BODY

text: The Salado is of primary importance to the containment of waste.  Because it is the principal
label: BODY

text: natural barrier, many of the properties of the Salado have been characterized by the DOE, and
label: BODY

text: numerical codes are used by the DOE to simulate the natural processes within the Salado that
label: BODY

text: affect the disposal system performance.
label: BODY

text: Two conceptual models of the Salado are used in the performance assessment.  One models the
label: BODY

text: creep closure properties of the Salado and the other, the hydrological properties.  The creep
label: BODY

text: closure of the Salado is discussed in Appendix PA, Attachment PORSURF.  This model uses key
label: BODY

text: parameters derived from both in-situ measurements and laboratory testing on Salado core
label: BODY

text: samples.  Summaries of these parameters are in Butcher (1997). Appendix PORSURF
label: BODY

text: Attachment 1, Table 2.
label: BODY

text: The second conceptual model is titled the Salado conceptual model and is discussed in Section
label: BODY

text: 6.4.5.  This model divides the Salado into two lithologic units:  impure halite and Salado
label: BODY

text: interbeds.  The impure halite in this conceptual model is characterized entirely by its
label: BODY

text: hydrological parameters as shown in Table 6-16.  The interbeds are characterized by both
label: BODY

text: hydrological parameters in Table 6-17 and fracture properties in Table 6-19.  This latter
label: BODY

text: information is needed since the model in Section 6.4.5.2 incorporates the possibility of interbed
label: BODY

text: fracturing should pressures in the repository become high enough.  The modeling assumptions
label: BODY

text: surrounding the fracturing model are discussed in Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section
label: BODY

text: MASS-13.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.5 The Rustler
label: BODY

text: The Rustler is the youngest evaporite-bearing formation in the Delaware Basin.  It was originally
label: BODY

text: named by Richardson in 1904 for outcrops in the Rustler Hills of Culberson County, Texas.
label: BODY

text: Adams (1944, p. 1614) first used the names Culebra Member and Magenta Member to describe
label: BODY

text: the two carbonates in the formation, indicating that Lang favored the names, although Lang did
label: BODY

text: not use these names to subdivide the Rustler in his 1942 publication.  Vine (1963, p. B1)
label: BODY

text: extensively described the Rustler in Nash Draw and proposed the four formal names and one
label: BODY

text: informal term that were used for the stratigraphic subdivisions of the Rustler.  These are as
label: BODY

text: follows (from the base):  unnamed lower member, Culebra Dolomite Member, Tamarisk
label: BODY

text: Member, Magenta Dolomite Member, and Forty-niner Member (Figure 2-14). Powers and Holt
label: BODY

text: (1999) formalized the nomenclature for the lower Rustler, naming the Los Medaños Member for
label: BODY

text: the exposures of the former “unnamed lower member” in the WIPP shafts and in boreholes in the
label: BODY

text: vicinity of Los Medaños near the WIPP site. Four studies of the Rustler since Vine’s 1963 work
label: BODY

text: contribute important information about the stratigraphy, sedimentology, and regional
label: BODY

text: relationships while examining more local details as well.  Eager (1983) published a report on
label: BODY

text: relationships of the Rustler observed in the southern Delaware Basin as part of sulfur exploration
label: BODY

text: in the area.  Holt and Powers (1988, Section 5.0), reproduced
label: BODY

text: as CCA Appendix FAC, reported the details of sedimentologic and stratigraphic studies of

text: WIPP shafts and cores as well as of geophysical logs from about 600 boreholes in southeastern

label: BODY

text: The Rustler is regionally extensive; a similar unit in the Texas panhandle is also called the
label: BODY

text: Rustler. Within the area around WIPP, evaporite units of the Rustler are interbedded with
label: BODY

text: significant siliciclastic beds and the carbonates.  Both the Magenta and the Culebra extend
label: BODY

text: regionally beyond areas of direct interest to the WIPP.  In the general area of the WIPP, both the
label: BODY

text: Tamarisk and the Forty-niner have similar lithologies:  lower and upper sulfate beds and a
label: BODY

text: middle unit that varies principally from mudstone to halite from west to east (Figure 2-14).  In a
label: BODY

text: general sense, halite in the Los Medaños broadly persists to the west of the WIPP site, and halite
label: BODY

text: is found east of the center of the WIPP in the Tamarisk and the Forty-niner (Figure 2-15).
label: BODY

text: Two different explanations have been proposed over the history of the project to account for the
label: BODY

text: observed distribution of halite in the non-dolomite members of the Rustler.  The earliest
label: BODY

text: researchers (e.g., Bachman [1985] and Snyder [1985]) assumed that halite had originally been
label: BODY

text: present in all the non-sulfate intervals of the Forty-niner, Tamarisk, and Los Medaños Members,
label: BODY

text: and that its present-day absence reflected post-depositional dissolution.
label: BODY

text: An alternative interpretation was presented by Holt and Powers (1988) following detailed
label: BODY

text: mapping of the Rustler exposed in the WIPP ventilation (now waste) and exhaust shafts in 1984.
label: BODY

text: Fossils, sedimentological features, and bedding relationships were identified in units that had
label: BODY

text: previously been interpreted from boreholes as dissolution residues. Cores from existing
label: BODY

text: boreholes, outcrops, geophysical logs, and petrographic data were also reexamined to establish
label: BODY

text: facies variability across the area.
label: BODY

text: As a result of these studies, the Rustler was interpreted to have formed in variable depositional
label: BODY

text: environments, including lagoon and saline playas, with two major episodes of marine flooding
label: BODY

text: which produced the carbonate units.  Sedimentary structures were interpreted to indicate
label: BODY

text: synsedimentary dissolution of halite from halitic mudstones around a saline playa and fluvial
label: BODY

text: transport of more distal clastic sediments.  The halite in the Rustler, by this interpretation, has a
label: BODY

text: present-day distribution similar to that at the time the unit was deposited.  Some localized
label: BODY

text: dissolution of halite may have occurred along the depositional margins, but not over large areas.
label: BODY

text: Hence, the absence of halite in Rustler members at the WIPP site more generally reflects non-
label: BODY

text: deposition than dissolution.
