text: This hypothesis was tested and refined by subsequent investigations (e.g., Powers and Holt 1990,
label: BODY

text: 1999, 2000; Holt and Powers 1990a) and is now considered the accepted explanation for the
label: BODY

text: present-day distribution of halite in the Rustler.  Powers and Holt (1999) thoroughly described
label: BODY

text: the sedimentary structures and stratigraphy of the Los Medaños as part of the procedure for
label: BODY

text: naming the unit.  This shows the basis for interpreting the depositional history of the member
label: BODY

text: and for rejecting significant post-burial dissolution of halite in that unit.  Powers and Holt (2000)
label: BODY

text: further describe the lateral facies relationships in other Rustler units, especially the Tamarisk,
label: BODY

text: developed on sedimentologic grounds, and rejected the concept of broad, lateral dissolution of
label: BODY

text: halite from the Rustler across the WIPP site area.
label: BODY

text: As discussed in Section 2.2.1.4, regional Culebra transmissivity shows about six orders of
label: BODY

text: magnitude variation across the area around the site and about three orders of magnitude across
label: BODY

text: the site itself.  Although some investigators have called attention to the broad relationship
label: BODY

text: between the distribution of halite in the Rustler and variations in Culebra transmissivity and have
label: BODY

text: attributed the variation to fracturing resulting from postdepositional dissolution of Rustler halite
label: BODY

text: (see, for example, Snyder 1985, p. 10; and CCA Appendix DEF, Section DEF-3.2), CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix FAC and Powers and Holt 1990, 1999, 2000) largely rule out this explanation.
label: BODY

text: Variations in transmissivity of the Culebra were correlated qualitatively to the thickness of
label: BODY

text: overburden above the Culebra (see discussion in Section 2.1.5.2), the amount of dissolution of
label: BODY

text: the upper Salado, and the distribution of gypsum fillings in fractures in the Culebra (Beauheim
label: BODY

text: and Holt 1990).  Subsequently, Holt and Yarbrough (2002) and Powers et al. (2003) related the
label: BODY

text: variation in Culebra transmissivity more quantitatively to overburden thickness and dissolution
label: BODY

text: of upper Salado halite. The DOE believes that variations in Culebra transmissivity are primarily
label: BODY

text: caused by the relative abundance of open fractures in the unit, which may be related to each of
label: BODY

text: these factors.  As discussed in Section 6.4.6.2 and Appendix PA, Attachment TFIELD,
label: BODY

text: uncertainty in spatial variability in the transmissivity of the Culebra has been incorporated in the
label: BODY

text: PA.
label: BODY

text: In the region around the WIPP, the Rustler reaches a maximum thickness of more than 152 m
label: BODY

text: (500 ft) (Figure 2-16), while it is about 91 to 107 m (300 to 350 ft) thick within most of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site.  Much of the difference in Rustler thickness can be attributed to variations in the
label: BODY

text: amount of halite contained in the formation.  Variation in Tamarisk thickness accounts for a
label: BODY

text: larger part of thickness changes than do variations in either the Los Medaños or the Forty-niner.
label: BODY

text: Details of the Rustler thickness can be found in CCA Appendix GCR, 4-39 to 4-42 and Figure
label: BODY

text: 4.3-8.  See also CCA Appendix FAC.
label: BODY

text: Much project-specific information about the Rustler is contained in CCA Appendix FAC.  The
label: BODY

text: WIPP shafts were a crucial element in Holt and Powers’ 1988 study, exposing features not
label: BODY

text: previously reported.  Cores were available from several WIPP boreholes, and their lithologies
label: BODY

text: were matched to geophysical log signatures to extend the interpretation throughout a larger area
label: BODY

text: in southeastern New Mexico.  These data are included in CCA Appendix FAC, Appendix II.

text: 2.1.3.5.1   Los Medaños Member
label: BODY

text: The unit formerly referred to as the unnamed lower member has been named the Los Medaños
label: BODY

text: Member. The  Los Medaños rests on the Salado with apparent conformity at the WIPP site.  It
label: BODY

text: consists of significant proportions of bedded and burrowed siliciclastic sedimentary rocks with
label: BODY

text: cross-bedding and fossil remains.  These beds record the transition from strongly evaporative
label: BODY

text: environments of the Salado to saline lagoonal environments.  The upper part of the  Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños includes halitic and sulfatic beds within clastics. CCA Appendix FAC, pp. 6-8 and
label: BODY

text: Powers and Holt (1999) interpret these as facies changes within a saline playa or lagoon
label: BODY

text: environment, not dissolution residues from postdepositional dissolution.
label: BODY

text: According to CCA Appendix FAC, Figure 4-4, the Los Medaños ranges in thickness from about
label: BODY

text: 29 to 38 m (96 to 126 ft) within the site boundaries. The maximum thickness recorded during
label: BODY

text: that study was 63 m (208 ft) southeast of the WIPP site.  An isopach of the Los Medaños is
label: BODY

text: shown as Figure 4-7 in CCA Appendix FAC.
label: BODY

text: Halite is present in the M1/H1 unit of the Los Medaños west of most of the site area (see Figure
label: BODY

text: 2-15 for an illustration of the halite margins).  The drilling initiated during CRA-2004
label: BODY

text: preparation to investigate Culebra transmissivity variations based on overburden and Salado
label: BODY

text: dissolution will develop additional detailed information about distribution of halite in the Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños.  Cross-sections based on geophysical log interpretations by Holt and Powers (CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix FAC) and Powers and Holt (2000) show that the unit is thicker to the east where the
label: BODY

text: halite is more abundant. The Los Medaños is incorporated into the conceptual model as
label: BODY

text: described in Section 6.4.6.1.  Model parameters are in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR, Table
label: BODY

text: PAR- 27.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.5.2  The Culebra Dolomite Member
label: BODY

text: The Culebra rests with apparent conformity on the Los Medaños, though the underlying unit
label: BODY

text: ranges from claystone to its lateral halitic equivalent in the site area.  West of the WIPP site, in
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw, the Culebra is disrupted from dissolution of underlying halite.  Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (CCA Appendix FAC, Section 8.9.3) principally attribute this to dissolution of Salado halite,
label: BODY

text: noting the presence of sedimentologic features in the lower Rustler (see also Powers and Holt
label: BODY

text: 1999).  Culebra hydrology and its significance to disposal system performance are discussed in
label: BODY

text: detail in Section 2.2.1.4.1.2.
label: BODY

text: The Culebra was described by Robinson and Lang (1938, p. 83) as a dolomite 11 m (35  ft) in
label: BODY

text: thickness.  The Culebra is generally brown, finely crystalline, locally argillaceous and
label: BODY

text: arenaceous dolomite with rare to abundant vugs with variable gypsum and anhydrite filling;
label: BODY

text: Adams (1944, p. 1614) noted that oölites are present in some outcrops as well.  Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (CCA Appendix FAC, pp. 5 - 11) describe the Culebra features in detail, noting that most of the
label: BODY

text: Culebra is microlaminated to thinly laminated, while some zones display no depositional fabric.
label: BODY

text: Holt and Powers (1984) described an upper interval of the Culebra consisting of medium brown,
label: BODY

text: microlaminated carbonate that thickens up to 0.6 m (2 ft) in the vicinity of dome structures and is
label: BODY

text: of probable algal origin.  This is underlain by a 0.64-to 2.54-cm (0.25-to-1-in) thick bed of
label: BODY

text: cohesive black claystone.  Because of the unique organic composition of this thin layer, Holt and
label: BODY

text: Powers (1988) did not include it in the Culebra for thickness computations, and this will be
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: factored into discussions of Culebra thickness.  Based on core descriptions from the WIPP
label: BODY

text: project, Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC) concluded that there is very little variation of
label: BODY

text: depositional sedimentary features throughout the Culebra.
label: BODY

text: Vugs are an important part of Culebra porosity.  They are commonly zoned parallel to bedding.
label: BODY

text: In outcrop, vugs are commonly empty.  In the subsurface, vugs range from open to partially
label: BODY

text: filled or filled with anhydrite, gypsum, or clay (Holt and Powers 1990a, pp. 3-18 to 3-20).
label: BODY

text: Lowenstein (1987, pp. 19 - 20) noted similar features.  Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC)
label: BODY

text: attributed vugs partly to syndepositional growth as nodules and partly as later replacive textures.
label: BODY

text: Lowenstein (1987, pp. 29 - 31) also described textures related to later replacement and alteration
label: BODY

text: of sulfates.  Vug or pore fillings vary across the WIPP site and contribute to the porosity
label: BODY

text: structure of the Culebra.  As pointed out by Holt and Powers (see CCA Appendix FAC, Section
label: BODY

text: 8.8), natural fractures filled with gypsum are common east of the WIPP site center and in a
label: BODY

text: smaller area west of the site center (Figure 2-17).  Section 2.1.5.2 discusses Culebra fracture
label: BODY

text: mechanisms.  Additional discussion of Culebra fractures and their role in groundwater flow and
label: BODY

text: transport is in Section 2.2.1.4.1.1, Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Sections MASS.14.4 and
label: BODY

text: MASS.15.
label: BODY

text: Holt (1997) reexamined geological and hydrological data for the Culebra and developed a
label: BODY

text: conceptual model for transport processes.  In this document, Holt (1997) recognized several
label: BODY

text: porosity types for the Culebra, and separated four Culebra units (CU) informally designated CU-
label: BODY

text: 1 through CU-4 from top to bottom.  CU-1 differs from underlying units because it has been
label: BODY

text: disrupted very little by syndepositional processes.  Microvugs and interbeds provide most of the
label: BODY

text: porosity, and the permeability of CU-1 is relatively limited. CU-2 and CU-3 likely contribute
label: BODY

text: most of the flow in the Culebra, and the significant difference is that CU-2 includes more
label: BODY

text: persistent silty dolomite interbeds.  CU-2 and CU-3 include “small-scale bedding-plane
label: BODY

text: fractures, networks of randomly oriented small-scale fractures and microfractures, discontinuous
label: BODY

text: silty dolomite interbeds, large vugs hydraulically connected with microfractures and small-scale
label: BODY

text: fractures, microvugs hydraulically connected with microfractures and intercrystalline porosity,
label: BODY

text: blebs of silty dolomite interconnected with microfractures and intercrystalline porosity, and
label: BODY

text: intercrystalline porosity” (Holt 1997, p. 2-19).  Bedding-plane fractures dominate CU-4 at the
label: BODY

text: base of the Culebra, and the unit shows some brittle deformation.  CU-4 has not been isolated for
label: BODY

text: hydraulic testing.
label: BODY

text: Holt (1997, p. I) also related porosity and solute transport, conceptualizing the medium “as
label: BODY

text: consisting of advective porosity, where solutes are carried by the groundwater flow, and fracture-
label: BODY

text: bounded zones of diffusive porosity, where solutes move through slow advection or diffusion.”
label: BODY

text: Holt (1997) noted that length or time scales will govern how each porosity type will contribute to
label: BODY

text: solute transport.
label: BODY

text: Sewards et al. (1991, pp. IX-1) report that the Culebra is primarily dolomite with some quartz
label: BODY

text: and clay.  Clay minerals include corrensite, illite, serpentine, and chlorite.  Clay occurs in bulk
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: In the WIPP area, the Culebra varies in thickness.  Depending on the area considered and the
label: BODY

text: horizons chosen for the upper and lower boundaries of the Culebra, different data sources
label: BODY

text: provide varying estimates (Table 2-3).  Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC, p. 4-4)
label: BODY

text: considered the organic-rich layer at the Culebra-Tamarisk contact separately from the Culebra in
label: BODY

text: interpreting geophysical logs.
label: BODY

text: Comparing data sets, Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC) typically interpret the Culebra as
label: BODY

text: being about 1 m (about 3 ft) thinner than do other interpretations.  In general, this reflects the
label: BODY

text: difference between including or excluding the unit at the Culebra-Tamarisk contact. The isopach
label: BODY

text: of the Culebra is shown as Figure 4.8 in CCA Appendix FAC.
label: BODY

text: LaVenue et al. (1988, Table B.1) calculated a mean thickness of 7.7 m (25  ft) for the Culebra
label: BODY

text: within their model domain based on thicknesses measured in 78 boreholes.  Mercer (1983,
label: BODY

text: reproduced as CCA Appendix HYDRO) reported a data set similar to that of LaVenue et al.  The
label: BODY

text: borehole database for the region of interest is provided in CCA Appendix BH.
label: BODY

text: The treatment of the Culebra in the conceptual model is discussed in Section 6.4.6.2 and
label: BODY

text: associated parameter values in Table 6-20.  A more thorough discussion of Culebra features,
label: BODY

text: such as fractures, is provided in Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section MASS.15.

text: 2.1.3.5.3  The Tamarisk Member
label: BODY

text: Vine (1963, B14) named the Tamarisk for outcrops near Tamarisk Flat in Nash Draw.  Outcrops
label: BODY

text: of the Tamarisk are distorted, and subsurface information was used to establish member
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231

text: March 2004

label: BODY

text: characteristics.  Vine reported two sulfate units separated by a siltstone, about 1.5 m (5 ft) thick,
label: BODY

text: interpreted by Jones et al. in 1960 as a dissolution residue.
label: BODY

text: The Tamarisk is generally conformable with the underlying Culebra.  The transition is marked
label: BODY

text: by an organic-rich unit interpreted as being present over most of southeastern New Mexico.  The
label: BODY

text: Tamarisk around the WIPP site consists of lower and upper sulfate units separated by a unit that
label: BODY

text: varies from mudstone (generally to the west) to mainly halite (to the east).  Near the center of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site, the lower anhydrite was partially eroded during deposition of the middle mudstone
label: BODY

text: unit, as observed in the WIPP waste-handling and exhaust shafts.  The lower anhydrite was
label: BODY

text: completely eroded at WIPP-19.  Before shaft exposures were available, the lack of the Lower
label: BODY

text: Tamarisk anhydrite at WIPP-19 was interpreted as the result of dissolution and the mudstone was
label: BODY

text: considered a cave filling.
label: BODY

text: Jones (1978) interprets halite to be present east of the center of the WIPP site based on
label: BODY

text: geophysical logs and drill cuttings.  Based mainly on cores and cuttings records from the WIPP
label: BODY

text: potash drilling program, Snyder prepared a map showing the halitic areas of each of the
label: BODY

text: noncarbonate members of the Rustler (Snyder 1985, Figure 4).  A very similar map based on
label: BODY

text: geophysical log characteristics was prepared by Holt and Powers (1988).
label: BODY

text: CCA Appendix FAC describes the mudstones and halitic facies in the middle of the Tamarisk
label: BODY

text: and postulate that the unit formed in a salt-pan-to-mudflat system.  Powers and Holt (2000) cited
label: BODY

text: sedimentary features and the lateral relationships as evidence of syndepositional dissolution of
label: BODY

text: halite in the marginal mudflat areas.
label: BODY

text: The Tamarisk thickness varies greatly in southeastern New Mexico, principally as a function of
label: BODY

text: the thickness of halite in the middle unit.  Within T22S, R31E, the thickness ranges from 26 to
label: BODY

text: 56 m (84 to 184 ft) for the entire Tamarisk and from 2 to 34 m (6 to 110 ft) for the interval of
label: BODY

text: mudstone-halite between lower and upper anhydrites (CCA Appendix FAC, Figures 4-9 and 4-
label: BODY

text: 11).  Expanded geophysical logs with corresponding lithology illustrate some of the lateral
label: BODY

text: relationships for this interval (Figure 2-18; see also Powers and Holt 2000).
label: BODY

text: The Tamarisk is modeled as discussed in Section 6.4.6.3.  Tamarisk parameter values are given
label: BODY

text: in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR, Table PAR-24.

text: 2.1.3.5.5  The Forty-niner Member
label: BODY

text: Vine (1963) named the Forty-niner for outcrops at Forty-niner Ridge in eastern Nash Draw, but
label: BODY

text: the unit is poorly exposed there.  In the subsurface around the WIPP, the Forty-niner consists of
label: BODY

text: basal and upper sulfates separated by a mudstone.  It is conformable with the underlying
label: BODY

text: Magenta.  As with other members of the Rustler, geophysical log characteristics can be
label: BODY

text: correlated with core and shaft descriptions to extend geological inferences across a large area
label: BODY

text: (Holt and Powers 1988).
label: BODY

text: The Forty-niner varies from 13 to 23 m (43 to 77 ft) thick within T22S, R31E.  East and
label: BODY

text: southeast of the WIPP, the Forty-niner exceeds 24 m (80 ft), and some of the geophysical logs
label: BODY

text: from this area indicate that halite is present in the beds between the sulfates. A regional isopach
label: BODY

text: map of the Forty-niner is in CCA Appendix FAC (Figure 4-13).  See also Powers and Holt
label: BODY

text: Within the waste-handling shaft, the Forty-niner mudstone displayed sedimentary features and
label: BODY

text: bedding relationships indicating sedimentary transport.  These beds are not known to have been
label: BODY

text: described in detail prior to mapping in the waste-handling shaft at WIPP, and the features found
label: BODY

text: there led Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC) to reexamine the available evidence for, and
label: BODY

text: interpretations of, dissolution of halite in Rustler units.
label: BODY

text: The inclusion of the Forty-niner in the conceptual model is discussed in Section 6.4.6.5.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.6 The Dewey Lake
label: BODY

text: The nomenclature for rocks included in the Dewey Lake Formation was introduced during the
label: BODY

text: 1960s to clarify relationships between these rocks assigned to the Upper Permian and the
label: BODY

text: Cenozoic Gatuña Formation.
label: BODY

text: There are three main sources of data about the Dewey Lake in the area around WIPP.  Miller
label: BODY

text: reported the petrology of the unit in 1955 and 1966.  Schiel (1988) described outcrops in the
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw areas and interpreted geophysical logs of the unit in southeastern New Mexico and
label: BODY

text: west Texas to infer the depositional environments and stratigraphic relationships in 1988 and
label: BODY

text: 1994.  Holt and Powers (1990a) were able to describe the Dewey Lake in detail at the AIS for
label: BODY

text: WIPP in 1990, confirming much of Schiel’s (1988) information and adding data regarding the
label: BODY

text: Lower Dewey Lake.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: bedding, and larger channeling are common features in outcrops, and additional soft sediment
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Holt and Powers (1990a).  Schiel (1988, p. 143; 1994, p. 9) attributed the Dewey Lake to
label: BODY

text: deposition on “a large, arid fluvial plain subject to ephemeral flood events.”
label: BODY

text: There is no direct faunal or radiometric evidence of the age of the Dewey Lake in the vicinity of
label: BODY

text: the WIPP site.  It is assigned to the Ochoan Series, considered historically to be Late Permian in
label: BODY

text: age, and it is regionally correlated with units of similar lithology and stratigraphic position.
label: BODY

text: Schiel (1988, 1994) reviewed the limited radiometric data from lithologically similar rocks
label: BODY

text: (Quartermaster Formation) and concluded that much of the unit could be Early Triassic in age.
label: BODY

text: Renne et al. (1996) resampled tephra from the Quartermaster in the Texas panhandle area and
label: BODY

text: found that radiometric data support the idea that the Quartermaster is mainly Triassic in age
label: BODY

text: rather than Permian.  Others have begun to infer as well that the Dewey Lake in the vicinity of
label: BODY

text: the WIPP may be mostly Triassic (e.g., Powers and Holt 1999).  These age relationships
label: BODY

text: continue to be of academic interest because of the geologic significance of the Permo-Triassic
label: BODY

text: boundary, but there is no significance for waste isolation at the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: Near the center of the WIPP site, Holt and Powers (1990a, Figure 5) mapped 152 m (498 ft) of
label: BODY

text: the Dewey Lake (Figure 2-19).  The formation is thicker to the east (Schiel 1994, Figure 2) of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site, in part because western areas were eroded before the overlying Triassic rocks were
label: BODY

text: deposited.
label: BODY

text: The Dewey Lake contains fractures, which are filled with minerals to varying degrees.  Both
label: BODY

text: cements and fracture fillings have been examined and used to infer groundwater infiltration.
label: BODY

text: Holt and Powers (1990a, pp. 3-10) described the Dewey Lake as cemented by carbonate above
label: BODY

text: 50 m (164.5 ft) in the AIS; some fractures in the lower part of this interval were also filled with
label: BODY

text: carbonate, and the entire interval surface was commonly moist.  Below this point, the cement is
label: BODY

text: harder and more commonly anhydrite (Powers 2003b), the shaft is dry, and fractures are filled
label: BODY

text: with gypsum.  Powers (2002c; 2003b) reports core and geophysical log data supporting these
label: BODY

text: vertical changes in natural mineral cements in the Dewey Lake over a larger region at a horizon
label: BODY

text: that is believed to underlie known natural groundwater occurrences in the Dewey Lake.  In areas
label: BODY

text: where the Dewey Lake has been exposed to weathering after erosion of the overlying Santa
label: BODY

text: Rosa, this cement boundary tends to generally parallel the eroded upper surface of the Dewey
label: BODY

text: Lake, suggesting that weathering has affected the location of the boundary.  Where the Dewey
label: BODY

text: Lake has been protected by overlying rocks of the Santa Rosa, the cement change appears to be
label: BODY

text: stratigraphically controlled but the data points are too few to be certain.  Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (1990a, pp. 3 - 11, Figure 16) suggested that the cement change might be related to infiltration of
label: BODY

text: meteoric water.  They also determined that some of the gypsum-filled fractures are
label: BODY

text: syndepositional.  Dewey Lake fractures include horizontal to subvertical trends, some of which
label: BODY

text: were mapped in detail (Holt and Powers 1986, Figures 6, 7, and 8).

text: Lambert (1991, pp. 5 - 65) analyzed the deuterium/hydrogen (D/H) ratios of gypsum in the
label: BODY

text: Rustler and gypsum veins in the Dewey Lake.  He suggest that none of the gypsum formed from
label: BODY

text: evaporitic fluid such as Permian seawater but that the D/H ratios all show influence of meteoric
label: BODY

text: water.  Furthermore, Lambert (1991, 5 – 66) infers that the gypsum D/H ratio is not consistent
label: BODY

text: with modern meteoric water; it may, however, be consistent with older meteoric fluids.  There is
label: BODY

text: no obvious correlation with depth to indicate infiltration.  Strontium isotope ratios (
label: BODY

text: 87Sr/ 86Sr)
label: BODY

text: indicate no intermixing or homogenization of fluids between the Rustler and the Dewey Lake,
label: BODY

text: but there may have been lateral movement of water within the Dewey Lake (Lambert 1991, pp.
label: BODY

text: 5 - 54).  Dewey Lake carbonate-vein material shows a broader range of strontium ratios than
label: BODY

text: does surface caliche, and the ratios barely overlap.

text: 2.1.3.7 The Santa Rosa
label: BODY

text: There have been different approaches to the nomenclature of rocks of Triassic age in
label: BODY

text: southeastern New Mexico.  Bachman (1974) generally described the units as “Triassic,
label: BODY

text: undivided” or as the Dockum Group, without dividing it.  Vine (1963) used “Santa Rosa
label: BODY

text: Sandstone,” and Santa Rosa has become common usage.  Lucas and Anderson (1993a, 1993b)
label: BODY

text: import other formation names that are unlikely to be useful for WIPP.
label: BODY

text: The Santa Rosa has been called disconformable over the Dewey Lake by Vine (1963, B25).
label: BODY

text: These rocks have more variegated hues than the underlying uniformly colored Dewey Lake.
label: BODY

text: Coarse-grained rocks, including conglomerates, are common, and the formation includes a
label: BODY

text: variety of cross-bedding and sedimentary features (Lucas and Anderson 1993a, pp. 231 - 235).
label: BODY

text: Within the WIPP site boundary, the Santa Rosa is relatively thin to absent (Figure 2-20).  At the
label: BODY

text: AIS, Holt and Powers (1990a, Figure 5) attributed about 0.6 m (2 ft) of rock to the Santa Rosa.
label: BODY

text: The Santa Rosa is a maximum of 78 m (255 ft) thick in potash holes drilled for WIPP east of the
label: BODY

text: site boundary.  The Santa Rosa is thicker to the east.  The geologic data from design studies
label: BODY

text: (Sergent et al. 1979) were incorporated with data from drilling to investigate shallow subsurface
label: BODY

text: water in the Santa Rosa to provide structure and thickness maps of the Santa Rosa in the vicinity
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP surface structures area (Powers 1997).  These results are consistent with the broader
label: BODY

text: regional distribution of the Santa Rosa.
label: BODY

text: The Santa Rosa and younger rocks are modeled in the WIPP PA as a single region as discussed
label: BODY

text: in Section 6.4.6.7.  The model parameters for this supra-Dewey Lake region are given in Table
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.8 The Gatuña
label: BODY

text: Lang (in Robinson and Lang 1938, p. 84) named the Gatuña for outcrops in the vicinity of
label: BODY

text: Gatuña Canyon in the Clayton Basin.  Rocks now attributed to the Gatuña in Pierce Canyon were
label: BODY

text: once included in the Pierce Canyon Formation with rocks now assigned to the Dewey Lake.  The
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: formation has been mapped from the Santa Rosa, New Mexico, area south to the vicinity of
label: BODY

text: Pecos, Texas.  It is unconformable with underlying units.
label: BODY

text: Vine (1963) and Bachman (1974) provided some limited description of the Gatuña.  The most
label: BODY

text: comprehensive study of the Gatuña is based on WIPP investigations and landfill studies for the
label: BODY

text: City of Carlsbad and Eddy County (Powers and Holt 1993).  Much of the formation is colored
label: BODY

text: light reddish-brown.  It is broadly similar to the Dewey Lake and the Santa Rosa, though the
label: BODY

text: older units have more intense hues.  The formation is highly variable, ranging from coarse
label: BODY

text: conglomerates to claystones with some highly gypsiferous sections.  Sedimentary structures are
label: BODY

text: abundant.  Analysis of lithofacies indicates that the formation is dominantly fluvial in origin with
label: BODY

text: areas of low-energy deposits and evaporitic minerals.
label: BODY

text: The thickness of the Gatuña is not very consistent regionally, as shown in Figure 2-21.  The
label: BODY

text: thickness of the Gatuña ranges up to 91 m (300 ft) at Pierce Canyon, with thicker areas generally
label: BODY

text: subparallel to the Pecos River.  To the east, the Gatuña is thin or absent.  Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (1990a) reported about 2.7 m (9 ft) of undisturbed Gatuña in the AIS at WIPP.  Powers (1997)
label: BODY

text: integrated data from facility design geotechnical work (Sergent et al. 1979) and drilling to
label: BODY

text: investigate shallow water to develop maps of the Gatuña in the vicinity of the WIPP surface
label: BODY

text: facility.  These maps are consistent with the broader regional view of the distribution of the
label: BODY

text: Gatuña.
label: BODY

text: The Gatuña has been considered Pleistocene in age based on a volcanic glass in the Upper
label: BODY

text: Gatuña along the eastern margin of Nash Draw that has been identified as the Lava Creek B ash,
label: BODY

text: dated at 0.6 million years by Izett and Wilcox (1982).  This upper-limit age is corroborated by
label: BODY

text: the age determinations from the Mescalero caliche (hereafter referred to as the Mescalero) that
label: BODY

text: overlies the Gatuña (see Section 2.1.3.9).  An additional volcanic ash from the Gatuña in Texas
label: BODY

text: yields consistent K-Ar and geochemical data, indicating that it is about 13 million years old at
label: BODY

text: that location (Powers and Holt 1993, p. 271).  Thus, the Gatuña ranges in age over a period of
label: BODY

text: time that may be greater than that spanned by the Ogallala Formation (hereafter referred to as the
label: BODY

text: Ogallala) on the High Plains east of WIPP.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.3.9 Mescalero Caliche
label: BODY

text: The Mescalero caliche is an informal stratigraphic unit apparently first differentiated by
label: BODY

text: Bachman in 1974, though Bachman (1973, p. 17, p. 27) described the caliche on the Mescalero
label: BODY

text: Plain.  He differentiated the Mescalero from the older, widespread  Ogallala caliche or caprock
label: BODY

text: on the basis of textures, noting that breccia and pisolitic textures are much more common in the
label: BODY

text: Ogallala caliche.  The Mescalero has been noted over significant areas in the Pecos drainage,
label: BODY

text: including the WIPP area, and it has been formed over a variety of substrates. Bachman (1973)
label: BODY

text: described the Mescalero as a two-part unit:  (1) an upper dense laminar caprock and (2) a basal,
label: BODY

text: earthy-to-firm, nodular calcareous deposit.  Machette (1985, p. 5) classified the Mescalero as
label: BODY

text: having Stage V morphologies of a calcic soil (the more mature Ogallala caprock that occurs east
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP site reaches Stage VI).
label: BODY

text: Bachman (1976, Figure 8) provided structure contours on the Mescalero caliche for a large area
label: BODY

text: of southeastern New Mexico, including the WIPP site.  From the contours and Bachman’s
label: BODY

text: discussion of the Mescalero as a soil, it is clear that the Mescalero is expected to be continuous
label: BODY

text: over large areas.  Explicit WIPP data are limited mainly to boreholes, though some borehole
label: BODY

text: reports do not mention the Mescalero.  The unit may be as much as 3 m (10 ft) thick.

label: BODY

text: The Mescalero overlies the Gatuña and was interpreted by Bachman (1976) on basic
label: BODY

text: stratigraphic grounds as having accumulated during the early-to-middle Pleistocene.  Samples of
label: BODY

text: the Mescalero from the vicinity of the WIPP were studied using uranium-trend methods.
label: BODY

text: Based on early written communication from Rosholt, Bachman (1985, p. 20) reports that the
label: BODY

text: basal Mescalero began to form about 510,000 years ago and the upper part began to form about
label: BODY

text: 410,000 years ago; these ages are commonly cited in WIPP literature.  The samples are
label: BODY

text: interpreted by Rosholt and McKinney (1980, Table 5) in the formal report as indicating ages of
label: BODY

text: 570,000 ± 110,000 years for the lower part of the Mescalero and 420,000 ± 60,000 years for the
label: BODY

text: upper part.
label: BODY

text: According to Bachman (1985, p. 19), where the Mescalero is flat-lying and not breached by
label: BODY

text: erosion, it is an indicator of stability or integrity of the land surface over the last 500,000 years.
label: BODY

text: An additional discussion of the Mescalero caliche can be found in CCA Appendix GCR, Section

text: 2.1.3.10 Surficial Sediments
label: BODY

text: Soils of the region have developed mainly from Quaternary and Permian parent material.  Parent
label: BODY

text: material from the Quaternary System is represented by alluvial deposits of major streams, dune
label: BODY

text: sand, and other surface deposits.  These are mostly loamy and sandy sediments containing some
label: BODY

text: coarse fragments.  Parent material from the Permian System is represented by limestone,
label: BODY

text: dolomite, and gypsum bedrock.  Soils of the region have developed in a semiarid, continental
label: BODY

text: climate with abundant sunshine, low relative humidity, erratic and low rainfall, and a wide
label: BODY

text: variation in daily and seasonal temperatures.  Subsoil colors are normally light brown to reddish
label: BODY

text: brown but are often mixed with lime accumulations (caliche) that result from limited, erratic
label: BODY

text: rainfall and insufficient leaching.
label: BODY

text: A soil association is a landscape with a distinctive pattern of soil types (series).  It normally
label: BODY

text: consists of one or more major soils and at least one minor soil.  There are three soil associations
label: BODY

text: within 8.3 km (5 mi) of the WIPP site: the Kermit-Berino, the Simona-Pajarito, and the Pyote-
label: BODY

text: Maljamar-Kermit.  Of these three associations, only the Kermit-Berino soil series has been
label: BODY

text: mapped across the WIPP site by Chugg et al. (1952, Sheet No. 113).  These are sandy soils
label: BODY

text: developed on eolian material.  The Kermit-Berino soils include active dune areas.  The Berino
label: BODY

text: soil has a sandy A horizon; the B horizons include more argillaceous material and weak-to-
label: BODY

text: moderate soil structures.  A and B horizons are described as noncalcareous, and the underlying C
label: BODY

text: horizon is commonly caliche.  Bachman (1980, p. 44) interpreted the Berino soil as a paleosol
label: BODY

text: that is a remnant B horizon of the underlying Mescalero.  Rosholt and McKinney (1980, Table 5)
label: BODY

text: applied uranium-trend methods to samples of the Berino soil from the WIPP site area.  Rosholt
label: BODY

text: and McKinney (1980) interpreted the age of formation of the Berino soil as 330,000 ± 75,000
label: BODY

text: years.
label: BODY

text: Generally, the Berino Series, which covers about 50 percent of the site, consists of deep,
label: BODY

text: noncalcareous, yellow-red to red sandy soils that developed from wind-worked material of
label: BODY

text: mixed origin.  These soils are described as undulating to hummocky and gently sloping (zero to
label: BODY

text: three percent slopes).  The soils are the most extensive of the deep, sandy soils in the Eddy
label: BODY

text: County area.  Berino soils are subject to continuing wind and water erosion.  If the vegetative
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: cover is seriously depleted, the water-erosion potential is slight, but the wind-erosion potential is
label: BODY

text: very high.  These soils are particularly sensitive to wind erosion in the months of March, April,
label: BODY

text: and May, when rainfall is minimal and winds are highest.  These soil characteristics are a
label: BODY

text: consideration for the design of long-term passive controls such as monuments and markers (see
label: BODY

text: CCA Appendix PIC, Section III).
label: BODY

text: The Kermit Series consists of deep, light-colored, noncalcareous, excessively drained loose
label: BODY

text: sands, typically yellowish-red fine sand.  The surface is undulating to billowy (from 0 to
label: BODY

text: 3 percent slopes) and consists mostly of stabilized sand dunes.  Kermit soils are slightly to
label: BODY

text: moderately eroded.  Permeability is very high, and, if vegetative cover is removed, the water-
label: BODY

text: erosion potential is slight, but the wind-erosion potential is very high.
label: BODY

text: Surface soils appear to play a role in the infiltration of precipitation.  Mercer (CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: HYDRO) points out that where surface deposits are thickest, they may contain localized perched
label: BODY

text: zones of groundwater.  A more thorough discussion of this topic can be found in CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: HYDRO.

text: 2.1.3.11 Summary
label: BODY

text: The stratigraphy and lithology at the WIPP site has been summarized from the lowermost pre-
label: BODY

text: Cambrian units to the surface soils.  While these are important for an understanding of the site
label: BODY

text: and its stability, not all of these units are important to the performance of the disposal system.
label: BODY

text: As a result, the DOE has developed a conceptual model that describes the lithology as 13
label: BODY

text: discrete model regions ranging from the Castile to a region that generally includes units above
label: BODY

text: the Dewey Lake.  In this model, emphasis is placed on the Castile, the Salado, the five members
label: BODY

text: of the Rustler, the Dewey Lake, and the supra-Dewey Lake units.  The Salado is divided into five
label: BODY

text: stratigraphic units to capture the variations in properties near the horizon of the repository (see
label: BODY

text: Figure 6-14).  The identification and definition of the appropriate modeling units is based on the
label: BODY

text: identification of FEPs that can impact the performance of the disposal system.  Details of the
label: BODY

text: conceptual model can be found in Section 6.4.2.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.4 Physiography and Geomorphology
label: HH2

text: In this section, the DOE presents a discussion of the physiography and geomorphology of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site and surrounding area.  This information is taken from DOE 1980 (pp. 7-21 to 7-23).
label: BODY

text: Geomorphology and physiography are determined by the DOE (1980) to be features that are
label: BODY

text: potentially important to disposal system performance.  They are included in the consequence
label: BODY

text: analysis through consideration of the topography and its influence on the regional water table.
label: BODY

text: (See discussion of regional water table characteristics in Section 2.2.1.)  Consequently,
label: BODY

text: topographic information is presented in this section.  In addition, several geomorphological
label: BODY

text: processes have been screened out on the basis of either low consequence or low probability, as
label: BODY

text: discussed in Appendix PA, Attachment SCR.  These include weathering, erosion, sedimentation,
label: BODY

text: and soil development.  Information is presented in this section to support this screening.  In order
label: BODY

text: to perform this screening, such factors as slopes, proximity to watercourses, dissection, and
label: BODY

text: historic and existing processes are important.  These are presented in this section in terms of the
label: BODY

text: regional and local physiographic and geomorphological characteristics.  Tectonic processes that
label: BODY

text: may alter the physiography of the region or site area are discussed in Section 2.1.5.  In addition,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Section 2.1.6 presents more specific details on nontectonic processes identified during site
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.1.4.1 Regional Physiography and Geomorphology
label: BODY

text: The WIPP site is in the Pecos Valley section of the southern Great Plains physiographic province
label: BODY

text: (Figure 2-22), a broad, highland belt sloping gently eastward from the Rocky Mountains and the
label: BODY

text: Basin and Range Province to the Central Lowlands Province.  The Pecos Valley section itself is
label: BODY

text: dominated by the Pecos River Valley, a long north-south trough that is from 8.3 to 50 km (5 to
label: BODY

text: 30 mi) wide and as much as 305 m (1,000 ft) deep in the north.  The Pecos River System has
label: BODY

text: evolved from the south, cutting headward through the Ogallala sediments and becoming
label: BODY

text: entrenched some time after the Middle Pleistocene.  It receives almost all the surface and
label: BODY

text: subsurface drainage of the region; most of its tributaries are intermittent because of the semiarid
label: BODY

text: climate.  The surface locally has a karst terrain containing sinkholes, dolines, and solution-
label: BODY

text: subsidence troughs from both surface erosion and subsurface dissolution.  The valley has an
label: BODY

text: uneven rock- and alluvium-covered floor with widespread solution-subsidence features, the
label: BODY

text: result of dissolution in the underlying Upper Permian rocks.  The terrain varies from plains and
label: BODY

text: lowlands to rugged canyonlands, and contains such erosional features as scarps, cuestas, terraces,
label: BODY

text: and mesas.  The surface slopes gently eastward, reflecting the underlying rock strata.  Elevations
label: BODY

text: vary from more than 1,829 m (6,000 ft) in the northwest to about 610 m (2,000 ft) in the south.
label: BODY

text: The Pecos Valley section is bordered on the east by the virtually uneroded plain of the Llano
label: BODY

text: Estacado.  The Llano Estacado is part of the High Plains section of the Great Plains
label: BODY

text: physiographic province and is a poorly drained eastward-sloping surface covered by gravels,
label: BODY

text: wind-blown sand, and caliche that has developed since early-to-middle Pleistocene time.  Few
label: BODY

text: and minor topographic features are present in the High Plains section, formed when more than
label: BODY

text: 152 m (500 ft) of Tertiary silts, gravels, and sands were laid down in alluvial fans by streams
label: BODY

text: draining the Rocky Mountains.  In many areas, the nearly flat surface is cemented by a hard
label: BODY

text: caliche layer.
label: BODY

text: To the west of the Pecos Valley section are the Sacramento Mountains and the Guadalupe
label: BODY

text: Mountains, part of the Sacramento section of the Basin and Range Province.  The Capitan
label: BODY

text: escarpment along the southeastern side of the Guadalupe Mountains marks the boundary
label: BODY

text: between the Basin and Range and the Great Plains provinces.  The Sacramento section has large
label: BODY

text: basinal areas and a series of intervening mountain ranges (DOE 1980).
label: BODY

text: 2.1.4.2 Site Physiography and Geomorphology
label: BODY

text: The land surface in the area of the WIPP site is a semiarid, wind-blown plain sloping gently to
label: BODY

text: the west and southwest, and is hummocky with sand ridges and dunes.  A hard caliche layer
label: BODY

text: (Mescalero rocks) is typically present beneath the sand blanket and on the surface of the
label: BODY

text: underlying Gatuña.  Figure 2-23 is a topographic map of the area.  Elevations at the site range
label: BODY

text: from 1,088 m (3,570 ft) in the east to 990 m (3,250 ft) in the west.  The average east-to-west
label: BODY

text: slope is 9.4 m per kilometer (50 ft/mi).
label: BODY

text: Livingston Ridge is the most prominent physiographic feature near the site.  It is a west-facing
label: BODY

text: escarpment that has about 23 m (75 ft) of topographic relief and marks the eastern edge of Nash
label: BODY

text: Draw, the drainage course nearest to the site (see Figure 2-23).  Nash Draw is a shallow 8-km-
label: BODY

text: wide (5-mi-wide) basin, 61 to 91 m (200 to 300 ft) deep and open to the southwest.  It was
label: BODY

text: caused, at least in part, by subsurface dissolution and the accompanying subsidence of overlying
label: BODY

text: sediments.  Livingston Ridge is the approximate boundary between terrain that has undergone
label: BODY

text: erosion and/or solution collapse to the west and terrain that has been little affected to the east.
label: BODY

text: About 24 km (15 mi) east of the site is the southeast-trending San Simon Swale, a depression
label: BODY

text: caused, at least in part, by subsurface dissolution.  Between San Simon Swale and the site is a
label: BODY

text: broad, low mesa named the Divide.  Lying about 9.7 km (6 mi) east of the site and about 30 m
label: BODY

text: (100 ft) above the surrounding terrain, it is a boundary between southwest drainage toward Nash
label: BODY

text: Draw and southeast drainage toward San Simon Swale.  The Divide is capped by the Ogallala
label: BODY

text: and the overlying caliche, upon which have formed small, elongated depressions similar to those
label: BODY

text: in the adjacent High Plains section to the east.
label: BODY

text: Surface drainage is intermittent; the nearest perennial stream is the Pecos River, 19 km (12 mi)
label: BODY

text: southwest of the WIPP site boundary.  The site’s location near a natural divide protects it from
label: BODY

text: flooding and serious erosion caused by heavy runoff.  Should the climate become more humid,
label: BODY

text: any perennial streams should follow the present basins, and Nash Draw and San Simon Swale
label: BODY

text: would be the most eroded, leaving the area of the Divide relatively intact.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.5 Tectonic Setting and Site Structural Features
label: HH2

text: The DOE has screened out, on the basis of either probability or consequence or both, all tectonic,
label: BODY

text: magmatic, and structural related processes.  The screening discussions can be found in Appendix
label: BODY

text: PA, Attachment SCR.  The information needed for this screening is included here and covers
label: BODY

text: regional tectonic processes such as subsidence and uplift and basin tilting, magmatic processes
label: BODY

text: such as igneous intrusion and events such as volcanism, and structural processes such as faulting
label: BODY

text: and loading and unloading of the rocks because of long-term sedimentation or erosion.
label: BODY

text: Discussions of structural events, such as earthquakes, are considered to the extent that they may
label: BODY

text: create new faults or activate old faults.  The seismicity of the area is considered in Section 2.6 for
label: BODY

text: the purposes of determining seismic design parameters for the facility.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.5.1 Tectonics
label: BODY

text: The processes and features included in this section are those more traditionally considered part of
label: BODY

text: tectonics, processes that develop the broad-scale features of the earth.  Salt dissolution is a
label: BODY

text: different process that can develop some features resembling those of tectonics.
label: BODY

text: Most broad-scale structural elements of the area around the WIPP developed during the Late
label: BODY

text: Paleozoic (CCA Appendix GCR, pp. 3-58 to 3-77).  There is little historical or geological
label: BODY

text: evidence of significant tectonic activity in the vicinity, and the level of stress in the region is low.
label: BODY

text: The entire region tilted slightly during the Tertiary, and activity related to Basin and Range
label: BODY

text: tectonics formed major structures southwest of the area.  Seismic activity is specifically
label: BODY

text: addressed in a separate section.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231

label: BODY

text: Broad subsidence began in the area as early as the Ordovician, developing a sag called the
label: BODY

text: Tobosa Basin.  By Late Pennsylvanian to Early Permian time, the Central Basin Platform
label: BODY

text: developed (Figure 2-24), separating the Tobosa Basin into two parts:  the Delaware Basin to the
label: BODY

text: west and the Midland Basin to the east.  The Permian Basin refers to the collective set of
label: BODY

text: depositional basins in the area during the Permian Period.  Southwest of the Delaware Basin, the
label: BODY

text: Diablo Platform began developing either in the Late Pennsylvanian or Early Permian.  The
label: BODY

text: Marathon Uplift and Ouachita tectonic belt limited the southern extent of the Delaware Basin.
label: BODY

text: According to Brokaw et al. (1972, p. 30), pre-Ochoan sedimentary rocks in the Delaware Basin
label: BODY

text: show evidence of gentle downwarping during deposition, while Ochoan and younger rocks do
label: BODY

text: not.  A relatively uniform eastward tilt, generally from about 14 to 19 m/per km (75 to
label: BODY

text: 100 ft/mi), has been superimposed on the sedimentary sequence.1   King (1948, pp. 108 and 121)
label: BODY

text: generally attributes the uplift of the Guadalupe and Delaware mountains along the west side of
label: BODY

text: the Delaware Basin to the later Cenozoic, though he also notes that some faults along the west
label: BODY

text: margin of the Guadalupe Mountains have displaced Quaternary gravels.
label: BODY

text: 1 Local dip of the Salado has been determined by mapping in the WIPP underground excavations.  This dip is
label: BODY

text: modeled as one degree to the south, as discussed in Section 6.4.2.1.
label: BODY

text: King (1948, p. 144) also infers the uplift from the Pliocene-age deposits of the Llano Estacado.
label: BODY

text: Subsequent studies of the  Ogallala of the Llano Estacado show that it varies in age from
label: BODY

text: Miocene (about 12 million years before present) to Pliocene (Hawley 1993).  This is the most
label: BODY

text: likely range for uplift of the Guadalupe Mountains and broad tilting to the east of the Delaware
label: BODY

text: Basin sequence.
label: BODY

text: Analysis of the present regional stress field indicates that the Delaware Basin lies within the
label: BODY

text: Southern Great Plains stress province.  This province is a transition zone between the extensional
label: BODY

text: stress regime to the west and the region of compressive stress to the east.  An interpretation by
label: BODY

text: Zoback and Zoback (1991, p. 350) of the available data indicates that the level of stress in the
label: BODY

text: Southern Great Plains stress province is low.  Changes to the tectonic setting, such as the
label: BODY

text: development of subduction zones and a consequent change in the driving forces, would take
label: BODY

text: much longer than 10,000 years to occur.
label: BODY

text: To the west of the Southern Great Plains province is the Basin and Range province, or
label: BODY

text: Cordilleran Extension province, where according to Zoback and Zoback (1991, pp. 348 - 351),
label: BODY

text: normal faulting is the characteristic style of deformation.  The eastern boundary of the Basin and
label: BODY

text: Range province is marked by the Rio Grande Rift.  Sanford et al. (1991, p. 230) note that, as a
label: BODY

text: geological structure, the rift extends beyond the relatively narrow geomorphological feature seen
label: BODY

text: at the surface, with a magnetic anomaly at least 500 km (300 mi) wide.  On this basis, the Rio
label: BODY

text: Grande Rift can be regarded as a system of axial grabens along a major north-south trending
label: BODY

text: structural uplift (a continuation of the Southern Rocky Mountains).  The magnetic anomaly
label: BODY

text: extends beneath the Southern Great Plains stress province, and regional-scale uplift of about
label: BODY

text: 1,000 m (3,300 ft) over the past 10 million years also extends into eastern New Mexico.
label: BODY

text: To the east of the Southern Great Plains province is the large Mid-Plate province that
label: BODY

text: encompasses central and eastern regions of the conterminous United States and the Atlantic
label: BODY

text: basin west of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.  The Mid-Plate province is characterized by low levels of
label: BODY

text: paleo- and historic seismicity.  Where Quaternary faulting has occurred, it is generally strike-slip
label: BODY

text: and appears to be associated with the reactivation of older structural elements.
label: BODY

text: Zoback et al. (1991) report no stress measurements from the Delaware Basin.  The stress field in
label: BODY

text: the Southern Great Plains stress province has been defined from borehole measurements in west
label: BODY

text: Texas and from volcanic lineaments in northern New Mexico.  These measurements were
label: BODY

text: interpreted by Zoback and Zoback (1991, p. 353) to indicate that the least principal horizontal
label: BODY

text: stress is oriented north-northeast and south-southwest and that most of the province is
label: BODY

text: characterized by an extensional stress regime.
label: BODY

text: There is an abrupt change between the orientation of the least principal horizontal stress in the
label: BODY

text: Southern Great Plains and the west-northwest orientation of the least principal horizontal stress
label: BODY

text: characteristic of the Rio Grande Rift.  In addition to the geological indications of a transition
label: BODY

text: zone as described above, Zoback and Zoback (1980, p. 6134) point out that there is also evidence
label: BODY

text: for a sharp boundary between these two provinces.  This is reinforced by the change in crustal
label: BODY

text: thickness from about 40 km (24 mi) beneath the Colorado Plateau to about 50 km (30 mi) or
label: BODY

text: more beneath the Southern Great Plains east of the Rio Grande Rift.  The base of the crust within
label: BODY

text: the Rio Grande Rift is poorly defined but is shallower than that of the Colorado Plateau
label: BODY

text: (Thompson and Zoback 1979, p. 152). There is also markedly lower heat flow in the Southern
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Great Plains (typically < 60 mWm-2) reported by Blackwell et al. (1991, p. 428) compared with
label: BODY

text: that in the Rio Grande Rift (typically > 80 mWm
label: BODY

text: -2) reported by Reiter et al. (1991, p. 463).
label: BODY

text: On the eastern boundary of the Southern Great Plains province, there is only a small rotation in
label: BODY

text: the direction of the least principal horizontal stress.  There is, however, a change from an
label: BODY

text: extensional, normal faulting regime to a compressive, strike-slip faulting regime in the Mid-Plate
label: BODY

text: province.  According to Zoback and Zoback (1980, p. 6134), the available data indicate that this
label: BODY

text: change is not abrupt and that the Southern Great Plains province can be viewed as a marginal
label: BODY

text: part of the Mid-Plate province.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.5.2 Loading and Unloading
label: BODY

text: Loading and unloading during the geological history since deposition is considered an influence
label: BODY

text: on the hydrology of the Permian units because of its possible effect on the development of
label: BODY

text: fractures.
label: BODY

text: The sedimentary loading, depth of total burial, and erosion events combine in a complex history
label: BODY

text: reconstructed here from regional geological trends and local data.  The history is presented in
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-25 with several alternatives, depending on the inferences that are drawn, ranging from
label: BODY

text: minimal to upper-bound estimates (Powers and Holt 1995, Section 5.3). Borns (1987) also made
label: BODY

text: a generalized estimate of loading that is similar.  The estimates are made with a reference point
label: BODY

text: and depth to the Culebra at the AIS.
label: BODY

text: Given the maximum local thickness of the Dewey Lake, the maximum load at the end of the
label: BODY

text: Permian was no more than approximately 240 m (787 ft).  Given the present depth to the Culebra
label: BODY

text: from the top of the Dewey Lake in the AIS, approximately 35 m (115 ft) of Dewey Lake might
label: BODY

text: have been eroded during the Early Triassic before additional sediments were deposited.  The
label: BODY

text: Triassic thickness at the AIS is approximately 8 m (26 ft).  Northeast of the WIPP site (T21S,
label: BODY

text: R33E), Triassic rocks (Dockum Group) have a maximum local thickness of approximately
label: BODY

text: 373 m (1,233 ft).  This thickness is a reasonable estimate of the maximum thickness also attained
label: BODY

text: at the WIPP site prior to the Jurassic Period.  At the end of the Triassic, the total thickness at the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site may have then attained approximately 586 m (1,863 ft) in two similar loading stages
label: BODY

text: of a few million years each, over a period of approximately 50 million years.
label: BODY

text: The Jurassic outcrops nearest to the WIPP site are in the Malone Mountains of west Texas.
label: BODY

text: There is no evidence that Jurassic rocks were deposited at or in the vicinity of the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: As a consequence, the Jurassic is considered a time of erosion or nondeposition at the site,
label: BODY

text: though erosion is most likely.
label: BODY

text: Widespread erosion during the Jurassic obviously cannot be broadly inferred for the area or there
label: BODY

text: would not be thick Triassic rocks still preserved.  Triassic rocks of this thickness are preserved
label: BODY

text: nearby, indicating either pre-Jurassic tilting or that erosion did not occur until later (but still after
label: BODY

text: tilting to preserve the Triassic rocks near the WIPP site).  It is also possible that the immediate
label: BODY

text: site area had little Triassic deposition or erosion, but very limited Triassic deposition (that is, 8 m
label: BODY

text: [26 ft]) at the WIPP site seems unlikely.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-25.  Loading and Unloading History Estimated to the Base of the Culebra
label: HH2

text: Lang (1947) reported fossils from Lower Cretaceous rocks in the Black River Valley southwest
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP site.  Bachman (1980, p. 28) also reported similar patches of probable Cretaceous
label: BODY

text: rocks near Carlsbad and south of White’s City.  From these reports, it is likely that some
label: BODY

text: Cretaceous rocks were deposited at the WIPP site.  Approximately 110 km (70 mi) south-
label: BODY

text: southwest of the WIPP site, significant Cretaceous outcrops of both Early and Late Cretaceous
label: BODY

text: age have a total maximum thickness of approximately 300 m (1,000 ft).  Southeast of the WIPP,
label: BODY

text: the nearest Cretaceous outcrops are thinner and represent only the Lower Cretaceous.  Based on
label: BODY

text: outcrops, a maximum thickness of 300 m (1,000 ft) of Cretaceous rocks could be estimated for
label: BODY

text: the WIPP site.  Compared to the estimate of Triassic rock thickness, it is less likely that
label: BODY

text: Cretaceous rocks were this thick at the site.  The uppermost lines of Figure 2-25 summarize the
label: BODY

text: assumptions of maximum thickness of these units.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: A more likely alternative is that virtually no Cretaceous rocks were deposited, followed by
label: BODY

text: erosion of remaining Triassic rocks during the Late Cretaceous to the Late Cenozoic.  Such
label: BODY

text: erosion may also have taken place over an even longer period, beginning with the Jurassic
label: BODY

text: Period.  Ewing (1993) favors Early Cretaceous uplift and erosion for the Trans-Pecos Texas area,
label: BODY

text: but does not analyze later uplift and erosional patterns.
label: BODY

text: In the general vicinity of the WIPP site, there are outcrops of Cenozoic rock from the Late
label: BODY

text: Miocene (Gatuña and Ogallala Formations).  There is little reason to infer any significant Early
label: BODY

text: Cenozoic sediment accumulation at the WIPP site.  Erosion is the main process inferred to have
label: BODY

text: occurred during this period and an average erosion rate of approximately 10 m (33 ft) per million
label: BODY

text: years is sufficient during the Cenozoic to erode the maximum inferred Triassic and Cretaceous
label: BODY

text: thickness prior to Gatuña and Ogallala deposition.  Significant thicknesses of Cretaceous rocks
label: BODY

text: may not have been deposited, however, and average erosion rates could have been lower.
label: BODY

text: Maximum-known Gatuña thickness in the area around the WIPP is approximately 100 m
label: BODY

text: (330 ft); at the WIPP site, the Gatuña is very thin to absent.  Ogallala deposits are known from
label: BODY

text: the Divide east of the WIPP site, as well as from the High Plains further east and north.  On the
label: BODY

text: High Plains northeast of the WIPP, the upper Ogallala surface slopes to the southeast at a rate of
label: BODY

text: approximately 4 m/km (20 feet per mile).  A straight projection of the 1,250-m (4,100-ft) contour
label: BODY

text: line from this High Plains surface intersects the site area, which is at an elevation slightly above
label: BODY

text: 1,036 m (3,400 ft).  This difference in elevation of 213 m (700 ft) represents one estimate,
label: BODY

text: probably near an upper bound, of possible unloading subsequent to deposition of the Ogallala
label: BODY

text: Formation.
label: BODY

text: Alternatively, the loading and unloading of the Ogallala could have been closer to 100 m
label: BODY

text: (330 ft).  In any case, it would have occurred as a short-lived pulse over a few million years at
label: BODY

text: most.
label: BODY

text: While the above inferences about greater unit thicknesses and probable occurrence are
label: BODY

text: permissible, a realistic assessment suggests a more modest loading and unloading history
label: BODY

text: (Powers and Holt 1995).  It is likely that the Dewey Lake accumulated to near local maximum
label: BODY

text: thickness of approximately 240 m (787 ft) before being slightly eroded prior to the deposition of
label: BODY

text: Triassic rocks.  It also is most probable that the Triassic rocks accumulated at the site to near
label: BODY

text: local maximum thickness.  In two similar cycles of rapid loading, the Culebra was buried to a
label: BODY

text: depth of approximately 650 m (2,132 ft) by the end of the Triassic.
label: BODY

text: It also seems unlikely that a significant thickness of Cretaceous rock accumulated at the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site.  Erosion probably began during the Jurassic, slowed or stopped during the Early Cretaceous
label: BODY

text: as the area was nearer or at base level, and then accelerated during the Cenozoic, especially in
label: BODY

text: response to uplift as Basin and Range tectonics encroached on the area and the basin was tilted
label: BODY

text: more.  Erosional beveling of Dewey Lake and Santa Rosa suggest considerable erosion since
label: BODY

text: tilting in the mid-Cenozoic.  Erosion rates for this shorter period could have been relatively high,
label: BODY

text: resulting in the greatest stress relief on the Culebra and surrounding units.  Some filling occurred
label: BODY

text: during the Late Cenozoic as the uplifted areas to the west formed an apron of Ogallala sediment
label: BODY

text: across much of the area, but it is not clear how much Gatuña or Ogallala sediment was deposited
label: BODY

text: in the site area.  From general reconstruction of Gatuña history in the area (Powers and Holt
label: BODY

text: 1993, p. 281), the DOE infers that Gatuña or Ogallala deposits likely were not much thicker at
label: BODY

text: March 2004

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: the WIPP site than they are now.  The loading and unloading spike (Figure 2-25) representing
label: BODY

text: Ogallala thickness probably did not occur.  Cutting and headward erosion by the Pecos River has
label: BODY

text: created local relief and unloading by erosion.
label: BODY

text: At the WIPP site, this history is a little complicated by dissolution, though locally (for example,
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw) the effects of erosion and dissolution are more significant.  The underlying
label: BODY

text: evaporites have responded to foundering of anhydrite in less dense halite beds.  These have
label: BODY

text: caused local uplift of the Culebra (as at ERDA 6) but little change in the overburden at the
label: BODY

text: WIPP.  Areas east of the WIPP site are likely to have histories similar to that of the site.  West of
label: BODY

text: the site, the final unloading is more complicated by dissolution and additional erosion leading to
label: BODY

text: exposure of the Culebra along stretches of the Pecos River Valley.

text: 2.1.5.3 Faulting
label: BODY

text: Fault zones are well known along the Central Basin Platform, east of WIPP, from extensive
label: BODY

text: drilling for oil and gas, as reported by Hills (1984).  Holt and Powers performed an analysis in
label: BODY

text: 1988 (CCA Appendix FAC, p. 4-14) of geophysical logs from oil and gas wells to examine the
label: BODY

text: regional geology for the Rustler.  This analysis showed that faults along the margin of the
label: BODY

text: Central Basin Platform displaced Rustler rocks of at least Late Permian age.  The overlying
label: BODY

text: Dewey Lake shows marked thinning along the same trend, according to Schiel (1988, Figure 21),
label: BODY

text: but the structure contours of the top of the Dewey Lake are not clearly offset.  Schiel (1988)
label: BODY

text: concluded that the fault was probably reactivated during the Dewey Lake’s deposition, but
label: BODY

text: movement ceased at least by the time the Santa Rosa was deposited.  No surface displacement or
label: BODY

text: fault has been reported along this trend.
label: BODY

text: Muehlberger et al. (1978) mapped Quaternary fault scarps along the Salt Basin graben west of
label: BODY

text: both the Guadalupe and Delaware mountains.  These are the nearest known Quaternary faults of
label: BODY

text: tectonic origin to the WIPP.  Kelley (1971) inferred the Carlsbad and Barrera faults along the
label: BODY

text: eastern escarpment of the Guadalupe Mountains based mainly on vegetative lineaments.  Hayes
label: BODY

text: and Bachman (1979) reexamined the field evidence for these faults in 1979 and concluded that
label: BODY

text: they were nonexistent.  Figure 2-26 illustrates major regional structures, including faults.
label: BODY

text: On a national basis, Howard et al. (1971, sheets 1 and 2) assessed the location and potential for
label: BODY

text: activity of young faults.  For the region around the WIPP site, Howard et al. (1971, sheet 1)
label: BODY

text: located faults along the western escarpment of the Delaware and Guadalupe mountain trend.
label: BODY

text: These faults were judged to be Late Quaternary (approximately the last 500,000 years) or older.
label: BODY

text: In summary, there are no known Quaternary or Holocene faults of tectonic origin that offset
label: BODY

text: rocks at the surface nearer to the site than the western escarpment of the Guadalupe Mountains.
label: BODY

text: A significant part of the tilt of basin rocks is attributed to a mid-Miocene to Pliocene uplift trend
label: BODY

text: along the Guadalupe-Sacramento Mountains that is inferred on the basis of High Plains
label: BODY

text: sediments of the Ogallala.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6 Nontectonic Processes and Features
label: HH2

text: Nontectonic processes and features, which include evaporite deformation and dissolution of
label: BODY

text: strata, are known to be active in the Delaware Basin.  These processes are of interest because
label: BODY

text: they represent mechanisms that are potentially disruptive to the repository in the long term.  Both
label: BODY

text: processes have been investigated extensively.  The conclusions from these investigations are
label: BODY

text: summarized in this section.
label: BODY

text: Halite in evaporite sequences is relatively plastic, which can lead to the process of deformation;
label: BODY

text: it is also highly soluble, which can lead to the process of dissolution.  Both processes
label: BODY

text: (deformation and dissolution) can produce structural features similar to those produced by
label: BODY

text: tectonic processes.  The features developed by dissolution and deformation can be distinguished
label: BODY

text: from similar-looking tectonic features where the underlying units do not reflect the same feature
label: BODY

text: as do the evaporites.  As an example, the evaporite deformation commonly does not affect the
label: BODY

text: underlying Bell Canyon.  Beds underlying areas of dissolved salt are not affected, but overlying
label: BODY

text: units to the surface may be affected.  The deformation in the Castile and Salado also tends to die
label: BODY

text: out in overlying units, and the Rustler or the Dewey Lake may show little, if any, effects from
label: BODY

text: deformed evaporites.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.1 Evaporite Deformation
label: BODY

text: The most recent review of evaporite deformation in the northern Delaware Basin and original
label: BODY

text: work to evaluate deformation is summarized here.  More detail is provided in CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: DEF.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.1.1  Basic WIPP History of Deformation Investigations
label: BODY

text: The Castile has been known for many years to be deformed in parts of the Delaware Basin,
label: BODY

text: especially along the northern margin.  Jones et al. (1973) clearly showed the Castile to be thicker
label: BODY

text: from the northwestern to northern part of the basin margin, just inside the Capitan Reef.  A
label: BODY

text: dissertation by Snider (1966, Figures 11 and 14) and a paper by Anderson et al. (1972, Figure
label: BODY

text: 10) also presented maps showing some evidence of thicker sections of Castile next to the
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Capitan. ERDA-6 was drilled during 1975 as part of the program to characterize an initial site for
label: BODY

text: WIPP.  The borehole penetrated increasingly deformed beds through the Salado into the Castile,
label: BODY

text: and, at 826 m (2,711 ft) depth, the borehole began to produce pressurized brine and gas.
label: BODY

text: Anderson and Powers (1978, p. 79) and Jones (1981a) interpreted beds to have been displaced
label: BODY

text: structurally by as much as 289.5 m (950 ft).  Some of the lower beds may have pierced overlying
label: BODY

text: beds.  The beds were considered too structurally deformed to mine reasonably along single
label: BODY

text: horizons for a repository.  Therefore, the site was abandoned in 1975, and the current site was
label: BODY

text: located in 1976 (CCA Appendix GCR).  The deformed beds around ERDA-6 were considered
label: BODY

text: part of a deformed zone within about 10 km (6 mi) of the inner margin of the Capitan Reef.  As a
label: BODY

text: consequence, the preliminary selection criteria were revised to prohibit locating a new site within
label: BODY

text: 10 km (6 mi) of the Capitan margin.
label: BODY

text: General criteria for the present site for the WIPP appeared to be met based on initial data from
label: BODY

text: drilling (ERDA-9) and geophysical surveys.  Beginning in 1977, the new site was more
label: BODY

text: intensively characterized through geophysical surveys, including seismic reflection and drilling.
label: BODY

text: Extensive seismic reflection work revealed good reflector quality in the southern part of the site
label: BODY

text: and poor-quality or disturbed reflectors in a sector of the northern part of the site (see CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix DEF, Figure DEF-2.2).  The area of disturbed reflectors became known as the
label: BODY

text: disturbed zone, the area of anomalous seismic reflectors, or the zone of anomalous seismic
label: BODY

text: reflection data.  (The disturbed zone based on poor Castile seismic reflectors is completely
label: BODY

text: different from the DRZ that describes the deformation around mined underground openings at
label: BODY

text: the WIPP.)
label: BODY

text: Powers et al., in CCA Appendix GCR, Figures 4.4, 4.5, and 4.6, generally shows the disturbed
label: BODY

text: zone beginning about 1.6 km (1 mi) north of the WIPP site center.  Borns et al. (1983), included
label: BODY

text: two areas south of the WIPP site as showing the same features of the disturbed zone.  Neill et
label: BODY

text: al.(1983) summarized the limits of the disturbed zone based on differing interpretations and
label: BODY

text: included the area less than 1.6 km (1 mi) north of the site center, where the dip in the Castile
label: BODY

text: begins to steepen.  WIPP-11 was drilled in early 1978 about 5 km (3 mi) north of the site center
label: BODY

text: over part of the disturbed zone where proprietary petroleum company data had also indicated
label: BODY

text: significant seismic anomalies.  The borehole encountered highly deformed beds within the
label: BODY

text: Castile and altered thicknesses of halite units, but no pressurized brine and gas were found.
label: BODY

text: Less than 1.6 km (1 mi) north of the site center, seismic data indicated possible faulting of the
label: BODY

text: upper Salado and the lower Rustler over the area of steepening Castile dips.  Four boreholes
label: BODY

text: (WIPP-18, -19, -21, -22) were drilled into the upper Salado and demonstrated neither faulting
label: BODY

text: nor significant deformation of the Rustler-Salado contact.  Lateral changes in the seismic
label: BODY

text: velocity of the upper sections contributed to the interpretation of a possible fault and thus
label: BODY

text: complicated interpretations of deeper structure.
label: BODY

text: WIPP-12 was located about 1.6 km (1 mi) north of the center of the site and drilled during 1978
label: BODY

text: to a depth of 850 m (2,785 ft) in the upper Castile to determine the significance of structure on
label: BODY

text: possible repository horizons.  The top of the Castile was encountered at an elevation about 49 m
label: BODY

text: (160 ft) above the same contact in ERDA-9 at the site center.
label: BODY

text: WIPP-12 was deepened during late 1981 to a depth of 1,200 m (3,925 ft) to test for possible
label: BODY

text: brine and gas in the deformed Castile.  The probability of encountering brine and gas was

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: DOE-2 was the last WIPP borehole to examine structure within the Castile.  Potash drillhole data
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.1.2  Extent of the Disturbed Zone at the Site
label: BODY

text: Nearby surface drilling, shafts, and underground drilling during early excavations at WIPP
label: BODY

text: showed that the repository horizon varies modestly from the regional structure over the central
label: BODY

text: part of the site; north of the site center, the beds dip gently to the south.  Borns (1987) suggested
label: BODY

text: that the south dip is probably related to the dip on the underlying Castile.
label: BODY

text: The upper surface of MB 139, under the repository horizon, exhibited local relief in the
label: BODY

text: exploratory salt-handling shaft.  Jarolimek et al. (1983, pp. 4 - 6) interpreted the relief as mainly
label: BODY

text: caused by syndepositional growth of gypsum at the water-sediment interface to form mounds
label: BODY

text: and by subsequent partial crushing.  Jarolimek et al. (1983) concluded that the MB relief was not
label: BODY

text: caused by deformation because the base of the MB showed no comparable relief.  Based on
label: BODY

text: concerns of the EEG, MB 139 was reevaluated.  Borns (1985) found less relief on the upper
label: BODY

text: surface of the MB in the areas they examined; he also concluded that depositional processes
label: BODY

text: were responsible for the relief.  In both cases, deformation is not thought to have caused the
label: BODY

text: relief on MB 139.
