text: 2.1.6.1.3  Deformation Mechanisms
label: BODY

text: In analyzing Castile structure in the northern Delaware Basin, Borns et al. (1983, p. 3) proposed
label: BODY

text: five processes as the principal hypotheses to explain the structure:  gravity foundering,
label: BODY

text: dissolution, gravity sliding, gypsum dehydration, and depositional processes.  Gravity foundering
label: BODY

text: is the most comprehensive and best-accepted hypothesis of the five.  It is based on the fact that
label: BODY

text: anhydrite is much more dense (about 2.9 g/cm3) than halite (about 2.1 g/cm3), and anhydrite beds
label: BODY

text: therefore have a potential for sinking into underlying halite.  Regardless of which mechanism
label: BODY

text: caused the disturbed zone, the important consideration is the long-term future effects.  To
label: BODY

text: evaluate this, Borns et al. (1983) postulated that both gravity-driven deformation mechanisms
label: BODY

text: could be ongoing.  The strain rates from such deformation are such that deformation would
label: BODY

text: progress over the next 250,000 years and that such deformation would not directly jeopardize the
label: BODY

text: disposal system.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.1.4 Timing of Deformation of the Disturbed Zone at the Site
label: BODY

text: Jones (1981a, p. 18) estimated that deformation of the Castile and overlying rocks took place
label: BODY

text: before the Ogallala Formation was deposited, as he believes the unit is undeformed.  Anderson
label: BODY

text: and Powers (1978, p. 79) inferred that data from ERDA-6 indicate that the Castile was deformed
label: BODY

text: after the basin was tilted.  Though these lines of evidence could be consistent with mid-Miocene
label: BODY

text: deformation, there are other interpretations consistent with older deformation.  There is no
label: BODY

text: known evidence of surface deformation or other features to indicate recent deformation.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.2 Evaporite Dissolution
label: BODY

text: Because evaporites are much more soluble than most other rocks, project investigators have
label: BODY

text: considered it important to understand the dissolution processes and rates that occur within the
label: BODY

text: site being considered for long-term isolation.  These dissolution processes and rates constitute
label: BODY

text: the limiting factor in any evaluation of the site.  Over the course of the WIPP project, extensive
label: BODY

text: resources have been committed to identify and study a variety of features in southeastern New
label: BODY

text: Mexico interpreted to have been caused by dissolution.  The subsurface distribution of halite for
label: BODY

text: various units has been mapped.  Several different kinds of surface features have been attributed
label: BODY

text: to dissolution of salt or karst formation.  The processes proposed or identified include point-
label: BODY

text: source (brecciation), deep dissolution, shallow dissolution, and karst.  These are each discussed
label: BODY

text: in more detail in CCA Appendix DEF, Section DEF.3.  Screening arguments relative to
label: BODY

text: dissolution are presented in Appendix PA, Attachment SCR, FEPs N17 and N21 (including
label: BODY

text: dissolution associated with abandoned boreholes in the discussion for FEP H34).  These
label: BODY

text: arguments are based principally on the observed rates and processes in the region.  These are
label: BODY

text: described below.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.2.1 Brief History of Project Studies
label: BODY

text: Well before the WIPP project, several geologists recognized that dissolution is an important
label: BODY

text: process in southeastern New Mexico, and that it contributed to the subsurface distribution of
label: BODY

text: halite and to the surficial features.  Early studies include those by Lee (1925), Maley and
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Huffington (1953), and Olive (1957) Robinson and Lang (1938, p. 100) identified an area under
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw where brine occurred at about the stratigraphic position of the upper Salado-basal
label: BODY

text: Rustler and considered that salt had been dissolved to produce a dissolution residue. Vine (1963,
label: BODY

text: p. B38 and B40) mapped Nash Draw and surrounding areas.  Vine (1963) reported surficial
label: BODY

text: domal structures, later called breccia pipes and identified as deep-seated dissolution and collapse
label: BODY

text: features.
label: BODY

text: As the USGS and Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) began to survey southeastern New
label: BODY

text: Mexico as an area in which to locate a repository site in salt, Brokaw et al. (1972) prepared a
label: BODY

text: summary of the geology that included solution and subsidence as significant processes in
label: BODY

text: creating the features of southeastern New Mexico.  Brokaw et al. (1972) also recognized a
label: BODY

text: solution residue at the top of the salt in the Salado in the Nash Draw area, and the unit commonly
label: BODY

text: became known as the brine aquifer because it yielded brine.  Brokaw et al. (1972) also
label: BODY

text: interpreted the east-west decrease in thickness of the Rustler to be a consequence of removal by
label: BODY

text: dissolution of halite and other soluble minerals.
label: BODY

text: During the early 1970s, the basic ideas about shallow dissolution of salt (generally from higher
label: BODY

text: stratigraphic units and within a few hundred feet of the surface) were set out in a series of
label: BODY

text: reports, as discussed in the following sections.  Piper (1973; 1974) independently evaluated the
label: BODY

text: geological survey data for ORNL.  Claiborne and Gera (1974) concluded that salt was being
label: BODY

text: dissolved too slowly from the near-surface units to affect a repository for several million years,
label: BODY

text: at least.
label: BODY

text: By 1978, shallower drilling around the WIPP site to evaluate potash resources was interpreted by
label: BODY

text: Jones (1978, p. 9), who felt that the Rustler included “dissolution debris, convergence of beds,
label: BODY

text: and structural evidence for subsidence.”  Halite in the Rustler has been reevaluated by the DOE,
label: BODY

text: but there are only minor differences in inferred distributions among the various investigators.
label: BODY

text: These investigators do have different explanations about how this distribution occurred (see
label: BODY

text: Section 2.1.3.5 on Rustler stratigraphy):  (1) through extensive dissolution of the Rustler’s halite
label: BODY

text: after the Rustler was deposited, or (2) through syndepositional dissolution of halite from saline
label: BODY

text: mud flat environments during Rustler deposition.
label: BODY

text: Anderson (1978) and Anderson et al. (1978) reevaluated halite distribution in deeper units,
label: BODY

text: especially the Castile and Salado formations.  They identified local anomalies proposed as
label: BODY

text: features developed after deep dissolution of halite by water flowing upward from the underlying
label: BODY

text: Bell Canyon.  Anderson (1978) mapped geophysical log signatures of the Castile and interpreted
label: BODY

text: lateral thinning and change from halite to non-halite lithology as evidence of lateral dissolution
label: BODY

text: of deeper units (part of deep dissolution), and proposed that deep dissolution might threaten the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site.  In response to Anderson’s (1978) developing concepts, ERDA-10 was drilled south
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP area during the latter part of 1977.  ERDA-10 intercepted a stratigraphic sequence
label: BODY

text: without evidence of solution residues in the upper Castile.
label: BODY

text: A set of annular or ring fractures is evident in the surface around San Simon Sink, about 30 km
label: BODY

text: (18 mi) east of the WIPP site.  Nicholson and Clebsch (1961, p. 14) suggested that San Simon
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: data to interpret collapse.  Anderson (1978) and Bachman (1980) both interpret San Simon Sink

label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.2.2  Extent of Dissolution
label: BODY

text: Within the Rustler, dissolution of halite is believed to have occurred only near the depositional
label: BODY

text: margins, as discussed in Section 2.1.3.5.  Figure 2-15 shows the only two areas where evidence
label: BODY

text: has been found for halite dissolution from the M3/H3 horizon in the Tamarisk.
label: BODY

text: Upper intervals of the Salado thin dramatically west and south of the WIPP site (Figure 2-29)
label: BODY

text: compared to deeper Salado intervals.  There are no cores for further consideration of possible
label: BODY

text: depositional variations.  As a consequence, this zone of thinning is interpreted by the DOE as the
label: BODY

text: edge of dissolution of the upper Salado.
label: BODY

text: 2.1.6.2.3  Timing of Dissolution
label: BODY

text: The dissolution of Ochoan evaporites through the near-surface processes of weathering and
label: BODY

text: groundwater recharge has been studied extensively (Anderson 1981; Lambert 1983a; Lambert
label: BODY

text: 1983b; Bachman 1984; and CCA Appendix FAC).  The work of Lambert (1983a) was
label: BODY

text: specifically mandated by the agreement between the DOE and the state of New Mexico to
label: BODY

text: evaluate in detail the conceptual models of evaporite dissolution proposed by Anderson (1981).
label: BODY

text: There was no clear consensus among investigators on the volume of rock salt removed.  Hence,

label: BODY

text: estimates of the instantaneous rate of dissolution vary significantly.  Dissolution may have taken
label: BODY

text: place as early as the Ochoan, during or shortly after deposition.  For the Delaware Basin as a
label: BODY

text: whole, Anderson (1981) proposed that up to 40 percent of the rock salt in the Castile and Salado
label: BODY

text: formations was dissolved during the past 600,000 years.  Lambert (1983b, p. 292) suggested that
label: BODY

text: in many places the variations in salt-bed thicknesses inferred from borehole geophysical logs that
label: BODY

text: were the basis for Anderson’s (1981) calculation were depositional in origin, compensated by
label: BODY

text: thickening of adjacent nonhalite beds, and were not associated with the characteristic dissolution
label: BODY

text: residues.  Borns and Shaffer (1985, p. 44 – 45) also suggested in 1985 a depositional origin for
label: BODY

text: many apparent structural features attributed to dissolution.
label: BODY

text: Snyder (1985, p. 8), as well as earlier workers (for example, Vine 1963; Lambert 1983b; and
label: BODY

text: Bachman 1984), attribute the variations in thickness in the Rustler, which crops out in Nash
label: BODY

text: Draw, to postdepositional evaporite dissolution.  Holt and Powers (CCA Appendix FAC, p. 9-2)
label: BODY

text: have challenged this view and attribute the east-to-west thinning of salt beds in the Rustler to
label: BODY

text: depositional facies variability rather than postdepositional dissolution.  Bachman (1974, 1976,
label: BODY

text: 1980) envisioned several episodes of dissolution since the Triassic, each dominated by greater
label: BODY

text: degrees of evaporite exhumation and a wetter climate, interspersed with episodes of evaporite
label: BODY

text: burial and/or a drier climate.  Evidence for dissolution after deposition of the Salado and before
label: BODY

text: deposition of the Rustler along the western part of the Basin was cited by Adams (1944, p.
label: BODY

text: 1612).  Others have argued that the evaporites in the Delaware Basin were above sea level and
label: BODY

text: therefore potentially subject to dissolution, during the Triassic, Jurassic, Tertiary, and Quaternary
label: BODY

text: periods.  Because of discontinuous deposition, not all of these times are separable in the
label: BODY

text: geological record of southeastern New Mexico.  Bachman (1980) contends that dissolution was
label: BODY

text: episodic during the past 225 million years as a function of regional base level, climate, and
label: BODY

text: overburden.
label: BODY

text: There have been several attempts to estimate the rates of shallow dissolution in the basin.
label: BODY

text: Bachman (1974) provided initial estimates of dissolution rates based on a reconstruction of Nash
label: BODY

text: Draw relationships, including the observation that portions of the Gatuña were deposited over
label: BODY

text: areas of active dissolution and subsidence of the underlying evaporites.  Though these rates
label: BODY

text: indicate no hazard to the WIPP related to Nash Draw dissolution, Bachman (1980, p. 85) later
label: BODY

text: reconsidered the Nash Draw relationships and concluded that pre-Cenozoic dissolution had also
label: BODY

text: contributed to salt removal.  Thus, the initial estimated rates were too high.
label: BODY

text: With regard to deep dissolution, Anderson concluded in 1978 that the integrity of the WIPP to
label: BODY

text: isolate radioactive waste would not be jeopardized by dissolution within about one million years.
label: BODY

text: Anderson and Kirkland (1980, pp. 66 - 69) expanded on the concept of brine density flow
label: BODY

text: proposed by Anderson (1978) as a means of dissolving evaporites at a point by circulating water
label: BODY

text: from the underlying Bell Canyon.  Wood et al. (1982, p. 100) examined the mechanism and
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: collapse of a cylindrical mass of rock, from evaporite karst features that appear similar to breccia
label: BODY

text: pipes.  There are surficial karst features, including sinks and caves, in large areas of the basin.

text: Nash Draw is the result of combined dissolution and erosion.  Within the site boundaries, there
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The subsurface structure of the Culebra is shown in Figure 2-28.  South of the WIPP site, an
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.2 Surface Water and Groundwater Hydrology
label: HH2

text: The DOE has determined that the hydrological characteristics of the disposal system are
label: BODY

text: important because contaminant transport via fluid flow has a potential to impact the performance
label: BODY

text: of the disposal system.  In addition, the EPA has provided numerous criteria related to
label: BODY

text: groundwater in 40 CFR § 194.14(a).  At the WIPP site, one of the DOE’s selection criteria was
label: BODY

text: to choose a location that would minimize this impact.  This was accomplished when the DOE
label: BODY

text: selected (1) a host formation that contains little groundwater and transmits it poorly, (2) a
label: BODY

text: location where the effects of groundwater flow are minimal and predictable, (3) an area where
label: BODY

text: groundwater use is low, (4) an area where there are no permanent surface waters, (5) an area
label: BODY

text: where future groundwater use is unlikely, and (6) a repository host rock that will not likely be
label: BODY

text: affected by anticipated possible long-term climate changes within 10,000 years.
label: BODY

text: The following discussion summarizes the characteristics of the groundwater and surface water at
label: BODY

text: and around the WIPP site.  This summary is based on data collection programs that were
label: BODY

text: initiated with the WIPP program and that continue to some extent today.  The purpose of these
label: BODY

text: programs was to provide information sufficient for the development and use of predictive models
label: BODY

text: of the groundwater movement at the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: For a comprehensive understanding of the impact of groundwater and surface water on the
label: BODY

text: disposal system, the following factors have been evaluated:
label: BODY

text: Groundwater
label: BODY

text: • Horizontal and vertical flow fluxes and velocities,
label: BODY

text: • Hydraulic interconnectivity between rock units,
label: BODY

text: • Hydraulic parameters (porosity, etc.),
label: BODY

text: • General groundwater use, and
label: BODY

text: • Chemistry (including, but not limited to, salinity, mineralization, age, Eh, and pH).
label: BODY

text: Surface Water
label: BODY

text: • Regional precipitation and evapotranspiration rates,
label: BODY

text: • Location and size of surface-water bodies,
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: • Water volume, flow rate, and direction,
label: BODY

text: • Drainage network,
label: BODY

text: • Hydraulic connection with groundwater,
label: BODY

text: • Soil hydraulic properties (infiltration), and
label: BODY

text: • General water chemistry and use.
label: BODY

text: Changes to the hydrological system due to human activity are evaluated in Chapter 6.0.
label: BODY

text: The specifics of groundwater modeling are found in Section 6.4.6, Appendix PA, Attachment
label: BODY

text: MASS, Section MASS.14.2. The hydrological system is divided into four segments for the
label: BODY

text: discussion in this chapter.  These are:  (1) the rock units below the Salado, which may impact the
label: BODY

text: disturbed (human intrusion) performance of the disposal system, (2) the Salado, which mostly
label: BODY

text: addresses the undisturbed performance of the disposal system, (3) the rock units above the
label: BODY

text: Salado, which essentially impact only the disturbed (human intrusion) performance of the
label: BODY

text: disposal system, and (4) the surface waters.  The groundwater regime is discussed in
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.1, and the surface-water regime in Section 2.2.2.
label: BODY

text: The WIPP site lies within the Pecos River drainage area (Figure 2-23, see also Section 2.2.2,
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-43).  As discussed in the Final Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS) (DOE 1980,
label: BODY

text: Section 7.1.1), the climate is semiarid, with a mean annual precipitation of about 0.33 m (13 in.),
label: BODY

text: a mean annual runoff of 2.5 to 5 mm (0.1 to 0.2 in.), and a mean annual pan evaporation of more
label: BODY

text: than 2.5 m (100 in.).  Runoff is practically nonexistent and the WIPP does not have a well
label: BODY

text: defined drainage pattern.  The general movement of runoff can be inferred from the topography
label: BODY

text: in Figure 2-23.  Only one stream flow gaging station has been operated in the vicinity.  This is at
label: BODY

text: the location shown as Hill Tank in Figure 2-23.  Observations at Hill Tank are discussed in
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.2.
label: BODY

text: Additional information about climatic conditions at the WIPP is given in Section 2.5.2.  Brackish
label: BODY

text: water with total dissolved solids (TDS) concentrations of more than 3,000 parts per million is
label: BODY

text: common in the shallow wells near the WIPP site.  Surface waters typically have high TDS
label: BODY

text: concentrations, particularly of chloride, sulfate, sodium, magnesium, and calcium.  Additional
label: BODY

text: information about water quality is given in Section 2.4.2.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1 Groundwater Hydrology
label: HH2

text: At the WIPP site, the DOE has obtained groundwater hydrologic data from conventional and
label: BODY

text: special-purpose test configurations in multiple surface boreholes.  Geophysical logging of the
label: BODY

text: boreholes has provided hydrologic information on the rock strata intercepted.  Pressure
label: BODY

text: measurements, fluid samples, and ranges of rock permeability have been obtained for selected
label: BODY

text: formations through the use of standard and modified drill-stem tests.  Slug injection or
label: BODY

text: withdrawal tests and other flow-rate tests have provided data to aid in the estimation of
label: BODY

text: transmissivity and storage. The hydraulic heads of groundwaters within many water-bearing
label: BODY

text: zones in the region have been mapped from measured depths to water in the boreholes. Since the
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: CCA was submitted to the EPA in 1996, the DOE has implemented a number of monitoring
label: BODY

text: programs (see Appendix MON-2004), including the Groundwater Monitoring Program, to meet
label: BODY

text: the assurance requirements of 40 CFR § 191.14(b).  In addition to the groundwater monitoring
label: BODY

text: program, other hydrologic data gathered since the CCA come from logging of new or
label: BODY

text: replacement wells, piezometers, special-purpose field investigations, and surveys of drilling
label: BODY

text: practices in the Delaware Basin.  A data summary of all these activities is provided in Appendix
label: BODY

text: DATA.
label: BODY

text: Historically, the DOE has obtained hydrological data principally from a conventional well-
label: BODY

text: monitoring network (Figures 2-3 through 2-6 are maps of the well locations) comprising 71 wells
label: BODY

text: located on 45 separate wellpads (DOE 2003).  Most of the 71 wells are completed only to a
label: BODY

text: single hydrologic unit; however, six are multiple-completions to allow monitoring of two or
label: BODY

text: more units in the same well.  Hydrologic information (such as hydraulic head) is obtained at 80
label: BODY

text: completion intervals within the 71 wells.  The focus of the hydrological monitoring is the Rustler
label: BODY

text: (comprising 72 of the 80 monitored intervals) because this formation contains two of the most
label: BODY

text: transmissive saturated units, the Culebra and Magenta Dolomites, which are important to the
label: BODY

text: modeling of releases during various human intrusion scenarios.  Limited hydrological monitoring
label: BODY

text: of the Bell Canyon, Dewey Lake, and Santa Rosa also occurs.
label: BODY

text: Rock units that are shown in the conceptual models in Section 6.4 to be important to disposal
label: BODY

text: system performance from a hydrological standpoint are the Castile, the Salado, the Rustler, and
label: BODY

text: the Dewey Lake (Figures 2-30 and 2-31).  However, other units which are discussed due to their
label: BODY

text: significance in screening hydrological processes or because they are less important to the
label: BODY

text: conceptual model include the Bell Canyon, the Capitan, the Rustler-Salado contact zone, and the
label: BODY

text: supra-Dewey Lake units.  These will also be discussed because they are features of the
label: BODY

text: groundwater flow system of the WIPP region.
label: BODY

text: The Bell Canyon is of interest to the DOE because it is the first regionally continuous water-
label: BODY

text: bearing unit beneath the WIPP and is the target stratigraphic horizon for salt-water injection by
label: BODY

text: industry outside of the WIPP site boundary. The halite and anhydrite layers of the Castile
label: BODY

text: provide a hydrologic barrier between the Salado and the underlying Bell Canyon.  The Castile is
label: BODY

text: of interest to PA because it contains isolated high-permeability zones containing pressurized
label: BODY

text: brine.  As discussed in Section 2.1.6.1, several such zones of pressurized brine have been
label: BODY

text: intercepted by boreholes near the WIPP site, and one or more of these zones may exist at the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: The Salado comprises low-permeability beds of variable composition.  The low permeability of
label: BODY

text: the Salado provides a hydrologic barrier in all directions between the repository and the
label: BODY

text: accessible environment or more transmissive beds.  At the repository horizon, a much higher

text: The Rustler contains two laterally transmissive members.  The Culebra is the first laterally
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: release directly to the surface, the Culebra provides the most direct pathway between the WIPP
label: BODY

text: underground and the accessible environment.  The hydrology and fluid geochemistry of the
label: BODY

text: Culebra are complex and, as a result, have received a great deal of study (see, for example,
label: BODY

text: LaVenue et al. 1988, 1990; Haug et al. 1987; and Siegel et al. 1991.  The Magenta, although
label: BODY

text: more transmissive than the anhydrite and claystone members of the Rustler, has lower
label: BODY

text: transmissivity than the Culebra, and is unfractured at the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: There was no inflow of water from the Dewey Lake into the WIPP shafts after they were
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: observed during construction (the DOE is investigating the source and extent of this water; see
label: BODY

text: Sections 2.2.1.4.2.1 and Appendix DATA).  The quantity and quality of water in the Dewey
label: BODY

text: Lake is also monitored in a deeper fractured zone in the Dewey Lake at well WQSP-6a (WIPP

text: 2.2.1.1 Conceptual Models of Groundwater Flow
label: BODY

text: The DOE addresses issues related to groundwater flow and radionuclide transport within the
label: BODY

text: context of a conceptual model of how the natural hydrologic system works on a large scale.  The
label: BODY

text: conceptual model of regional flow around the WIPP that is presented here is based on widely
label: BODY

text: accepted concepts of regional groundwater flow in groundwater basins (see, for example,
label: BODY

text: Hubbert 1940; Tóth 1963; and Freeze and Witherspoon 1967).
label: BODY

text: See CCA Appendix MASS, Sections MASS.14.1 and MASS.14.2 for a summary of the DOE’s
label: BODY

text: activities leading to the acceptance of the groundwater basin model as a reasonable
label: BODY

text: representation of groundwater flow in the region.
label: BODY

text: An idealized groundwater basin is a three-dimensional closed hydrologic unit bounded on the
label: BODY

text: bottom by an impermeable rock unit (units with much smaller permeability than the units above),
label: BODY

text: on the top by the ground surface, and on the sides by groundwater divides.  The water table is the
label: BODY

text: upper boundary of the region of saturated liquid flow.  All rocks in the basin are expected to
label: BODY

text: have finite permeability; in other words, hydraulic continuity exists throughout the basin. This
label: BODY

text: means that the potential for liquid flow from any unit to any other units exists, although the
label: BODY

text: existence of any particular flow path is dependent on a number of conditions related to gradients
label: BODY

text: and permeabilities.  All recharge to the basin is by infiltration of precipitation to the water table
label: BODY

text: and all discharge from the basin is by flow across the water table to the land surface.
label: BODY

text: Differences in elevation of the water table across an idealized basin provide the driving force for
label: BODY

text: groundwater flow.  The pattern of groundwater flow depends on the lateral extent of the basin,
label: BODY

text: the shape of the water table, and the heterogeneity of the permeability of the rocks in the basin.
label: BODY

text: Water flows along gradients of hydraulic head from regions of high head to regions of low head.
label: BODY

text: The highest and lowest heads in the basin occur at the water table at its highest and lowest
label: BODY

text: points, respectively.  Therefore, groundwater flows from the elevated regions of the water table,
label: BODY

text: downward across confining layers (layers with relatively small permeability), then laterally along
label: BODY

text: more conductive layers, and finally upward to exit the basin in regions where the water table
label: BODY

text: (and by association, the land surface) is at low elevations.  Recharge is necessary to maintain
label: BODY

text: relief on the water table, without which flow does not occur.
label: BODY

text: Groundwater divides are boundaries across which it is assumed that no groundwater flow occurs.
label: BODY

text: In general, these are located in areas where groundwater flow is dominantly downward (recharge
label: BODY

text: areas) or where groundwater flow is upward (discharge areas).  Topography and surface-water
label: BODY

text: drainage patterns provide clues to the location of groundwater divides.  Ridges between creeks
label: BODY

text: and valleys may serve as recharge-type divides, and rivers, lakes, or topographic depressions
label: BODY

text: may serve as discharge-type divides.
label: BODY

text: In the groundwater basin model, rocks can be classified into hydrostratigraphic units.  A
label: BODY

text: hydrostratigraphic unit is a continuous region of rock across which hydraulic properties are
label: BODY

text: similar or vary within described or stated limits.  The definition of hydrostratigraphic units is a
label: BODY

text: practical exercise to separate rock regions with similar hydrologic characteristics from rock
label: BODY

text: regions with dissimilar hydrologic characteristics.  Although hydrostratigraphic units often are
label: BODY

text: defined to be similar to stratigraphic units, this need not be the case.  Hydrostratigraphic unit
label: BODY

text: boundaries can reflect changes in hydraulic properties related to differences in composition,
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: fracturing, dissolution, or a variety of other factors that may not be reflected in the definition of
label: BODY

text: stratigraphic formations.
label: BODY

text: Confining layers in a groundwater basin model can be characterized as allowing vertical flow
label: BODY

text: only.  The amount of vertical flow occurring in a confining layer generally decreases in relation
label: BODY

text: to the depth of the layer.  Flow in conductive units is more complicated.  In general, flow will be
label: BODY

text: lateral through conductive units.  The magnitude (in other words, volume flux) of lateral flow is
label: BODY

text: related to the thickness, conductivity, and gradient present in the unit.  Gradients generally
label: BODY

text: decrease in deeper units.  The direction of flow is generally related to the distance the unit is
label: BODY

text: from the land surface.  Near the land surface, flow directions are influenced primarily by the
label: BODY

text: local slope of the land surface.  In deeper conductive units, flow directions are generally oriented
label: BODY

text: parallel to the direction between the highest and lowest points in a groundwater basin.  Thus,
label: BODY

text: flow rates, volumes, and directions in conductive units in a groundwater basin are generally not
label: BODY

text: expected to be the same.
label: BODY

text: In the WIPP region, the Salado provides an extremely low-permeability layer that forms the base
label: BODY

text: for a regional groundwater-flow basin in the overlying rocks of the Rustler, Dewey Lake, and
label: BODY

text: Santa Rosa.  The Castile and Salado together form their own groundwater system, and they
label: BODY

text: separate flow in units above them from that in units below.  Because of the plastic nature of
label: BODY

text: halite and the resulting low permeability, fluid pressures in the evaporites are more related to
label: BODY

text: lithostatic stress than to the shape of the water table in the overlying units, and regionally neither
label: BODY

text: vertical nor horizontal flow will occur as a result of natural pressure gradients in time scales
label: BODY

text: relevant to the disposal system.  (On a repository scale, however, the excavations themselves
label: BODY

text: create pressure gradients that may induce flow near the excavated region.)  Consistent with the
label: BODY

text: recognition of the Salado as the base of the groundwater basin of primary interest, the following
label: BODY

text: discussion is divided into three sections:  hydrology of units below the Salado, hydrology of the
label: BODY

text: Salado, and hydrology of the units above the Salado.  The DOE has implemented the
label: BODY

text: groundwater basin model in the conceptual model for groundwater flow within the rocks above
label: BODY

text: the Salado.  The details of the model are discussed in Section 6.4.6.  Key modeling assumptions
label: BODY

text: associated with the implementation are provided in Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section
label: BODY

text: MASS.14.2.
label: BODY

text: Technical issues related to the Castile brine, Salado marker bed permeability, and Culebra
label: BODY

text: hydraulic properties (e.g., transmissivity variation) were raised by the EPA in a letter dated
label: BODY

text: December 19, 1996 (Docket A-93-02, Item II-I-01).  The DOE provided additional information
label: BODY

text: regarding these issues in letters dated January 24, 1997; February 7, 1997; April 15, 1997; June
label: BODY

text: 13, 1997; June 27, 1997; and July 3, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Items II-I-03, II-I-07, II-I-24, II-H-
label: BODY

text: 44, II-H-45, and II-H-46, respectively).
label: BODY

text: A request was made in the December 19, 1996 EPA letter (Docket A-93-02, Item II-I-01) that
label: BODY

text: DOE provide general hydraulic characteristic information for all geologic units within the
label: BODY

text: disposal system by revising a partially complete table included in the letter.  The DOE letter,

text: characteristics, and hydraulic gradients for each of the geologic units in the WIPP disposal

text: 2.2.1.2 Units Below the Salado
label: BODY

text: Units of interest to the WIPP project below the Salado are the Bell Canyon and the Castile.
label: BODY

text: These units have quite different hydrologic characteristics.  Because of its potential to contain
label: BODY

text: brine reservoirs below the repository, the hydrology of the Castile is regarded as having the most
label: BODY

text: potential of all units below the Salado to impact the performance of the disposal system.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.2.1  Hydrology of the Bell Canyon Formation
label: BODY

text: The Bell Canyon is considered for the purposes of regional groundwater flow to form a single
label: BODY

text: hydrostratigraphic unit about 300 m (1,000 ft) thick.  Tests at five boreholes (Atomic Energy
label: BODY

text: Commission [AEC]-7, AEC-8, ERDA-10, DOE-2, and Cabin Baby [CB]-1) (CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: HYDRO, pp. 29-31; Beauheim et al. 1983, pp. 4-9 to 4-12; Beauheim 1986, p. 61-1]) indicate a
label: BODY

text: range of hydraulic conductivities for the Bell Canyon from 1.7 × 10-7 to 3.5 × 10-12 m/s (5 ×
label: BODY

text: 10-2 ft/day to 1 × 10-6 ft/day).  The pressure measured in the Bell Canyon at the DOE-2 and
label: BODY

text: CB-1 boreholes at the time of the CCA ranged from 12.6 to 13.3 megapascals.  Under the current
label: BODY

text: groundwater-monitoring program, Bell Canyon water levels are measured in only two wells: CB-
label: BODY

text: 1 and AEC-8 (see locations in Figure 2-6).
label: BODY

text: After recovery from well work in 1999, the Bell Canyon water levels at CB-1 have remained
label: BODY

text: steady for more that three years at 919 m (3,015 ft) above mean sea level (SNL 2003a).  In
label: BODY

text: contrast, since the beginning of 1994, the Bell Canyon water levels at AEC-8 have steadily risen
label: BODY

text: by more than 32 m (106 ft) at a rate of approximately 0.5 m/month (1.6 ft/month) and stood at
label: BODY

text: over 933.4 m (3,062 ft) above mean sea level (SNL 2003a) at the end of 2002.  This water-level
label: BODY

text: rise is hypothesized to be the result of deterioration of the well and not a response to actual Bell
label: BODY

text: Canyon hydrologic conditions at this location.  The well will be inspected and repaired or
label: BODY

text: plugged and abandoned, as necessary, according to the requirements of DOE’s groundwater
label: BODY

text: monitoring program (see Appendix MON-2004).
label: BODY

text: Fluid flow in the Bell Canyon is markedly influenced by the presence of the extremely low-
label: BODY

text: permeability Castile and Salado above it, which effectively isolate the Bell Canyon from
label: BODY

text: interaction with overlying units except where the Castile is absent because of erosion or
label: BODY

text: nondeposition, such as in the Guadalupe Mountains, or where the Capitan Reef is the overlying
label: BODY

text: unit (Figures 2-30 and 2-31).  Because of the isolating nature of the Castile and Salado, fluid
label: BODY

text: flow directions in the Bell Canyon are sensitive only to gradients established over very long
label: BODY

text: distances.  At the WIPP, the brines in the Bell Canyon flow northeasterly under an estimated
label: BODY

text: hydraulic gradient of 4.7 to 7.6 m/km (25 to 40 ft/mi) and discharge into the Capitan aquifer.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Velocities are on the order of tenths of feet per year, and groundwater yields from wells in the
label: BODY

text: Bell Canyon are 2.3 to 5.8 liters (0.6 to 1.5 gallons) per minute.  The fact that flow directions in
label: BODY

text: the Bell Canyon under the WIPP are inferred to be almost opposite to the flow directions in units
label: BODY

text: above the Salado (see Section 2.2.1.4) is not of concern because, as discussed above, the
label: BODY

text: presence of the Castile and Salado makes the flow in the Bell Canyon sensitive to gradients
label: BODY

text: established over long distances, whereas flow in the units above the Salado is sensitive to
label: BODY

text: gradients established by more local variations in water table elevation.
label: BODY

text: As discussed in Appendix DATA, oil companies are currently involved in deep-well injection at
label: BODY

text: several locations outside of the WIPP site boundary.  Specifically, salt water (brine) produced
label: BODY

text: during oil-field exploitation is injected into the Bell Canyon and Brushy Canyon Formations.
label: BODY

text: For nearly four years, the DOE has monitored injection rates and pressures for a cluster of six of
label: BODY

text: these salt water injection wells located approximately 1.6 to 2.4 km (1 to 1.5 mi) northeast of
label: BODY

text: well H-9.  Table 2-5 summarizes the depth intervals of the injection zones for each well.  The
label: BODY

text: cluster of six wells is currently injecting approximately 800 to 950 m3 per day (5,000 to 6,000
label: BODY

text: barrels per day) of salt water; however, in previous years, injection has ranged from
label: BODY

text: approximately 480 to 1270 m3 per day (3,000 to 8,000 barrels per day) (SNL 2003a).  Wellhead
label: BODY

text: injection pressures typically range between 5.5 to 6.9 MPa (800 to 1,000 psi).  Because only two
label: BODY

text: Bell Canyon wells are currently being monitored, the effect of salt-water injection on Bell
label: BODY

text: Canyon water levels is speculative, but water levels in the Bell Canyon monitoring well nearest
label: BODY

text: the cluster (i.e., CB-1, Figure 2-6) indicate no response to the injection.  Additional discussion on
label: BODY

text: potential effects of salt-water injection on the WIPP hydrologic setting is provided below in
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.1.4.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.2.2  Castile Hydrology
label: BODY

text: As described in Section 2.1.3, the Castile is dominated by low-permeability anhydrite and halite
label: BODY

text: zones.  However, fracturing in the upper anhydrite has generated isolated regions with much
label: BODY

text: greater permeability than the surrounding intact anhydrite.  These regions are located in the area
label: BODY

text: of structural deformation, as discussed in Section 2.1.6.1.1.  The higher-permeability regions of
label: BODY

text: the Castile contain brine at pressures greater than hydrostatic and have been referred to as brine
label: BODY

text: reservoirs (see Figure 2-32).  The fluid pressure measured by Popielak et al. (1983) in the WIPP-
label: BODY

text: 12 borehole (12.7 megapascals) is greater than the nominal hydrostatic pressure for a column of
label: BODY

text: equivalent brine at that depth (11.1 megapascals).
label: BODY

text: Therefore, under open-hole conditions, brine could flow upward to the surface through a
label: BODY

text: borehole.
label: BODY

text: Results of hydraulic tests performed in the ERDA-6 and WIPP-12 boreholes suggest that the
label: BODY

text: extent of the highly permeable portions of the Castile is limited.  As discussed in Section 2.1.3.3
label: BODY

text: and modeled in Section 6.4.8, the vast majority of brine is thought to be stored in low-
label: BODY

text: permeability microfractures; about  five percent of the overall brine volume is stored in large

text: A geophysical survey using time-domain electromagnetic (TDEM) methods was completed over
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: under a portion of the waste disposal panels.  Powers et al. (1996) used 354 drill holes and 27
label: BODY

text: Castile brine occurrences to establish that there is an eight percent probability of a hole drilled
label: BODY

text: into the waste panel region encountering brine in the Castile.  This analysis was included as CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix MASS, Attachment 18-6.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Appendix DATA provides extensive information pertinent to the brine reservoirs. The Delaware
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: In the other encounter, initial flows of from 64 to 79 m3 (400 to 500 barrels) per hour were
label: BODY

text: observed, but flow dissipated within hours of the encounter.  Because of the relatively large
label: BODY

text: number of boreholes (345 wells in the nine-township area drilled between 1996 and 2002), the
label: BODY

text: five brine encounters that occurred do not substantially change the probability defined by Powers
label: BODY

text: et al. (1996) and are unlikely to have any significant impact on PA given the large range of
label: BODY

text: probabilities sampled in the PAVT analyses.
label: BODY

text: The origin of brine in the Castile has been investigated geochemically.  Popielak et al. (1983, p.
label: BODY

text: 2) concluded that the ratios of major and minor element concentrations in the brines indicate that
label: BODY

text: these fluids originated from ancient seawater and that no evidence exists for fluid contribution
label: BODY

text: from present meteoric waters.  The Castile brine chemistries from the ERDA-6 and WIPP-12
label: BODY

text: reservoirs are distinctly different from each other and from local groundwaters.  These
label: BODY

text: geochemical data indicate that brine in reservoirs has not mixed to any significant extent with
label: BODY

text: other waters and has not circulated.  The brines are saturated, or nearly so, with respect to halite
label: BODY

text: and, consequently, have little potential to dissolve halite.  The chemical composition of Castile
label: BODY

text: brine is given in Table 2-6. It’s the use of the chemical composition of Castile brine as a
label: BODY

text: parameter in the conceptual model of repository performance is discussed in Appendix PA.

text: 2.2.1.3 Hydrology of the Salado
label: BODY

text: As described in Section 2.1.3, the Salado consists mainly of halite and anhydrite.  A considerable
label: BODY

text: amount of information about the hydraulic properties of these rocks has been collected through
label: BODY

text: field and laboratory experiments.  Appendix PA summarizes this information.
label: BODY

text: Hydraulic testing in the Salado in boreholes in the WIPP underground repository provided
label: BODY

text: quantitative estimates of the hydraulic properties controlling brine flow through the Salado
label: BODY

text: (Beauheim et al. 1991a; Beauheim et al. 1993; Domski et al. 1996; Roberts et al. 1999).  This
label: BODY

text: work was summarized by Beauheim and Roberts (2002).  The stratigraphic intervals tested

label: BODY

text: found to be dependent on the pressures at which the tests were conducted, which is interpreted as
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: dimensions inferred from most test responses are subradial, meaning that flow to/from the test
label: BODY

text: boreholes is not radially symmetric but is derived from a subset of the rock volume.  The
label: BODY

text: subradial flow dimensions are believed to reflect channeling of flow through fracture networks,
label: BODY

text: or portions of fractures, that occupy a diminishing proportion of the radially available space, or
label: BODY

text: through percolation networks that are not “saturated” (that is, fully interconnected).  This is
label: BODY

text: probably related to the directional nature of the permeability created or enhanced by excavation
label: BODY

text: effects.  Other test responses indicate flow dimensions between radial and spherical, which may
label: BODY

text: reflect propagation of pressure transients above or below the plane of the test interval or into
label: BODY

text: regions of increased permeability (e.g., closer to an excavation).  The variable stress and pore-
label: BODY

text: pressure fields around the WIPP excavations probably contribute to the observed non-radial flow
label: BODY

text: dimensions.
label: BODY

text: The properties of anhydrite interbeds have also been investigated in the laboratory.  Tests were
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Fluid pressure above hydrostatic is a hydrologic characteristic of the Salado (and the Castile) that
label: BODY

text: pressures in these formations accurately because the boreholes or repository excavations required
label: BODY

text: to access the rocks decrease the stress in the region measured.  Stress released instantaneously
label: BODY

text: decreases fluid pressure in the pores of the rock, so measured pressures must be considered as a
label: BODY

text: lower bound of the natural pressures.  Stress effects related to test location and the difficulty of
label: BODY

text: making long-duration tests in lower-permeability rocks result in higher pore pressures observed
label: BODY

text: to date in anhydrites.  The highest observed pore pressures in halite-rich units, near Room Q, are
label: BODY

text: on the order of 9 MPa, whereas the highest pore pressures observed in anhydrite are
label: BODY

text: approximately 12 MPa (Beauheim and Roberts 2002, p. 82).  Far-field pore pressures in halite-
label: BODY

text: rich and anhydrite beds in the Salado at the repository level are expected to be similar because
label: BODY

text: the anhydrites are too thin and of too low permeabilities to have liquid pressures much different
label: BODY

text: than those of the surrounding salt.  For comparison, the hydrostatic pressure for a column of
label: BODY

text: brine at the depth of the repository is about 7 MPa, and the lithostatic pressure calculated from
label: BODY

text: density measurements in ERDA-9 is about 15 MPa.
label: BODY

text: Fluid pressures in sedimentary basins that are much higher or much lower than hydrostatic are
label: BODY

text: referred to as abnormal pressures by the petroleum industry, where they have received
label: BODY

text: considerable attention.  In the case of the Delaware Basin evaporites, the high pressures are
label: BODY

text: almost certainly maintained because of the large compressibility and plastic nature of the halite
label: BODY

text: and, to a lesser extent, the anhydrite.  The lithostatic pressure at a particular horizon must be
label: BODY

text: supported by a combination of the stress felt by both the rock matrix and the pore fluid.  In
label: BODY

text: highly deformable rocks, the portion of the stress that must be borne by the fluid exceeds
label: BODY

text: hydrostatic pressure but cannot exceed lithostatic pressure.
label: BODY

text: Brine content within the Salado is estimated at 1 to 2 percent by weight, although the thin clay
label: BODY

text: seams have been inferred by Deal et al. (1993, pp. 4-3) to contain up to 25 percent brine by
label: BODY

text: volume.  Where sufficient permeability exists, this brine will move towards areas of lower
label: BODY

text: hydraulic potential, such as a borehole or mined section of the Salado.
label: BODY

text: Observation of the response of pore fluids in the Salado to changes in pressure boundary
label: BODY

text: conditions at walls in the repository, in boreholes without packers, in packer-sealed boreholes, or
label: BODY

text: in laboratory experiments is complicated by low permeability and low porosity.  Qualitative data
label: BODY

text: on brine flow to underground workings and exploratory boreholes were collected routinely
label: BODY

text: between 1985 and 1993 under the Brine Sampling and Evaluation Program (BSEP) and have
label: BODY

text: been documented in a series of reports (Deal and Case 1987; Deal et al. 1987, 1989, 1991a,
label: BODY

text: 1991b, 1993, and 1995).  A discussion of alternative conceptual models for Salado fluid flow is
label: BODY

text: given in Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section MASS.7.  Additional data on brine inflow
label: BODY

text: are available from the Large-Scale Brine Inflow Test (Room Q).  Flow has been observed to
label: BODY

text: move to walls in the repository, to boreholes without packers, and to packer-sealed boreholes.
label: BODY

text: These qualitative and relatively short-term observations suggest that brine flow in the fractured
label: BODY

text: DRZ is a complex process.  In some locations, evidence for flow is no longer observed where it
label: BODY

text: once was; in others, flow has begun where it once was not observed.  In many cases,
label: BODY

text: observations and experiments must last for months or years to obtain useful results.
label: BODY

text: For PA modeling, brine flow is a calculated term dependent on local hydraulic gradients and
label: BODY

text: properties of the Salado units.  Data on pore pressure and permeability of halite and anhydrite
label: BODY

text: discusses the role of brine chemistry in the conceptual model for actinide dissolution.  The
label: BODY

text: conceptual model is described in Section 6.4.3.5.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4 Units Above the Salado
label: BODY

text: In evaluating groundwater flow above the Salado, the DOE considers the Rustler, Dewey Lake,
label: BODY

text: Santa Rosa, and overlying units to form a groundwater basin with boundaries coinciding with
label: BODY

text: selected groundwater divides as discussed in Section 2.2.1.1.  The model boundary follows Nash
label: BODY

text: Draw and the Pecos River valley to the west and south and the San Simon Swale to the east
label: BODY

text: (Figure 2-33).  The boundary continues up drainages and dissects topographic highs along its
label: BODY

text: northern part.  These boundaries represent groundwater divides whose positions remain fixed
label: BODY

text: over the past several thousand years and 10,000 years into the future.  For reasons described in
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.1.2.1, the lower boundary of the groundwater basin is the upper surface of the
label: BODY

text: Salado.  Nash Draw and the Pecos River are areas where discharge to the surface occurs.  Hunter
label: BODY

text: (1985) described discharge at Surprise Spring and into saline lakes in Nash Draw.  She reported
label: BODY

text: groundwater discharge into the Pecos River between Avalon Dam north of Carlsbad and a point
label: BODY

text: south of Malaga Bend as approximately 0.92 m3/s (32.5 ft3/s), mostly in the region near Malaga
label: BODY

text: Bend.
label: BODY

text: Within this groundwater basin, hydrostratigraphic units with relatively high permeability are
label: BODY

text: called conductive units, and those with relatively low permeability are called confining layers.
label: BODY

text: The confining layers consist of halite and anhydrite and are perhaps five orders of magnitude less
label: BODY

text: permeable than conductive units.
label: BODY

text: In a groundwater basin, the position of the water table moves up and down in response to
label: BODY

text: changes in recharge.  The amount of recharge is generally a very small fraction of the amount of
label: BODY

text: rainfall; this condition is expected for the WIPP.  Modeling of recharge changes within the
label: BODY

text: groundwater basin as a function of climate variation is discussed in Section 6.4.9.  The water
label: BODY

text: table would stabilize at a particular position if the pattern of recharge remained constant for a
label: BODY

text: long time.  The equilibrated position depends, in part, on the distribution of hydraulic
label: BODY

text: conductivity in all hydrostratigraphic units in the groundwater basin.  However, the position of
label: BODY

text: the water table depends mainly on the topography and geometry of the groundwater basin and
label: BODY

text: the hydraulic conductivity of the uppermost strata.  The position of the water table can adjust
label: BODY

text: slowly to changes in recharge.  Consequently, the water table can be at a position that is very
label: BODY

text: much different from its equilibrium position at any given time.  Generally, the water table drops
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: HH2

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: very slowly in response to decreasing recharge but might rise rapidly in times of increasing
label: BODY

text: recharge.
label: BODY

text: The asymmetry of response occurs because the rate at which the water table drops is limited by
label: BODY

text: the rate at which water flows through the entire basin.  In contrast, the rate at which the water
label: BODY

text: table rises depends mainly on the recharge rate and the porosity of the uppermost strata.  From
label: BODY

text: groundwater basin modeling, the head distribution in the groundwater basin appears to
label: BODY

text: equilibrate rapidly with the position of the water table.
label: BODY

text: The groundwater basin conceptual model (Corbet and Knupp 1996) described above has been
label: BODY

text: implemented in a numerical model, as described in CCA Appendix MASS, Section MASS.14.2.
label: BODY

text: This model has been used to simulate the interactive nature of flow through conductive layers
label: BODY

text: and confining units for a variety of possible rock properties and climate futures.  Thus, this
label: BODY

text: model has allowed insight into the magnitude of flow through various units.  The DOE has used
label: BODY

text: this insight as a basis for model simplifications used in PA that are described here and in Chapter
label: BODY

text: One conclusion from the regional groundwater basin modeling is pertinent here.  In general,
label: BODY

text: vertical leakage through confining layers is directed downward over all of the controlled area.
label: BODY

text: This downward leakage uniformly over the WIPP site is the result of a well-developed discharge
label: BODY

text: area, Nash Draw and the Pecos River, along the western and southern boundaries of the
label: BODY

text: groundwater basin.  This area acts as a drain for the laterally conductive units in the groundwater
label: BODY

text: basin, causing most vertical leakage in the groundwater basin to occur in a downward direction.
label: BODY

text: This conclusion is important in PA simplifications related to the relative importance of lateral
label: BODY

text: flow in the Magenta versus the Culebra, which will be discussed later in this chapter and in
label: BODY

text: Section 6.4.6.
label: BODY

text: Public concern was expressed that groundwater flow to the spring supplying brine to Laguna
label: BODY

text: Grande de la Sal could be related to the presence of karst features.  The EPA examined
label: BODY

text: information regarding the hydrology of the units above the Salado and DOE’s conceptualization
label: BODY

text: of the groundwater flow model, including supplementary information submitted in letters dated
label: BODY

text: May 2, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Item V-B-6 (6)), and May 14, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Item II-I-
label: BODY

text: 31), and the EPA concluded that the information was adequate.
label: BODY

text: The EPA concluded, based on WIPP field observations and site-specific hydrologic information,
label: BODY

text: there is no indication that any cavernous or other karst-related flow is present within the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site boundary. The EPA concurred with DOE’s conceptualization of groundwater flow in the
label: BODY

text: Culebra, which includes the presence of fractures within the Culebra and recharge and discharge
label: BODY

text: areas for groundwater that are more consistent with potential discharge to areas south and west
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.1  Hydrology of the Rustler Formation
label: BODY

text: The Rustler is of particular importance for WIPP because it contains the most transmissive units
label: BODY

text: above the repository.  Fluid flow in the Rustler is characterized by very slow rates of vertical
label: BODY

text: leakage through confining layers and faster lateral flow in conductive units.  To illustrate this
label: BODY

text: point, regional modeling with the groundwater basin model indicates that lateral specific
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: discharges in the Culebra, for example, are perhaps two to three orders of magnitude greater than
label: BODY

text: the vertical specific discharges across the top of the Culebra.
label: BODY

text: Because of its importance, the Rustler continues to be the focus of studies to understand better
label: BODY

text: the complex relationship between hydrologic properties and geology, particularly in view of
label: BODY

text: water-level rises observed in the Culebra and Magenta (e.g., SNL 2003a; also see Appendix
label: BODY

text: DATA).  An example of the complex nature of Rustler hydrology is the variation in Culebra
label: BODY

text: transmissivity (T).  Culebra T varies over three orders of magnitude on the WIPP site itself and
label: BODY

text: over six orders of magnitude on the scale of the regional groundwater basin model with lower T
label: BODY

text: east of the site and higher T west of the site in Nash Draw (e.g., Beauheim and Ruskauff 1998).
label: BODY

text: As discussed below, site investigations and studies (e.g., Holt and Powers 1988; Beauheim and
label: BODY

text: Holt 1990; Powers and Holt 1995; Holt 1997; Holt and Yarbrough 2002; Powers et al. 2003)
label: BODY

text: suggest that the variability in Culebra T can be explained largely by the thickness of Culebra
label: BODY

text: overburden, the location and extent of upper Salado dissolution, and the occurrence of halite in
label: BODY

text: the mudstone units bounding the Culebra (see Section 2.1.3.5).
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.1.1  Los Medaños
label: BODY

text: The unnamed lower member was named the Los Medaños by Powers and Holt (1999). The Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños is treated as a single hydrostratigraphic unit in WIPP models of the Rustler, although
label: BODY

text: its composition varies. Overall, it acts as a confining layer. The basal interval of the Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños, approximately 19.5 m (64 ft) thick, is composed of siltstone, mudstone, and claystone
label: BODY

text: and contains the water-producing zones of the lowermost Rustler.  Transmissivities of 2.9 ×10-10
label: BODY

text: m2/s (2.7 × 10-4 ft2/day) and 2.4 × 10-10 m2/s (2.2 × 10-4 ft2/day) were reported by Beauheim
label: BODY

text: (1987a, p. 50) from tests at well H-16 that included this interval.  The porosity of the Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños was measured in 1995 as part of testing at the H-19 hydropad (TerraTek 1996). Two
label: BODY

text: claystone samples had effective porosities of 26.8 and 27.3 percent. One anhydrite sample had an
label: BODY

text: effective porosity of 0.2 percent.  The transmissivity values correspond to hydraulic
label: BODY

text: conductivities of 1.5 × 10-11 m/s (4.2 × 10-6 ft/day) and 1.2 × 10-11 m/s (3.4 × 10-6 ft/day).
label: BODY

text: Hydraulic conductivity in the lower portion of the Los Medaños is believed by the DOE to
label: BODY

text: increase to the west in and near Nash Draw, where dissolution at the underlying Rustler-Salado
label: BODY

text: contact has caused subsidence and fracturing of the sandstone and siltstone.
label: BODY

text: The remainder of the Los Medaños contains mudstones, anhydrite, and variable amounts of
label: BODY

text: halite.  The hydraulic conductivity of these lithologies is extremely low.  It is for this reason the
label: BODY

text: Los Medaños is treated as a single hydrostratigraphic unit that overall acts as a confining unit.
label: BODY

text: The conceptual model incorporating the Los Medaños is discussed in Section 6.4.6.1.  Important
label: BODY

text: hydrologic model properties of the Los Medaños are summarized in Appendix PA.
label: BODY

text: As described in Section 2.1.3.5, the Los Medaños contains two mudstone layers: one in the
label: BODY

text: middle of the Los Medaños and one immediately below the Culebra.  An anhydrite layer
label: BODY

text: separates the two mudstones.  The lower and upper Los Medaños mudstones have been given the
label: BODY

text: designations M1/H1 and M2/H2, respectively, by Holt and Powers (1988).  This naming
label: BODY

text: convention is used to indicate the presence of halite in the mudstone at some locations at and
label: BODY

text: near the WIPP site.  Powers (2002a) has mapped (Figure 2-15) the margins delineating the
label: BODY

text: occurrence of halite in both mudstone layers.  Whereas early researchers (e.g., Snyder 1985)
label: BODY

text: interpreted the absence of halite west of these margins as evidence of dissolution, Holt and
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Powers (1988) interpreted it as reflecting changes in the depositional environment, not
label: BODY

text: dissolution.  However, Holt and Powers (1988) concluded that dissolution of Rustler halite may
label: BODY

text: have occurred along the present-day margins.  The presence of halite in the Los Medaños
label: BODY

text: mudstones is likely to affect the conductivity of the mudstones, but its greater importance is the
label: BODY

text: implications it has for the conductivity of the Culebra.  As discussed in Section 2.2.1.4.1.2, the
label: BODY

text: Culebra transmissivity in locations where halite is present in M2/H2 and M3/H3 (a mudstone in
label: BODY

text: the lower Tamarisk Member of the Rustler) is assumed to be an order of magnitude lower than
label: BODY

text: where halite does not occur (Holt and Yarbrough 2002).
label: BODY

text: Fluid pressures in the Los Medaños have been continuously measured at well H-16 since 1987.
label: BODY

text: During this period, the fluid pressure has remained relatively constant at between 190 and 195
label: BODY

text: psi or a head of approximately 137 m (450 ft).  Given the location of the pressure transducer (an
label: BODY

text: elevation of 811.96 m amsl), the current elevation of the Los Medaños water level at H-16 is
label: BODY

text: approximately 949 m amsl.  No other wells in the WIPP monitoring network are completed to
label: BODY

text: the Los Medaños.  Thus, H-16 provides the only current head information for this member.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.1.2  The Culebra Dolomite Member
label: BODY

text: The Culebra is of interest because it is the most transmissive saturated unit above the WIPP
label: BODY

text: repository and hydrologic research has been concentrated on the unit for nearly two decades.
label: BODY

text: Although it is relatively thin, it is an entire hydrostratigraphic unit in the WIPP hydrological
label: BODY

text: conceptual model, and it is the most important conductive unit in this model.  Implementation of
label: BODY

text: the Culebra in the conceptual model is discussed in detail in Section 6.4.6.2.  Model discussions
label: BODY

text: cover groundwater flow and transport characteristics of the Culebra.  These are supported by
label: BODY

text: parameter values in Table 6-20, 6-21, 6-22, and 6-23.  Additional background for the Culebra
label: BODY

text: model is in CCA Appendix MASS, Sections MASS.14 and MASS.15.
label: BODY

text: The two primary types of field tests used to characterize the flow and transport characteristics of
label: BODY

text: the Culebra are hydraulic tests and tracer tests.
label: BODY

text: The hydraulic testing consists of pumping, injection, and slug testing of wells across the study
label: BODY

text: area (for example, Beauheim 1987a, p. 3).  The most detailed hydraulic test data exist for the
label: BODY

text: WIPP hydropads (for example, H-19).  The hydropads generally comprise a network of three or
label: BODY

text: more wells located within a few tens of meters of each other.  Long-term pumping tests have
label: BODY

text: been conducted at hydropads H-3, H-11, and H-19 and at well WIPP-13 (Beauheim 1987b;
label: BODY

text: 1989; Beauheim et al. 1995; Meigs et al. 2000).  These pumping tests provided transient pressure
label: BODY

text: data at the hydropad and over a much larger area.  Tests often included use of automated data-
label: BODY

text: acquisition systems, providing high-resolution (in both space and time) data sets.  In addition to
label: BODY

text: long-term pumping tests, slug tests and short-term pumping tests have been conducted at
label: BODY

text: individual wells to provide pressure data that can be used to interpret the transmissivity at that
label: BODY

text: well (Beauheim 1987a).  (Additional short-term pumping tests have been conducted in the
label: BODY

text: WQSP wells [Beauheim and Ruskauff 1998]).  Detailed cross-hole hydraulic testing has been
label: BODY

text: conducted at the H-19 hydropad (Beauheim 2000).
label: BODY

text: The hydraulic tests are designed to yield pressure data for the interpretation of such
label: BODY

text: characteristics as transmissivity, permeability, and storativity.  The pressure data from long-term
label: BODY

text: pumping tests and the interpreted transmissivity values for individual wells are used for the
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: generation of transmissivity fields in PA flow modeling (see Appendix PA, Attachment TFIELD,
label: BODY

text: Sections TFIELD 5.0 and TFIELD-6.0).  Some of the hydraulic test data and interpretations are
label: BODY

text: also important for the interpretation of transport characteristics.  For instance, information about
label: BODY

text: the vertical distribution of permeability interpreted from the hydraulic tests at a given hydropad
label: BODY

text: is needed for interpretations of tracer test data at that hydropad.
label: BODY

text: To evaluate transport properties of the Culebra, a series of tracer tests were conducted at six
label: BODY

text: locations (the H-2, H-3, H-4, H-6, H-11, and H-19 hydropads) near the WIPP site.  Tests at the
label: BODY

text: first five of these locations consisted of two-well dipole tests and/or multiwell convergent flow
label: BODY

text: tests and are described in detail in Jones et al. (1992).  Tracer tests at the H-19 hydropad and
label: BODY

text: additional tracer tests performed at the H-11 hydropad are described in Meigs et al. (2000).  The
label: BODY

text: 1995-1996 tracer test program consisted of single-well injection-withdrawal tests and multi-well
label: BODY

text: convergent flow tests (Meigs and Beauheim 2001).  Unique features of this testing program
label: BODY

text: include the single-well test at both H-19 and H-11, the injection of tracers into six wells during
label: BODY

text: the H-19 convergent-flow test, the injection of tracer into upper and lower zones of the Culebra
label: BODY

text: at the H-19 hydropad, repeated injections under different convergent-flow pumping rates, and the
label: BODY

text: use of tracers with different free-water diffusion coefficients.  The 1995-1996 tracer tests were
label: BODY

text: specifically designed to evaluate the importance of heterogeneity (both horizontal and vertical)
label: BODY

text: and diffusion on transport processes.
label: BODY

text: The Culebra is a fractured dolomite with nonuniform properties both horizontally and vertically.
label: BODY

text: Examination of core and shaft exposures has revealed that there are multiple scales of porosity
label: BODY

text: within the Culebra including fractures ranging from microscale to potentially large, vuggy zones,
label: BODY

text: and interparticle and intercrystalline porosity (Holt 1997).  Porosity measurements made on core
label: BODY

text: samples give porosity measurements ranging from 0.03 to 0.30 (Kelley and Saulnier 1990;
label: BODY

text: TerraTek 1996).  This large range in porosity for small samples is expected given the variety of
label: BODY

text: porosity types within the Culebra.  However, the effective porosity for flow and transport at
label: BODY

text: larger scales will have a smaller range due to the effects of spatial averaging.  The core
label: BODY

text: measurements indicate that the Culebra has significant quantities of connected porosity.
label: BODY

text: Flow in the Culebra occurs within fractures, within vugs where they are connected by fractures,
label: BODY

text: and to some extent within interparticle porosity where the porosity (and permeability) is high,
label: BODY

text: such as chalky lenses.  At any given location, flow will occur in response to hydraulic gradients
label: BODY

text: in all places that are permeable.  When the permeability contrast between different scales of
label: BODY

text: connected porosity is large, the total porosity can effectively be conceptualized by dividing the
label: BODY

text: system into advective porosity (often referred to as fracture porosity) and diffusive porosity
label: BODY

text: (often referred to as matrix porosity).  The advective porosity can be defined as the portion of the
label: BODY

text: porosity where flow is the dominant process (for example fractures and to some extent vugs
label: BODY

text: connected by fractures and interparticle porosity).  Diffusive porosity can be defined as the
label: BODY

text: portion of the porosity where diffusion is the dominant process (for example, intercrystalline
label: BODY

text: porosity and to some extent microfractures, vugs and portions of the interparticle porosity.)
label: BODY

text: For the Culebra in the vicinity of the WIPP site, defining advective porosity is not a simple
label: BODY

text: matter.  In some regions the permeability of the fractures is inferred to be significantly larger
label: BODY

text: than the permeability of the other porosity types, thus advective porosity can be conceptualized
label: BODY

text: as predominantly fracture porosity (low porosity).  In some regions, there appear to be no high
label: BODY

text: permeability fractures.  This may be due to a lack of large fractures or may be the result of
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: gypsum fillings in a portion of the porosity.  Where permeability contrasts between porosity
label: BODY

text: types are small, the advective porosity can be conceptualized as a combination of fractures, vugs
label: BODY

text: connected by fractures, and permeable portions of the interparticle porosity.  In each case, the
label: BODY

text: diffusive porosity can be conceptualized as the porosity where advection is not dominant.
label: BODY

text: The major physical transport processes that affect actinide transport through the Culebra include
label: BODY

text: advection (through fractures and other permeable porosity), diffusion from the advective porosity
label: BODY

text: into the rest of the connected porosity (diffusive porosity) and dispersive spreading due to
label: BODY

text: heterogeneity.  Diffusion can be an important process for effectively retarding solutes by
label: BODY

text: transferring mass from the porosity where advection (flow) is the dominant process into other
label: BODY

text: portions of the rock.  Diffusion into stagnant portions of the rock also provides access to
label: BODY

text: additional surface area for sorption. Further discussion of transport of actinides in the Culebra as
label: BODY

text: either dissolved species or as colloids is given in Section 6.4.6.2.  Parameter values determined
label: BODY

text: from tests of the Culebra are given in CCA Appendix PAR and are described in Section
label: BODY

text: 6.4.6.2.2.  A summary of input values to the conceptual model is in Tables 6-22 and 6-23.
label: BODY

text: Fluid flow in the Culebra is dominantly lateral and southward except in discharge areas along the
label: BODY

text: west or south boundaries of the basin.  Where transmissive fractures exist, flow is dominated by
label: BODY

text: fractures but may also occur in vugs connected by microfractures and interparticle porosity.
label: BODY

text: Regions where flow is dominantly through vugs connected by microfractures and interparticle
label: BODY

text: porosity have been inferred from pumping tests and tracer tests.  Flow in the Culebra may be
label: BODY

text: concentrated along zones that are thinner than the total thickness of the Culebra.  In general, the
label: BODY

text: upper portion of the Culebra is massive dolomite with a few fractures and vugs, and appears to
label: BODY

text: have low permeability.  The lower portion of the Culebra appears to have many more vuggy and
label: BODY

text: fractured zones and to have significantly higher permeability (Meigs and Beauheim 2001).
label: BODY

text: There is strong evidence that the permeability of the Culebra varies spatially and varies
label: BODY

text: sufficiently that it cannot be characterized with a uniform value or range over the region of
label: BODY

text: interest to the WIPP.  The transmissivity of the Culebra varies spatially over six orders of
label: BODY

text: magnitude from east to west in the vicinity of the WIPP (Figure 2-34).  Over the site, Culebra
label: BODY

text: transmissivity varies over three to four orders of magnitude.  CCA Appendix TFIELD, Section
label: BODY

text: TFIELD.2 contains the data used to develop Figure 2-34, which shows variation in
label: BODY

text: transmissivity in the Culebra in the WIPP region.  Attachment TFIELD to Appendix P provides
label: BODY

text: the modeling rationale and addresses how data collected over a number of years were correlated
label: BODY

text: for the generation of transmissivity fields.
label: BODY
