label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-34.  Transmissivities of the Culebra
label: BODY

text: Transmissivities are from about 1 × 10-9 m2/s (1 × 10-3 ft2/day) at well P-18 east of the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site to about 1 × 10-3 m2/s (1 × 103 ft2/day) at well H-7 in Nash Draw (see Figure 2-2 for the
label: BODY

text: locations of these wells and see Figure 4-8 in CCA Appendix FAC for a Culebra isopach map).
label: BODY

text: Transmissivity variations in the Culebra are believed to be controlled by the relative abundance
label: BODY

text: of open fractures rather than by primary (that is, depositional) features of the unit.  Lateral
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: variations in depositional environments were small within the mapped region, and primary
label: BODY

text: features of the Culebra show little map-scale spatial variability, according to Holt and Powers
label: BODY

text: (CCA Appendix FAC).  Direct measurements of the density of open fractures are not available
label: BODY

text: from core samples because of incomplete recovery and fracturing during drilling, but observation
label: BODY

text: of the relatively unfractured exposures in the WIPP shafts suggests that the density of open
label: BODY

text: fractures in the Culebra decreases to the east.
label: BODY

text: Recent investigations have made a significant contribution to the understanding of the large
label: BODY

text: variability observed for Culebra transmissivity (e.g., Holt and Powers 1988; Beauheim and Holt
label: BODY

text: 1990; Powers and Holt 1995; Holt 1997; Holt and Yarbrough 2002; Powers et al. 2003).  The
label: BODY

text: spatial distribution of Culebra transmissivity is believed to be due strictly to deterministic post-
label: BODY

text: depositional processes and geologic controls (Holt and Yarbrough 2002).  The important
label: BODY

text: geologic controls include Culebra overburden thickness, dissolution of the upper Salado, and the
label: BODY

text: occurrence of halite in the mudstone Rustler units (M2/H2 and M3/H3) above and below the
label: BODY

text: Culebra (Holt and Yarbrough 2002).  Culebra transmissivity is inversely related to thickness of
label: BODY

text: overburden because stress relief associated with erosion of overburden (see Section 2.1.5.2)
label: BODY

text: leads to fracturing and opening of preexisting fractures.  Culebra transmissivity is high where
label: BODY

text: dissolution of the upper Salado has occurred and the Culebra has subsided and fractured.
label: BODY

text: Culebra transmissivity is observed to be low where halite is present in overlying and/or
label: BODY

text: underlying mudstones.  Presumably, high Culebra transmissivity leads to dissolution of nearby
label: BODY

text: halite (if any).  Hence, the presence of halite in mudstones above and/or below the Culebra can
label: BODY

text: be taken as an indicator for low Culebra transmissivity.  Details of the geologic-based
label: BODY

text: The Culebra has been tested hydraulically at 42 locations, yielding reliable transmissivity values.
label: BODY

text: These values (log T) are plotted as a function of depth to Culebra (overburden thickness) in
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: distribution for transmissivity with one population having high transmissivity and the other low
label: BODY

text: transmissivity, with the difference attributed to open, interconnected fractures (“fracture
label: BODY

text: interconnectivity”) for the high-transmissivity population (Holt and Yarbrough 2002).  Using
label: BODY

text: these data, Holt and Yarbrough (2002) constructed a linear Culebra transmissivity model relating
label: BODY

text: In the region east of the upper Salado dissolution margin and west of the M2/H2 and M3/H3
label: BODY

text: margins, high transmissivity depends, in part, on the absence of gypsum fracture fillings.  No
label: BODY

text: method has yet been determined for predicting whether fractures will or will not be filled with
label: BODY

text: gypsum at a given location, so the distribution of high and low transmissivity is treated
label: BODY

text: stochastically in this region.  Predictions of transmissivity in this region make use of an isotropic
label: BODY

text: spherical variogram model.  Fitted parameters for the variogram model are described in
label: BODY

text: Attachment TFIELD (Section TFIELD-4.3) of Appendix PA.
label: BODY

text: Geochemical and radioisotope characteristics of the Culebra have been studied.  There is
label: BODY

text: considerable variation in groundwater geochemistry in the Culebra.  The variation has been
label: BODY

text: described in terms of different hydrogeochemical facies that can be mapped in the Culebra (see
label: BODY

text: Section 2.4.2).  A halite-rich hydrogeochemical facies exists in the region of the WIPP site and
label: BODY

text: to the east, approximately corresponding to the regions in which halite exists in units above and
label: BODY

text: below the Culebra  (Figure 2-15), and in which a large portion of the Culebra fractures are
label: BODY

text: gypsum filled (Figure 2-17).  An anhydrite-rich hydrogeochemical facies exists west and south
label: BODY

text: of the WIPP site, where there is relatively less halite in adjacent strata and where there are fewer
label: BODY

text: gypsum-filled fractures.
label: BODY

text: The Culebra groundwater geochemistry studies continue.  Culebra water quality is evaluated
label: BODY

text: semiannually at six wells, three north (WQSP-1, WQSP-2, and WQSP-3) and three south
label: BODY

text: (WQSP-4, WQSP-5, and WQSP-6) (WIPP MOC 1995) of the surface structures area (see Figure
label: BODY

text: 2-3 for well locations).  Five rounds of semiannual sampling of water quality completed before
label: BODY

text: the first receipt of waste at the WIPP were used to establish the initial Culebra water-quality
label: BODY

text: baseline for major ion species including Na+, Ca2+, Mg2
label: BODY

text: SO4
label: BODY

text: 2-, and HCO3
label: BODY

text: 2- (Crawley and Nagy 1998).  In 2000, this baseline was expanded to include
label: BODY

text: five additional rounds of sampling that were completed before first receipt of RCRA-regulated
label: BODY

text: waste (IT Corporation 2000).  Table 2-8 gives the 95 percent confidence intervals presented in
label: BODY

text: SNL (2001) for the major ion species determined from the 10 rounds (semiannual sampling for 5
label: BODY

text: years) of baseline sampling.  Culebra water quality is extremely variable among the six sampling
label: BODY

text: wells, as shown by the Cl- concentrations that range from approximately 6,000 mg/L at WQSP-6
label: BODY

text: to 130,000 mg/L at WQSP-3.
label: BODY

text: Radiogenic isotopic signatures suggest that the age of the groundwater in the Culebra is on the
label: BODY

text: order of 10,000 years or more (see, for example, Lambert 1987, Lambert and Carter 1987, and
label: BODY

text: Lambert and Harvey 1987).  The radiogenic ages of the Culebra groundwater and the
label: BODY

text: geochemical differences provide information potentially relevant to the groundwater flow
label: BODY

text: directions and groundwater interaction with other units and are important constraints on

text: conceptual models of groundwater flow.  Previous conceptual models of the Culebra (see for
label: BODY

text: example, Chapman 1986, Chapman 1988, LaVenue et al. 1990, and Siegel et al. 1991) have not
label: BODY

text: been able to consistently relate the hydrogeochemical facies, radiogenic ages, and flow
label: BODY

text: constraints (that is, transmissivity, boundary conditions, etc.) in the Culebra.
label: BODY

text: The groundwater basin modeling that was conducted, although it did not model solute transport
label: BODY

text: processes, provides flow fields that can be used to develop the following concepts that help
label: BODY

text: explain the observed hydrogeochemical facies and radiogenic ages.  The groundwater basin
label: BODY

text: model combines and tests three fundamental processes:  (1) it calculates vertical leakage, which
label: BODY

text: may carry solutes into the Culebra; (2) it calculates lateral fluxes in the Culebra (directions as
label: BODY

text: well as rates); and (3) it calculates a range of possible effects of climate change.  The presence of
label: BODY

text: the halite-rich groundwater facies is explained by vertical leakage of solutes into the Culebra
label: BODY

text: from the overlying halite-containing Tamarisk by advective or diffusive processes.  Because
label: BODY

text: lateral flow rates here are low, even slow rates of solute transport into the Culebra can result in
label: BODY

text: high solute concentration.  Vertical leakage occurs slowly over the entire model region, and thus
label: BODY

text: the age of groundwater in the Culebra is old, consistent with radiogenic information.  Lateral
label: BODY

text: fluxes within the anhydrite zone are larger because of higher transmissivity, and where the halite
label: BODY

text: and anhydrite facies regions converge, the halite facies signature is lost by dilution with
label: BODY

text: relatively large quantities of anhydrite facies groundwater.  Response of groundwater flow in the
label: BODY

text: Culebra as the result of increasing recharge is modeled through the variation in climate,
label: BODY

text: discussed in Section 6.4.9.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: numerous wells (Figure 2-2). The Culebra monitoring wells as of the end of 2002 are shown in
label: BODY

text: Figures 2-3 and 2-4; plugged and abandoned wells are not shown in these figures.  Beginning in
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: long-term rise has been observed in both Culebra and Magenta water levels (Figure 2-36) over a
label: BODY

text: broad area of the WIPP site including Nash Draw (SNL 2003a).  At the time of the CCA this
label: BODY

text: long-term rise was recognized, but was thought (outside of Nash Draw) to represent recovery
label: BODY

text: from the accumulation of hydraulic tests that had occurred since the late 1970s and the effects of
label: BODY

text: grouting around the WIPP shafts to limit leakage.  Water levels in Nash Draw were thought to
label: BODY

text: respond to changes in the volumes of potash mill effluent discharged into the draw (Silva 1996);
label: BODY

text: however, correlation of these water levels with potash mine discharge cannot be proven because
label: BODY

text: sufficient data on the timing and volumes of discharge are not available.  As the rise in water
label: BODY

text: levels has continued since 1996, observed heads have exceeded the ranges of uncertainty
label: BODY

text: established for the steady-state heads in most of the 32 wells used in the calibration of the
label: BODY

text: transmissivity fields described in CCA Appendix TFIELD.  Although recovery from the
label: BODY

text: hydraulic tests and shaft leakage has unquestionably occurred, the DOE has implemented a
label: BODY

text: program to identify other potential causes for the water-level rises (SNL 2003b).
label: BODY

text: Potentiometric surface maps of the freshwater head in the Culebra in December 1998 and
label: BODY

text: December 2002 are shown in Figures 2-37a, 2-37b and 2-37c, respectively.  The maps are
label: BODY

text: generally similar and indicate no changes in flow directions across the WIPP site over that
label: BODY

text: period.  Figure 2-37c shows the changes in heads at the wells monitored in both December 1998
label: BODY

text: and December 2002.  Freshwater heads in most wells increased by 2-4 ft from 1998 to 2002.
label: BODY

text: The largest rise was 4.84 ft at DOE-1.  Only one well, AEC-7, showed a drop over this period (-
label: BODY

text: 0.85 ft) larger than potential measurement error.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Although Culebra heads have been rising, the head distribution in the Culebra (see Figures 2-
label: BODY

text: 37a, 2-37b and 2-37c) is consistent with groundwater basin modeling results (discussed in
label: BODY

text: Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section MASS.14.2) indicating that the generalized direction
label: BODY

text: of groundwater flow remains north to south.  However, caution should be used when making
label: BODY

text: assumptions based on groundwater-level data alone.  Studies in the Culebra have shown that
label: BODY

text: fluid density variations in the Culebra can affect flow direction (Davies 1989, p. 35).  The
label: BODY

text: fractured nature of the Culebra, coupled with variable fluid densities, can also cause localized
label: BODY

text: flow patterns to differ from general flow patterns.  Water-level rises in the vicinity of the H-9
label: BODY

text: hydropad, about 10.46 km (6.5 mi) south of the site, are not thought to be caused by either WIPP
label: BODY

text: activities or potash mining discharge and have been included in the DOE program to investigate
label: BODY

text: Culebra water-level rises in general.  The DOE continues to monitor groundwater levels
label: BODY

text: throughout the region, but only water-level changes at or near the site have the potential to
label: BODY

text: impact the prediction of disposal system performance. The DOE has implemented water-level
label: BODY

text: changes in its conceptual model through variations in climate as discussed in Section 6.4.9.
label: BODY

text: These variations bring the water table to the surface for some calculations. The DOE has also
label: BODY

text: used recent (late 2000) Culebra heads in flow and transport calculations for this recertification
label: BODY

text: application, as discussed in Appendix PA, Attachment TFIELD, Section TFIELD-6.2.
label: BODY

text: Inferences about vertical flow directions in the Culebra have been made from well data collected
label: BODY

text: by the DOE.  Beauheim (1987a) reported flow directions toward the Culebra from both the Los
label: BODY

text: Medaños and the Magenta over the WIPP site, indicating that the Culebra acts as a drain for the
label: BODY

text: units around it.  This indication is consistent with results of groundwater basin modeling.  A
label: BODY

text: more detailed discussion of Culebra flow and transport can be found in Appendix PA,
label: BODY

text: Attachment TFIELD
label: BODY

text: In response to an EPA letter dated March 19, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Item II-I-17), supplemental
label: BODY

text: information to the CCA pertinent to groundwater flow and geochemistry within the Culebra was
label: BODY

text: provided by the DOE in a letter dated May 14, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Item II-I-31).  In that
label: BODY

text: letter, the DOE explained the conceptual model of Culebra groundwater flow used in the CCA.
label: BODY

text: The CCA conceptual model, referred to as the groundwater basin model, offers a three-
label: BODY

text: dimensional approach to treatment of supra-Salado rock units, and assumes that vertical leakage
label: BODY

text: (albeit very slow) occurs between rock units of the Rustler (where hydraulic gradients exist).
label: BODY

text: Flow in the Culebra is considered transient, but is not expected to change significantly over the
label: BODY

text: next 10,000 years. This differs from previous interpretations, wherein no flow was assumed
label: BODY

text: between the Rustler units.
label: BODY

text: In an attachment to the May 14, 1997 letter, the DOE concluded that the presence of anhydrite
label: BODY

text: within the Rustler units did not preclude slow downward infiltration, as previously argued by the
label: BODY

text: DOE, and that the observed geochemistry and flow directions can be explained with different
label: BODY

text: recharge areas and Culebra travel paths.  The EPA reviewed the groundwater flow and recharge
label: BODY

text: conceptualization and concluded that it provides a realistic representation of site conditions.

text: During the CCA review, the EPA found that information on the Culebra in the CCA lacked a
label: BODY

text: detailed discussion on the origin of the transmissivity variations relative to fracture
label: BODY

text: infill/dissolution, integration of climatic change, and loading/unloading events.  These are
label: BODY

text: important aspects to understanding not only current transmissivity differences, but also potential
label: BODY

text: future transmissivity variations that could affect PA calculations.  The EPA’s review stated,
label: BODY

text: however, that the determination of the specific origin of fractures was not necessary because
label: BODY

text: conditions were not expected to change during the regulatory period.

text: The DOE provided supplemental information in letters in 1997 (Docket A-93-02, Items II-I-03,
label: BODY

text: II-I-24, II-I-31, II-H-44, and II-H-46) indicating that dissolution of fracture fill (which has the
label: BODY

text: potential to alter fracture permeability) is unlikely to occur.  The EPA accepted the DOE’s
label: BODY

text: position that infiltrating waters would most likely become saturated with calcium sulfate and
label: BODY

text: consequently would not dissolve anhydrite or gypsum fracture fill.  Further information on the
label: BODY

text: EPA review of anhydrite and gypsum fracture fill dissolution is contained in EPA Technical
label: BODY

text: Support Document for Section 194.14:  Content of Compliance Certification Application,
label: BODY

text: Section IV.C (Docket A-93-02, Item V-B-3).
label: BODY

text: The Sandia National Laboratories Annual Compliance Monitoring Parameter Assessment reports
label: BODY

text: the annual assessment of the Compliance Monitoring Parameters (COMPs) pursuant to the SNL
label: BODY

text: Analysis Plan, AP-069. The first assessment, for calendar year 1998 (SNL 2000a), showed that
label: BODY

text: changes in Culebra water levels were considered minor. During the assessment of the COMP
label: BODY

text: ‘changes in groundwater flow’ for calendar year 2001 (SNL 2002), estimated freshwater Culebra
label: BODY

text: heads in 15 wells were identified as above the ranges of uncertainty estimated for steady-state
label: BODY

text: conditions at those wells.  At 8 of the 15 wells, the measured water levels exceed the uncertainty
label: BODY

text: range before being converted to freshwater head.  In these cases, conversion to freshwater head
label: BODY

text: using any feasible fluid density can only increase the deviation from the range.  The freshwater
label: BODY

text: head values from late 2000 were used to calibrate the Culebra transmissivity (T) fields used to
label: BODY

text: simulate the transport of radionuclides through the Culebra (Appendix PA, Attachment
label: BODY

text: TFIELD).
label: BODY

text: Because transport through the Culebra is a minor component of the total predicted releases from
label: BODY

text: the repository, these changes in head values have little or no effect on the total releases to the
label: BODY

text: accessible environment.  The COMP assessment for the calendar year 2001 concluded that the
label: BODY

text: current head values do not indicate a condition adverse to the predicted performance of the
label: BODY

text: repository.  However, because Culebra water levels are above expected values at most wells,
label: BODY

text: work has been initiated to investigate the reason for the change and further evaluate the impact
label: BODY

text: on performance.
label: BODY

text: Additional background for the Culebra model is in Appendix PA, Attachment TFIELD.
label: BODY

text: Additional information on long-term pumping test data is documented in Meigs et al. (2000) and
label: BODY

text: slug tests and short-term pumping tests are documented in Beauheim et al. (1991b) and
label: BODY

text: Beauheim and Ruskauff (1998).
label: BODY

text: Several new publications on the Culebra updating the original CCA information have been
label: BODY

text: released.  Transport properties and tracer tests of the Culebra performed at the H-11 and H-19
label: BODY

text: hydropads are described in Meigs et al. (2000).  The 1995-96 tracer test program, which
label: BODY

text: consisted of single-well injection-withdrawal tests and multiwell convergent flow tests, is
label: BODY

text: documented in Meigs and Beauheim (2001).  The higher permeability of the lower Culebra has
label: BODY

text: been addressed in Meigs and Beauheim (2001, p. 1116).
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.1.3  Tamarisk
label: BODY

text: The Tamarisk acts as a confining layer in the groundwater basin model.  Attempts were made in
label: BODY

text: two wells, H-14 and H-16, to test a 2.4-m (7.9-ft) sequence of the Tamarisk that consists of
label: BODY

text: claystone, mudstone, and siltstone overlain and underlain by anhydrite.  Permeability was too
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: low to measure in either well within the time allowed for testing; consequently, Beauheim
label: BODY

text: (1987a, pp. 108-110) estimated the transmissivity of the claystone sequence to be one or more
label: BODY

text: orders of magnitude less than that of the tested interval in the Los Medaños (that is, less than
label: BODY

text: approximately 2.7 × 10
label: BODY

text: -11 m2/s [2.5 × 10-5 ft2/day]).  The porosity of the Tamarisk was measured
label: BODY

text: in 1995 as part of testing at the H-19 hydropad (TerraTek 1996).  Two claystone samples had an
label: BODY

text: effective porosity of 21.3 to 21.7 percent.  Five anhydrite samples had effective porosities of 0.2
label: BODY

text: to 1.0 percent.
label: BODY

text: Fluid pressures in the Tamarisk have been measured continuously at well H-16 since 1987.
label: BODY

text: From 1998 through 2002, the pressures increased approximately 20 psi, from 80 to 100 psi (185
label: BODY

text: to 230 ft of water), probably in a continuing recovery response to shaft grouting conducted in
label: BODY

text: 1993 to reduce leakage.  Given the location of the pressure transducer, the elevation of Tamarisk
label: BODY

text: water level has increased from 899 to 913 m amsl (2,950 to 2,995 ft amsl) during this period.
label: BODY

text: Currently, no other wells in the WIPP monitoring network are completed to the Tamarisk.  Thus,
label: BODY

text: H-16 provides the only information on Tamarisk head levels.
label: BODY

text: Similar to the Los Medaños, the Tamarisk includes a mudstone layer (M3/H3) that contains
label: BODY

text: halite in some locations at and around the WIPP site.  This layer is considered to be important
label: BODY

text: because of the effect it has on the spatial distribution of transmissivity of the Culebra as
label: BODY

text: described in Section 2.2.1.4.1.2.  The M3/H3 margin is described in Section 2.1.3.5 and mapped
label: BODY

text: in Figure 2-15.
label: BODY

text: The Tamarisk is incorporated into the conceptual model as discussed in Section 6.4.6.3.  The role
label: BODY

text: of the Tamarisk in the groundwater basin model is in CCA Appendix MASS, Section
label: BODY

text: MASS.14.1.  Tamarisk hydrological model parameters are in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR,
label: BODY

text: Table PAR-25.
label: BODY

text: Magenta
label: BODY

text: The Magenta is a conductive hydrostratigraphic unit about 7.9 m (26 ft) thick at the WIPP.  The
label: BODY

text: Magenta is saturated except near outcrops along Nash Draw, and hydraulic data are available
label: BODY

text: from 22 wells including 7 wells recompleted to the Magenta between 1995 and 2002 (SNL
label: BODY

text: 2003a).  According to Mercer (CCA Appendix HYDRO, p. 65), transmissivity ranges over five
label: BODY

text: orders of magnitude from 1 × 10-9 to 4 × 10-4 m2/s (4 × 10-3 to 3.75 × 102 ft2/day ).  A slug test
label: BODY

text: performed in H-9c, a recompleted Magenta well (see Figure 2-5 for well location), yielded a
label: BODY

text: transmissivity of 6 × 10-7 m2/s (0.56 ft2/day), which is consistent with Mercer’s findings (SNL
label: BODY

text: 2003a).  The porosity of the Magenta was measured in 1995 as part of testing at the H-19
label: BODY

text: hydropad (TerraTek 1996).  Four samples had effective porosities ranging from 2.7 to 25.2
label: BODY

text: percent.
label: BODY

text: The hydraulic transmissivities of the Magenta, based on sparse data, show a decrease from west
label: BODY

text: to east, with slight indentations of the contours north and south of the WIPP that correspond to
label: BODY

text: the topographic expression of Nash Draw.  In most locations, the hydraulic conductivity of the
label: BODY

text: Magenta is one to two orders of magnitude less than that of the Culebra.  The Magenta does not
label: BODY

text: have hydraulically significant fractures in the vicinity of the WIPP.  Treatment of the Magenta in
label: BODY

text: the model is discussed in Section 6.4.6.4 with modeling parameters in Table 6-24.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Based on Magenta water levels measured in the 1980s (Lappin et al. 1989) when a wide network
label: BODY

text: of Magenta monitoring wells existed, the hydraulic gradient in the Magenta across the site varies
label: BODY

text: from 3 to 4 m/km (16 to 20 ft/mi) on the eastern side, steepening to about 6 m/km (32 ft/mi)
label: BODY

text: along the western side near Nash Draw (Figure 2-38).
label: BODY

text: Regional modeling using the groundwater basin model indicates that leakage occurs into the
label: BODY

text: Magenta from the overlying Forty-niner and out of the Magenta downward into the Tamarisk.
label: BODY

text: Regional modeling also indicates that flow directions in the Magenta are dominantly westward,
label: BODY

text: similar to the slope of the land surface in the immediate area of the WIPP.  This flow direction is
label: BODY

text: different than the dominant flow direction in the next underlying conductive unit, the Culebra.
label: BODY

text: This difference is consistent with the groundwater basin conceptual model, in that flow in
label: BODY

text: shallower units is expected to be more sensitive to local topography.
label: BODY

text: Inferences about vertical flow directions in the Magenta have been made from well data
label: BODY

text: collected by the DOE.  Beauheim (1987a, p. 137) reported flow directions downwards out of the
label: BODY

text: Magenta over the WIPP site, consistent with results of groundwater basin modeling.
label: BODY

text: However, Beauheim (1987a, p. 139) concluded that flow directions between the Forty-niner and
label: BODY

text: Magenta would be upward in the three boreholes from which reliable pressure data are available
label: BODY

text: for the Forty-niner (H-3, H-14, and H-16), which is not consistent with the results of
label: BODY

text: groundwater modeling.  This inconsistency may be the result of local heterogeneity in rock
label: BODY

text: properties that affect flow on a scale that cannot be duplicated in regional modeling.
label: BODY

text: As is the case for the Culebra, groundwater elevations in the Magenta have changed over the
label: BODY

text: period of observation.  The pattern of changes is similar to that observed for the Culebra (see
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.1.4.1.2), and is being investigated under the current DOE hydrology program (SNL
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.1.5  Forty-niner
label: BODY

text: The Forty-niner is a confining hydrostratigraphic layer about 20 m (66 ft) thick throughout the
label: BODY

text: WIPP area and consists of low-permeability anhydrite and siltstone.  Tests by Beauheim (1987a,
label: BODY

text: 119-123 and Table 5-2) in H-14 and H-16 yielded transmissivities of about 3 × 10-8 to 8 × 10-8
label: BODY

text: respectively, for the medial siltstone unit of the Forty-niner.  Tests of the siltstone in H-3d
label: BODY

text: provided transmissivity estimates of 3.8 × 10-9 to 4.8 × 10-9 m2/s (3.5 × 10-3 to 4.5 ×10-3 ft2/day)
label: BODY

text: (Beauheim et al. 1991b, Table 5-1).  The porosity of the Forty-niner was measured as part of
label: BODY

text: testing at the H-19 hydropad (TerraTek 1996).  Three claystone samples had effective porosities
label: BODY

text: ranging from 9.1 to 24.0 percent.  Four anhydrite samples had effective porosities ranging from
label: BODY

text: 0.0 to 0.4 percent.  Model consideration of the Forty-niner is in Section 6.4.6.5.  Modeling
label: BODY

text: parameters are in CCA Appendix PAR, Table PAR-27.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Fluid pressures in the Forty-niner have been measured continuously at well H-16, approximately
label: BODY

text: 13.9 m (45.6 ft) from the well of the AIS, since 1987.  The pressures cycle in a sinusoidal
label: BODY

text: fashion on an annual basis.  These cycles correlate with cycles observed in rock bolt loads in the
label: BODY

text: WIPP shafts (DOE 2002c), and presumably reflect seasonal temperature changes causing the
label: BODY

text: rock around the shafts to expand and contract. From 1998 through 2002, the pressures have
label: BODY

text: cycled between 40 and 70 psi (90 and 160 ft of fresh water).  Given the location of the pressure
label: BODY

text: transducer, the elevation of Forty-niner water level has varied between 899 to 920 m (2,950 to
label: BODY

text: 3,020 ft) amsl during this period.  Through April 2002, Forty-niner water levels were also
label: BODY

text: measured monthly at H-3d as part of the WIPP groundwater monitoring program.  Measurements
label: BODY

text: were discontinued after April 2002 because of an obstruction in the well.  The April 2002 Forty-
label: BODY

text: niner water level elevation determined at H-3d was 942 m (3,092 ft) amsl.  Differences in Forty-
label: BODY

text: niner water levels at H-16 and H-3d are probably due, in part, to differences in the densities of
label: BODY

text: the fluids in the wells.  No other wells in the WIPP monitoring network are completed to the
label: BODY

text: Forty-niner.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.2  Hydrology of the Dewey Lake and the Santa Rosa
label: BODY

text: The Dewey Lake and the Santa Rosa, and surficial soils, overlie the Rustler and are the
label: BODY

text: uppermost hydrostratigraphic units considered by the DOE.  The Dewey Lake and overlying
label: BODY

text: rocks are more permeable than the anhydrites at the top of the Rustler.  Consequently, basin
label: BODY

text: modeling indicates that most (probably more than 70 percent) of the water that recharges the
label: BODY

text: groundwater basin (that is, percolates into the Dewey Lake from surface water) flows only in the
label: BODY

text: rocks above the Rustler.  As modeled, the rest leaks vertically through the upper anhydrites of
label: BODY

text: the Rustler and into the Magenta or continues downward to the Culebra.  More flow occurs into
label: BODY

text: the Rustler units at times of greater recharge.  Even though it carries most of the modeled
label: BODY

text: recharge, lateral flow in the Dewey Lake is slow because of its low permeability in most areas.
label: BODY

text: A saturated, perched-water zone has been identified in the lower Santa Rosa directly below the
label: BODY

text: operational area of the WIPP (DOE 1999; INTERA 1997a; INTERA 1997b; DES 1997).  The
label: BODY

text: zone occurred at a location that previously had been dry or only partially saturated.  Details are
label: BODY

text: provided in Appendix DATA and a summary provided in Section 2.2.1.4.2.2.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.4.2.1  Dewey Lake
label: BODY

text: The Dewey Lake contains a productive zone of saturation, probably under water-table
label: BODY

text: conditions, in the southwestern to south-central portion of the WIPP site and south of the site.
label: BODY

text: Several wells operated by the J.C. Mills Ranch south of the WIPP site produce sufficient
label: BODY

text: quantities of water from the Dewey Lake to supply livestock.  Short-term production rates of 5.7
label: BODY

text: to 6.8 m3/hr (25 to 30 gpm) were observed in boreholes P-9 (Jones 1978, Vol. 1., pp. 167- 168),
label: BODY

text: WQSP-6, and WQSP-6a (see CCA Appendix USDW).  Based on a single hydraulic test
label: BODY

text: conducted at WQSP-6a (Figure 2-6), Beauheim and Ruskauff (1998) estimated the transmissivity
label: BODY

text: of a 7.3m (24ft) fractured section of the Dewey Lake at 3.9 × 10-4 m2/s (360 ft2/day).  The
label: BODY

text: productive zone is typically found in the middle of the Dewey Lake, 55 to 81 m (180 to 265 ft)
label: BODY

text: below ground surface and appears to derive much of its transmissivity from open fractures.
label: BODY

text: Where present, the saturated zone may be perched or simply underlain by less transmissive rock.
label: BODY

text: Fractures below the productive zone tend to be completely filled with gypsum.  Open fractures
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Under the groundwater monitoring program (Appendix MON-2004), water levels are measured
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: water levels at H-3d have risen about 0.3 m/yr (1 ft/yr).  Future changes in the Dewey Lake
label: BODY

text: water table due to wetter conditions are part of the conceptual model discussed in Sections 6.4.6
label: BODY

text: Similar to the six Culebra WQSP wells (WQSP-1 through WQSP-6), Dewey Lake water quality
label: BODY

text: is determined semiannually at WQSP-6a.  Baseline concentrations for major ion species have
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Powers (1997) suggests that what distinguishes the low-transmissivity lower Dewey Lake from
label: BODY

text: the high-transmissivity upper Dewey Lake is a change in natural cements from carbonate (above)
label: BODY

text: to sulfate (below).  Resistivity logs correlate with this cement change and show a drop in
label: BODY

text: porosity across the cement-change boundary.  Similarly, porosity measurements made on eight
label: BODY

text: core samples from the Dewey Lake from well H-19b4 showed a range from 14.9 to 24.8 percent
label: BODY

text: for the four samples from above the cement change, and a range from 3.5 to 11.6 percent for the
label: BODY

text: four samples from below the cement change (TerraTek 1996).  In the vicinity of the surface
label: BODY

text: structures area of the WIPP, Powers (1997) proposed the surface of the cement change is at a
label: BODY

text: depth of approximately 50 to 55 m (165 to 180 ft), is irregular, and trends downward
label: BODY

text: stratigraphically to the south and west of the site center.
label: BODY

text: During site characterization and initial construction of the WIPP shafts, the Dewey Lake did not
label: BODY

text: produce water within the WIPP shafts or in boreholes in the immediate vicinity of the panels.
label: BODY

text: However, since 1995, water has been observed leaking into the exhaust shaft at a depth of
label: BODY

text: approximately 24.4 m (80 ft) at the location of the Dewey Lake/ Santa Rosa contact (Docket A-
label: BODY

text: 93-02, Item number 11-1-07, 1999; INTERA 1997a; INTERA 1997b).  As described below in
label: BODY

text: Section 2.2.1.4.2.2, the water is interpreted to be from an anthropogenic source, including
label: BODY

text: infiltration from WIPP rainfall-runoff retention ponds and the WIPP salt storage area and
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: evaporation pond located at the surface.  At the site center, thin cemented zones in the upper
label: BODY

text: Dewey Lake retard, at least temporarily, downward infiltration of modern waters.
label: BODY

text: Saturation of the uppermost Dewey Lake was observed for the first time in 2001 as well C-2737
label: BODY

text: was being drilled (Powers 2002c).  Well C-2811 was then installed nearby to monitor this zone
label: BODY

text: (Powers and Stensrud 2003).  Because of the proximity of these two wells to the WIPP surface
label: BODY

text: structures area, and the absence of water at this horizon when earlier wells were drilled, the
label: BODY

text: saturation is assumed to be an extension of the anthropogenic waters described in the following
label: BODY

text: section.
label: BODY

text: For modeling purposes, the hydraulic conductivity of the Dewey Lake, assuming saturation, is
label: BODY

text: estimated to be 10-8 m/sec (3 × 10-3 ft/day), corresponding to the hydraulic conductivity of fine-
label: BODY

text: grained sandstone and siltstone (Davies 1989, p. 110).
label: BODY

text: The Dewey Lake is the uppermost important layer in the hydrological model.  Its treatment is
label: BODY

text: discussed in Section 6.4.6.6 and Appendix PA, Attachment MASS, Section MASS.14.2.  Model
label: BODY

text: parameters are in Table 6-25 and in Appendix PA, Attachment PAR, Table PAR-22.

text: 2.2.1.4.2.2  Santa Rosa
label: BODY

text: The Santa Rosa ranges from 0 to 91 m (0 to about 300 ft) thick and is present over the eastern
label: BODY

text: half of the WIPP site.  It is absent over the western portion of the site.  It crops out northeast of
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw.  The Santa Rosa near the WIPP site may have a naturalwater-saturated thickness of
label: BODY

text: limited extent.  It has a porosity of about 13 percent and a specific capacity of 0.029 to 0.041
label: BODY

text: L/s/m (0.14 to 0.20 gallons per minute per foot (gpm/ft) of drawdown, where it yields water in
label: BODY

text: the WIPP region.
label: BODY

text: In May 1995, a scheduled inspection of the WIPP exhaust shaft revealed water emanating from
label: BODY

text: cracks in the concrete liner at a depth of approximately 24.4 m (80 ft) below the shaft collar.
label: BODY

text: Because little or no groundwater had been encountered at this depth interval previously (Bechtel
label: BODY

text: 1979; DOE 1983; Holt and Powers 1984, 1986), the DOE implemented a program in early 1996
label: BODY

text: to investigate the source and extent of the water.  The program included installation of wells and
label: BODY

text: piezometers, hydraulic testing (pumping tests), water-quality sampling and analysis, and water-
label: BODY

text: level and precipitation monitoring (Docket A-93-02, Item number 11-1-07, DOE 1999; INTERA
label: BODY

text: 1997a; DES 1997; INTERA 1997b).
label: BODY

text: In the initial phases of the investigation, three wells (C-2505, C-2506, and C-2507) and 12
label: BODY

text: piezometers (PZ-1 through PZ-12) were installed within the surface structures area of the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site (Figure 2-39).  The three wells were located near the exhaust shaft and completed to the
label: BODY

text: Santa Rosa/Dewey Lake contact (approximately 15 m [50 ft] below ground surface).  Similarly,
label: BODY

text: the piezometers were also completed to the Santa Rosa/Dewey Lake contact (approximately 16
label: BODY

text: to 23 m [55 to 75 ft] below ground surface).  All wells and piezometers, with the exception of
label: BODY

text: PZ-8, encountered a saturated zone just above the Santa Rosa/Dewey Lake contact, but water did
label: BODY

text: not appear to have percolated significantly into the Dewey Lake.  PZ-8, the piezometer located
label: BODY

text: farthest to the east in the study area, was a dry hole.
label: BODY

text: Subsequent to the well and piezometer installations, water-level, water-quality, and rainfall data
label: BODY

text: were collected.  In addition, hydraulic tests were performed to estimate hydrologic properties and
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: water production rates.  These data suggest that the water present in the Santa Rosa below the
label: BODY

text: WIPP surface structures area represents an unconfined, water-bearing horizon perched on top of
label: BODY

text: the Dewey Lake (DES 1997).  Pressure data collected from instruments located in the exhaust
label: BODY

text: shaft show no apparent hydrologic communication between the Santa Rosa and other formations
label: BODY

text: located stratigraphically below the Santa Rosa.
label: BODY

text: A water-level-surface map of the Santa Rosa in the vicinity of the WIPPsurface structures area
label: BODY

text: indicates that a potentiometric high is located near the salt water evaporation pond and PZ-7
label: BODY

text: (Figure 2-40).  The water level at PZ-7 is approximately 1 m (3.3 ft) higher than the water levels
label: BODY

text: in any other wells or piezometers.  Water is presumed to move radially from this potentiometric
label: BODY

text: high.  The areal extent of the water is larger than the 80-acre investigative area shown in Figure
label: BODY

text: 2-39 (DES 1997) as evidenced by drilling records of C-2737 (Powers 2002c) located outside of
label: BODY

text: and south of the WIPP surface structures area that indicate a Santa Rosa/Dewey Lake perched-
label: BODY

text: water horizon at a depth of approximately 18 m (60 ft). The study of this water is ongoing.
label: BODY

text: Water-quality data for the perched Santa Rosa waters are highly variable and appear to be
label: BODY

text: dominated by two anthropogenic sources:  (1) runoff of rainfall into and infiltration from the
label: BODY

text: retention ponds located to the south of the WIPP surface facilities, and (2) infiltration of saline
label: BODY

text: waters from the salt storage area, the salt storage evaporation pond, and perhaps remnants of the
label: BODY

text: drilling and tailings pit used during the construction of the WIPP salt shaft.  The total dissolved
label: BODY

text: solids (TDS) in the perched water range from less than 3,000 mg/L at PZ-10 to more than
label: BODY

text: 160,000 mg/L at PZ-3 (DES 1997).  Concentration contours are known to shift with time.  For
label: BODY

text: example, the high-TDS zone centered at PZ-3 moved observably to the northeast toward PZ-9
label: BODY

text: between February 1997 and October 2000 (DOE 2002b).
label: BODY

text: Hydraulic tests (Docket A-93-02, Item number 11-1-07, DOE; INTERA 1997a; DES 1997)
label: BODY

text: conducted in the three wells and 12 piezometers indicate that the Santa Rosa behaves as a low-
label: BODY

text: permeability, unconfined aquifer perched on the Dewey Lake.  Hydraulic conductivity ranges
label: BODY

text: from 2.6  × 10-8 to 5.5 × 10-5 m/s (7.4 × 10-3 to 16 ft/day).  The wells are capable of producing at
label: BODY

text: rates of about 0.3 to 1.0 gpm.  The estimated storativity value for the Santa Rosa is 1 × 10-2.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.5 Hydrology of Other Groundwater Zones of Regional Importance
label: BODY

text: The groundwater regimes in the Capitan Limestone, which is generally regarded as the northern
label: BODY

text: boundary of the Delaware Basin, and Nash Draw have been evaluated by the DOE as part of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP project because of their importance in some processes, notably dissolution features, that
label: BODY

text: the DOE has determined to be of low probability at the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: 2.2.1.5.1  Capitan Limestone
label: BODY

text: The Capitan Limestone (hereafter referred to as the Capitan), which outcrops in the southern end
label: BODY

text: of the Guadalupe Mountains, is a massive limestone unit that grades basinward into recemented,
label: BODY

text: partly dolomitized reef breccia and shelfward into bedded carbonates and evaporites.  A deeply
label: BODY

text: incised submarine canyon near the Eddy-Lea county line has been identified (Hiss 1976).  This
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

label: HH2

text: C-2505) and Piezometers (e.g., PZ-1) (after INTERA 1997)

label: BODY

text: canyon is filled with sediments of lower permeability than the Capitan and, according to Hiss
label: BODY

text: (1975 p. 199), restricts fluid flow.  The hydraulic conductivity of the Capitan ranges from 3 ×
label: BODY

text: 10-6 to 9 × 10-5 m/s (1 to 25 ft/day) in southern Lea County and is 1.7 × 10-5 m/s (5 ft/day) east
label: BODY

text: of the Pecos River at Carlsbad (CCA Appendix HYDRO, p. 34).  Hiss (1975, p. 199) reported in
label: BODY

text: 1975 that average transmissivities around the northern and eastern margins of the Delaware
label: BODY

text: Basin are 0.01 m2/s (10,000 ft2/day) in thick sections and 5.4 × 10-4 m2/s (500 ft2/day) in incised
label: BODY

text: submarine canyons.  Water table conditions are found in the Capitan aquifer southwest of the
label: BODY

text: Pecos River at Carlsbad; however, artesian conditions exist to the north and east. The hydraulic
label: BODY

text: gradient to the southeast of the submarine canyon near the Eddy-Lea county line has been
label: BODY

text: affected by large oil field withdrawals.  The Capitan is recharged by percolation through the
label: BODY

text: northern shelf aquifers, by flow from the south and west from underlying basin aquifers (see
label: BODY

text: information on the Bell Canyon, Section 2.2.1.2.1), and by direct infiltration at its outcrop in the
label: BODY

text: Guadalupe Mountains.  The Capitan is important in the regional hydrology because breccia pipes
label: BODY

text: in the Salado have formed over it, most likely in response to the effects of dissolution by
label: BODY

text: groundwater flowing in the Castile along the base of the Salado.  See CCA Appendix DEF,
label: BODY

text: Section DEF.3.1 for a more thorough discussion of breccia pipe formation.

text: 2.2.1.5.2  Hydrology of the Rustler-Salado Contact Zone in Nash Draw
label: BODY

text: As discussed in Sections 2.1.3.4 and 2.1.6.2.1, in Nash Draw the contact between the Rustler and
label: BODY

text: the Salado is an unstructured residuum of gypsum, clay, and sandstone created by the dissolution
label: BODY

text: of halite and has been known as the brine aquifer, Rustler-Salado residuum, and residuum.  The
label: BODY

text: residuum is absent under the WIPP site.  It is clear that dissolution in Nash Draw occurred after
label: BODY

text: deposition of the Rustler (see CCA Appendix DEF, Section DEF.3.2 for a discussion of lateral
label: BODY

text: dissolution of the Rustler-Salado contact).  As described previously, the topographic low formed
label: BODY

text: by Nash Draw is a groundwater divide in the groundwater basin conceptual model of the units
label: BODY

text: above the Salado.  The brine aquifer is shown in Figure 2-41.
label: BODY

text: Robinson and Lang (1938) described the brine aquifer (Section 2.1.3.4) and suggested that the
label: BODY

text: structural conditions that caused the development of Nash Draw might control the occurrence of
label: BODY

text: the brine; thus, the brine aquifer boundary may coincide with the topographic surface expression
label: BODY

text: of Nash Draw, as shown in Figure 2-33.  Their studies show brine concentrated along a strip
label: BODY

text: from 3.3 to 13 km (2 to 8 mi) wide and about 43 km (26 mi) long.  Data from the test holes that
label: BODY

text: Robinson and Lang (1938) drilled indicate that the residuum (containing the brine) ranges in
label: BODY

text: thickness from 3 to 18 m (10.5 to 60 ft) and averages about 24 feet (7 meters).
label: BODY

text: Hydraulic properties were determined by Hale et al. (1954) primarily for the area between
label: BODY

text: Malaga Bend on the Pecos River and Laguna Grande de la Sal.  They calculated a transmissivity
label: BODY

text: value of 8.6 × 10-3 m2/s (8,000 ft2/day) and estimated the potentiometric gradient to be
label: BODY

text: 0.27 m/km (1.4 ft/mi).  In this area, the Rustler-Salado residuum apparently is part of a
label: BODY

text: continuous hydrologic system, as evidenced by the coincident fluctuation of water levels in the
label: BODY

text: test holes (as far away as Laguna Grande de la Sal) with pumping rates in irrigation wells along
label: BODY

text: the Pecos River.
label: BODY

text: In the northern half of Nash Draw, the approximate outline of the brine aquifer as described by
label: BODY

text: Robinson and Lang (1938) has been supported by drilling associated with the WIPP
label: BODY

text: hydrogeologic studies.  These studies also indicate that the main differences in areal extent occur
label: BODY

text: along the eastern side where the boundary is very irregular and, in places (test holes P-14 and H-
label: BODY

text: 07), extends farther east than previously indicated by Robinson and Lang (1938).
label: BODY

text: Other differences from the earlier studies include the variability in thickness of residuum present
label: BODY

text: in test holes WIPP-25 through WIPP-29.  These holes indicate thicknesses ranging from 3.3 m
label: BODY

text: (11 ft) in WIPP-25 to 33 m (108 ft) in WIPP-29 in Nash Draw, compared to 2.4 m (8 ft) in test
label: BODY

text: hole P-14, east of Nash Draw.  The specific geohydrologic mechanism that has caused
label: BODY

text: dissolution to be greater in one area than in another is not apparent, although a general increase
label: BODY

text: in chloride concentration in water from the north to the south may indicate the effects of
label: BODY

text: movement down the natural hydraulic gradient in Nash Draw.
label: BODY

text: The average hydraulic gradient within the residuum in Nash Draw is about 1.9 m/km (10 ft/mi);
label: BODY

text: in contrast, the average gradient at the WIPP site is 7.4 m/km (39 ft/mi) (CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: HYDRO, p. 50).  This difference reflects the changes in transmissivity, which are as much as
label: BODY

text: five orders of magnitude greater in Nash Draw.  The transmissivity determined from aquifer tests
label: BODY

text: in test holes completed in the Rustler-Salado contact residuum of Nash Draw ranges from
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 2.1 × 10-10 m2/s (2 × 10-4 ft2/day) at WIPP-27 to 8.6 × 10-6 m2/s (9 8 ft2/day) at WIPP-29.  This
label: BODY

text: is in contrast to the WIPP site proper, where transmissivities range from 3.2 × 10
label: BODY

text: (3 × 10-5 ft2/day) at test holes P-18 and H-5c to 5.4 × 10-8 m2/s (5 × 10-2 ft2/day) at test hole P-
label: BODY

text: 14 (CCA Appendix HYDRO, p. 50).  Locations and estimated hydraulic heads of these wells
label: BODY

text: based on water-level measurements made in the 1980s (Lappin et al. 1989) are illustrated in
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-42.
label: BODY

text: Hale et al. (1954) believed the Rustler-Salado contact residuum discharges to the alluvium near
label: BODY

text: Malaga Bend on the Pecos River.  Because the confining beds in this area are probably fractured
label: BODY

text: because of dissolution and collapse of the evaporites, the brine (under artesian head) moves up
label: BODY

text: through these fractures into the overlying alluvium and then discharges into the Pecos River.
label: BODY

text: According to CCA Appendix HYDRO, p. 55, water in the Rustler-Salado contact residuum in
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw contains the largest concentrations of dissolved solids in the WIPP area, ranging
label: BODY

text: from 41,500 mg/L in borehole H-1 to 412,000 mg/L in borehole H-5c.  These waters are
label: BODY

text: classified as brines.  The dissolved mineral constituents in the brine consist mostly of sulfates
label: BODY

text: and chlorides of calcium, magnesium, sodium, and potassium; the major constituents are sodium
label: BODY

text: and chloride.  Concentrations of the other major ions vary according to the spatial location of the
label: BODY

text: sample, are probably directly related to the interaction of the brine and the host rocks, and reflect
label: BODY

text: residence time within the rocks.  Residence time of the brine depends upon the transmissivity of
label: BODY

text: the rock.  For example, the presence of large concentrations of potassium and magnesium in
label: BODY

text: water is correlated with minimal permeability and a relatively undeveloped flow system.
label: BODY

text: The EPA’s initial review of the CCA found the discussion of the Rustler/Salado contact to
label: BODY

text: require clarification, particularly with respect to the possibility of the continued development and
label: BODY

text: characteristics of a dissolution front along this contact, and the impact that continued dissolution
label: BODY

text: within the brine aquifer residuum would have on the overlying units of the Rustler.  The DOE
label: BODY

text: discussed the rate and extent of dissolution processes further in supplemental information
label: BODY

text: provided in a letter dated June 13, 1997 (Docket A-93-02, II-H-44).  Based upon this
label: BODY

text: information, the EPA concluded that, while dissolution may occur along the Rustler/Salado
label: BODY

text: contact, it would not affect the WIPP’s containment capabilities during the regulatory time
label: BODY

text: period.  Further discussion of this topic is contained in EPA Technical Support Document for
label: BODY

text: Section 194.14:  Content of Compliance Certification Application, Section IV.C.3 (Docket A-93-
label: BODY

text: 02, Item V-B-3).

text: 2.2.2 Surface-Water Hydrology
label: HH2

text: The WIPP site is in the Pecos River basin, which contains about 50 percent of the drainage area
label: BODY

text: of the Rio Grande Water Resources Region.  The Pecos River headwaters are northeast of Santa
label: BODY

text: Fe, and the river flows to the south through eastern New Mexico and western Texas to the Rio
label: BODY

text: Grande.  The Pecos River has an overall length of about 805 km (500 mi), a maximum basin
label: BODY

text: width of about 209 km (130 mi), and a drainage area of about 115,301 km2 (44,535 mi2). (About
label: BODY

text: 53,075 km2 [20,500 mi2] contained within the basin have no external surface drainage and their
label: BODY

text: surface waters do not contribute to Pecos River flows.)  Figure 2-43 shows the Pecos River
label: BODY

text: drainage area.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231

label: BODY

text: The Pecos River generally flows year-round, except in the reach below Anton Chico where the
label: BODY

text: low flows percolate into the stream bed.  The main stem of the Pecos River and its major
label: BODY

text: tributaries have low flows, and the tributary streams are frequently dry.  About 75 percent of the
label: BODY

text: total annual precipitation and 60 percent of the annual flow result from intense local
label: BODY

text: thunderstorms between April and September.
label: BODY

text: There are no perennial streams at the WIPP site.  At its nearest point, the Pecos River is about 19
label: BODY

text: km (12 mi) southwest of the WIPP site boundary.  A few small creeks and draws are the only
label: BODY

text: westward flowing tributaries of the Pecos River within 32 km (20 mi) north or south of the site.
label: BODY

text: Nash Draw, the largest surface drainage feature east of the Pecos River in the WIPP region, is a
label: BODY

text: closed depression and does not provide surface flow into the Pecos.  Potash mining operations in
label: BODY

text: and near Nash Draw likely contribute to the flow in Nash Draw.  For example, the Mississippi
label: BODY

text: Potash Inc. East operation located 11 to 13 km (7 to 8 mi) due north of the WIPP site disposes of
label: BODY

text: mine tailings and refining-process effluent on its property and has done so since 1965.  Records
label: BODY

text: obtained from the New Mexico Office of the State Engineer show that since 1973, an average of
label: BODY

text: 3 × 106 m3 (2,400 acre-feet [ac-ft]) of water per year has been pumped from local aquifers
label: BODY

text: (Ogallala and Capitan) for use in the potash-refining process at that location (SNL 2003b).
label: BODY

text: Based on knowledge of the potash refining process, approximately 90 percent of the pumped
label: BODY

text: water is estimated to be discharged to the tailings pile.  Geohydrology Associates (1978)
label: BODY

text: estimated that approximately half of the brine discharged onto potash tailings piles in Nash Draw
label: BODY

text: seeps into the ground annually, while the remainder evaporates.  The Black River (drainage area:
label: BODY

text: 1,035 km2 [400 mi2]) joins the Pecos from the west about 25 km (16 mi) southwest of the site.
label: BODY

text: The Delaware River (drainage area: 1,812 km2 [700 mi2]) and a number of small creeks and
label: BODY

text: draws also join the Pecos River along this reach.  The flow in the Pecos River below Fort
label: BODY

text: Sumner is regulated by storage in Sumner Lake, Brantley Reservoir, Lake Avalon, and several
label: BODY

text: other smaller irrigation dams.
label: BODY

text: Five major reservoirs are located on the Pecos River: Santa Rosa Lake, Sumner Lake, Brantley
label: BODY

text: Reservoir, Lake Avalon, and the Red Bluff Reservoir, the last located just over the border in
label: BODY

text: Texas (Figure 2-43).  The storage capacities of these reservoirs and the Two Rivers Reservoir in
label: BODY

text: the Pecos River Basin are shown in Table 2-10.
label: BODY

text: With regard to surface drainage onto and off of the WIPP site, there are no major natural lakes or
label: BODY

text: ponds within 8 km (5 mi) of the site.  Laguna Gatuña, Laguna Tonto, Laguna Plata, and Laguna
label: BODY

text: Toston are playas more than 16 km (10 mi) north and are at elevations of 1,050 m (3,450 ft) or
label: BODY

text: higher.  Thus, surface runoff from the site (elevation 1,010 m [3,310 ft] above sea level) would
label: BODY

text: not flow toward any of them.  To the northwest, west, and southwest, Red Lake, Lindsey Lake,
label: BODY

text: and Laguna Grande de la Sal are more than 8 km (5 mi) from the site, at elevations of 914 to
label: BODY

text: 1,006 m (3,000 to 3,300 ft).  A low-flow investigation has been initiated by the USGS within the
label: BODY

text: Hill Tank Draw drainage area, the most prominent drainage feature near the WIPP site.  The
label: BODY

text: drainage area is about 10.3 km2 (4 mi2), with an average channel slope of 1 to 100, and the
label: BODY

text: drainage is westward into Nash Draw.  Two years of observations showed only four flow events.
label: BODY

text: The USGS estimates that the flow rate for these events was under 0.057 m3/s (2 ft3/s) (DOE
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: and the mean annual runoff is 2.5 to 5 mm (0.1 to 0.2 in.).  The maximum recorded 24-hour

text: precipitation at Carlsbad was 130 mm (5.12 in.) in August 1916.  The predicted maximum 6-
label: BODY

text: hour, 100-year precipitation event for the site is 91 mm (3.6 in.) and is most likely to occur
label: BODY

text: during the summer.  The maximum recorded daily snowfall at Carlsbad was 254 mm (10 in.) in
label: BODY

text: December 1923.
label: BODY

text: The maximum recorded flood on the Pecos River occurred near the town of Malaga, New
label: BODY

text: Mexico, on August 23, 1966, with a discharge of 3,396 m3 (120,000 ft3) per second and a stage
label: BODY

text: elevation of about 895 m (2,938 ft) amsl.  The minimum surface elevation at the WIPP is over 91
label: BODY

text: m (300 ft) above the elevation of this maximum historic flood (DOE 1980, Section 7.4.1).
label: BODY

text: As discussed in the FEIS (DOE 1980, pp. 7- 71), more than 90 percent of the mean annual
label: BODY

text: precipitation at the site is lost by evapotranspiration.  On a mean monthly basis,
label: BODY

text: evapotranspiration at the site greatly exceeds the available rainfall; however, intense local
label: BODY

text: thunderstorms may produce runoff and percolation.
label: BODY

text: Water quality in the Pecos River basin is affected by mineral pollution from natural sources and
label: BODY

text: from irrigation return flows (see Section 2.4.2.2 for discussion of surface-water quality).  At
label: BODY

text: Santa Rosa, New Mexico, the average suspended-sediment discharge of the river is about 1,497
label: BODY

text: metric tons/day (1,650 tons/day).  Large amounts of chlorides from Salt Creek and Bitter Creek
label: BODY

text: enter the river near Roswell.  River inflow in the Hagerman area contributes increased amounts
label: BODY

text: of calcium, magnesium, and sulfate; and waters entering the river near Lake Arthur are high in
label: BODY

text: chloride.  Below Brantley Reservoir, springs flowing into the river are usually submerged and
label: BODY

text: difficult to sample; springs that could be sampled had TDS concentrations of 3,350 to
label: BODY

text: 4,000 mg/L.  Concentrated brine entering at Malaga Bend adds an estimated 64 metric tons/day
label: BODY

text: (370 tons/day) of chloride to the Pecos River (CCA Appendix GCR, pp. 6-7).

text: 2.3 Resources
label: HH2

text: At the outset of the repository program, the DOE understood the importance of resources in the
label: BODY

text: vicinity of a disposal system.  Several of the siting criteria emphasized avoidance of resources
label: BODY

text: that would impact the performance of the disposal system.  In this regard, the DOE selected a
label: BODY

text: site that (1) maximized the use of federal lands, (2) avoided known oil and gas trends, (3)
label: BODY

text: minimized the impacts on potash deposits, and (4) avoided existing drill holes.  While the DOE
label: BODY

text: could not meet all these criteria totally, it is shown that the favorable characteristics of the
label: BODY

text: location compensate for any increased risks due to the presence of resources.  Consequently, the
label: BODY

text: DOE has prepared this section to discuss resources that may exist at or beneath the WIPP site.
label: BODY

text: The topic of resources is used to broadly define both economic (mineral and nonmineral) and
label: BODY

text: cultural resources associated with the WIPP site.  These resources are important because they
label: BODY

text: (1) provide evidence of past uses of the area and (2) indicate potential future use of the area with
label: BODY

text: the possibility that such use could lead to disruption of the closed repository.  Because of the
label: BODY

text: depth of the disposal horizon, it is believed that only the mineral resources are of significance in
label: BODY

text: predicting the long-term performance of the disposal system.  However, the nonmineral and
label: BODY

text: cultural resources are presented for completeness because they are included in the FEP screening
label: BODY

text: discussions in Chapter 6 and Appendix PA, Attachment SCR.  Information needed to make
label: BODY

text: screening decisions includes natural resource distributions, including potable groundwaters, the
label: BODY

text: distribution of drillholes, mines, excavations, and other man-made features that exploit these
label: BODY

text: resources, the distribution of drillholes and excavation used for disposal or injection purposes,
label: BODY

text: activities that significantly alter the land surface, agricultural activities that may affect the
label: BODY

text: disposal system, archaeological resources requiring deep excavation to exploit, and technological
label: BODY

text: changes that may alter local demographics.  This information is presented here or is referenced.
label: BODY

text: With respect to minerals or hydrocarbons, reserves are the portion of resources that are economic
label: BODY

text: at today’s market prices and with existing technology.  For hydrocarbons, proved (proven)
label: BODY

text: reserves are an estimated quantity that engineering and geologic data analysis demonstrates, with
label: BODY

text: reasonable certainty, is recoverable in the future from discovered oil and gas pools.  Probable
label: BODY

text: resources (extensions) consist of oil and gas in pools that have been discovered but not yet
label: BODY

text: developed by drilling.  Their presence and distribution can generally be surmised with a high
label: BODY

text: degree of confidence.  Probable resources (new pools) consist of oil and gas surmised to exist in
label: BODY

text: undiscovered pools within existing fields.  (Definitions are from NMBMMR 1995, V-2 and
label: BODY

text: Mineral resource discussions are focused principally on hydrocarbons and potassium salts, both
label: BODY

text: of which have long histories of development in the region.  Development of either resource
label: BODY

text: potentially could be disruptive to the disposal system.  The information regarding the mineral
label: BODY

text: resources concentrates on the following factors:
label: BODY

text: • number, location, depth, and present state of development, including penetrations through
label: BODY

text: the disposal horizon,
label: BODY

text: • type of resource,
label: BODY

text: • accessibility, quality, and demand, and
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: • mineral ownership in the area.
label: BODY

text: The specific impacts of resource development are discussed in Section 6.4.6.2.3, where scenarios
label: BODY

text: related to mineral development are included for evaluation of disposal system performance.  This
label: BODY

text: discussion uses information presented in CCA Appendices DEL and MASS as indicated in the
label: BODY

text: following text.  The discussion of cultural and economic resources is focused on describing past
label: BODY

text: and present land uses unrelated to the development of minerals.  The archaeological record
label: BODY

text: supports the observation that changes in land use are principally associated with climate and the
label: BODY

text: availability of forage for wild and domestic animals.  In no case does it appear that past or
label: BODY

text: present land use has had an impact on the subsurface beyond the development of shallow
label: BODY

text: groundwater wells to water livestock.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.1 Extractable Resources
label: HH1

text: The geologic studies of the WIPP site included the investigation of potential natural resources to
label: BODY

text: evaluate the impact of denying access to these resources and other consequences of their
label: BODY

text: occurrence.  Studies were completed in support of the FEIS to ensure knowledge of natural
label: BODY

text: resources, and the impacts of denying access were included in the decision-making process for
label: BODY

text: WIPP.  Of the natural resources expected to occur beneath the site, five are of practical concern:
label: BODY

text: the two potassium salts sylvite and langbeinite, which occur in the McNutt; and the three
label: BODY

text: hydrocarbons, crude oil, natural gas, and distillate liquids associated with natural gas, all three of
label: BODY

text: which occur elsewhere in strata below the Castile.  Other mineral resources beneath the site are
label: BODY

text: caliche, salt, gypsum, and lithium; enormous deposits of these minerals near the site and
label: BODY

text: elsewhere in the country are more than adequate (and more economically attractive) to meet
label: BODY

text: future requirements for these materials.  In 1995, the NMBMMR performed a reevaluation of the
label: BODY

text: mineral resources at and within 1.6 km (1 mi) around the WIPP site.  The following discussion is
label: BODY

text: based in part on information from NMBMMR (1995).
label: BODY

text: 2.3.1.1 Potash Resources at the WIPP Site
label: BODY

text: Throughout the Carlsbad Potash District, commercial quantities of potassium salts are restricted
label: BODY

text: to the middle portion of the Salado, locally called the McNutt.  A total of 11 zones (or distinct
label: BODY

text: ore layers) have been recognized in the McNutt.  Horizon Number 1 is at the base, and Number
label: BODY

text: 11 is at the top.  The 11th ore zone is not mined.
label: BODY

text: The USGS uses three standard grades—low, lease, and high—to quantify the potash resources at
label: BODY

text: the site.  The USGS assumes that the lease and high grades comprise reserves because some
label: BODY

text: lease-grade ore is mined in the Carlsbad Potash District.  Most of the potash that is mined,
label: BODY

text: however, is better typified as high-grade.  Even the high-grade resources may not be reserves,
label: BODY

text: however, if properties such as high clay content make processing uneconomical.  The analysis in
label: BODY

text: NMBMMR (1995) distinguishes between lease-grade ore and economically mineable ore.
label: BODY

text: The NMBMMR (1995) study contains a comprehensive summary of all previous potash resource
label: BODY

text: evaluations.  NMBMMR (1995, Chapter VII) used 40 existing boreholes drilled on and around
label: BODY

text: the WIPP site to perform a reevaluation of potash resources.  He selected holes that were drilled
label: BODY

text: using brine so that the dissolution of potassium salts was inhibited.  The conclusion reached is
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: that only the 4th and 10th ore zones contain economic potash reserves.  The quantities are

text: 2.3.1.2 Hydrocarbon Resources at the WIPP Site
label: BODY

text: In 1974, Foster of the NMBMMR conducted a hydrocarbon resource study in southeastern New
label: BODY

text: Mexico under contract to the ORNL.  The study included an area of 3,914 km2 (1,512 mi2).  At
label: BODY

text: the time of that study, the proposed repository site was about 8 km (5 mi) northeast of the current
label: BODY

text: site.  The 1974 NMBMMR evaluation included a more detailed study of a four-township area
label: BODY

text: centered on the old site; the present site is in the southwest quadrant of that area.  The 1974
label: BODY

text: NMBMMR hydrocarbon resources study (Foster 1974) is presented in more detail in the FEIS
label: BODY

text: (DOE 1980, Section 9.2.3.5).  The reader is referred to the FEIS or the original study for
label: BODY

text: additional information.

text: The resource evaluation was based both on the known reserves of crude oil and natural gas in the
label: BODY

text: region and on the probability of discovering new reservoirs in areas where past unsuccessful
label: BODY

text: drilling was either too widely spread or too shallow to have allowed discovery.  Potentially
label: BODY

text: productive zones were considered in the evaluation; therefore, the findings may be used for
label: BODY

text: estimating the total hydrocarbon resources at the site.  A fundamental assumption in the study
label: BODY

text: was that the WIPP area has the same potential for containing hydrocarbons as the
label: BODY

text: larger region studied for which exploration data are available.  Whether such resources actually
label: BODY

text: exist can be satisfactorily established only by drilling at spacings close enough to give a high
label: BODY

text: probability of discovery.

text: 2.3.1.3 Other Resources
label: BODY

text: While the focus of studies at the WIPP has been on potash and hydrocarbon, other resources are
label: BODY

text: known to occur within the Delaware Basin and are considered in the screening.  For example,
label: BODY

text: sulfur is produced in the vicinity of Orla, Texas.  Sulfur wells are included in CCA Appendix
label: BODY

text: DEL; however, no sulfur resources have been identified in the vicinity of the WIPP; therefore,
label: BODY

text: there are no projected impacts.  Another resource that is extensively produced is groundwater.
label: BODY

text: Potable water occurs in numerous places within the Delaware Basin.  Several communities rely
label: BODY

text: solely on groundwater sources for drinking water. CCA Appendix DEL includes a distribution of
label: BODY

text: groundwater wells in the Delaware Basin.  All such wells in the vicinity of the WIPP are
label: BODY

text: shallow, generally no deeper than the Culebra.  An evaluation of underground sources of
label: BODY

text: drinking water in the vicinity of the disposal system is presented in CCA Appendix USDW.
label: BODY

text: Figure USDW-4 shows the distribution of groundwater wells in the vicinity of the disposal
label: BODY

text: system.  Sand, gravel, and caliche are produced in numerous areas within the Delaware Basin.  In
label: BODY

text: all cases, these are surface quarries that are generally shallow (10s of feet).  No impact to the
label: BODY

text: disposal system is expected from these activities.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.2 Cultural and Economic Resources
label: HH2

text: The demographics, land use, and history and archaeology of the WIPP site and its environs are
label: BODY

text: characterized in the sections that follow.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.2.1 Demographics
label: BODY

text: The WIPP facility is located 42 km (26 mi) east of Carlsbad in Eddy County in southeastern
label: BODY

text: New Mexico and includes an area of 10,240 ac (approximately 41 km2) (16 mi2).  The facility is
label: BODY

text: located in a sparsely populated area with fewer than 30 permanent residents living within a 16-
label: BODY

text: km (10-mi) radius of the facility.  The area surrounding the facility is used primarily for grazing,
label: BODY

text: potash mining, and hydrocarbon production.  No resource development that would affect WIPP
label: BODY

text: facility operations or the long-term integrity of the facility is allowed within the 10,240 ac that
label: BODY

text: have been set aside for the WIPP project.
label: BODY

text: The permanent residence nearest to the WIPP site boundary is the J.C. Mills Ranch, which is
label: BODY

text: 2 km (1.2 mi) to the south.  The community nearest to the WIPP site is the town of Loving, New
label: BODY

text: Mexico, 29 km (18 mi) west-southwest of the site center.  The population of Loving increased
label: BODY

text: from 1,243 in 1990 to 1,326 in 2000.  The nearest population center is the city of Carlsbad, New
label: BODY

text: Mexico, 42 km (26 mi) west of the site.  The population of

text: 2.3.2.2 Land Use
label: BODY

text: At present, land within 16 km (10 mi) of the site is used for potash mining operations, active oil
label: BODY

text: and gas wells, activities associated with hydrocarbon production, and grazing.
label: BODY

text: The WIPP Land Withdrawal Act (LWA) (U.S. Congress 1992) withdrew certain public lands
label: BODY

text: from the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management (BLM).  The law provides for the
label: BODY

text: transfer of the WIPP site lands from the DOI to the DOE and effectively withdraws the lands,
label: BODY

text: subject to existing rights, from entry, sale, or disposition; appropriation under mining laws; or
label: BODY

text: operation of the mineral and geothermal leasing laws.  The LWA directed the Secretary of
label: BODY

text: Energy to produce a management plan to provide for grazing, hunting and trapping, wildlife
label: BODY

text: habitat, mining, and the disposal of salt and tailings.
label: BODY

text: Between 1978 and 1988, DOE acquired all active potash and hydrocarbon leases within the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site boundary.  These were acquired either through outright purchase or through
label: BODY

text: condemnation.  In one condemnation proceeding, the court awarded DOE the surface and top
label: BODY

text: 1.82 km (6,000 ft) of Section 31 and allowed the leaseholder to retain the subsurface below 1.82
label: BODY

text: km (6,000 ft).  This was allowed because analysis showed that wells developed within this lease
label: BODY

text: below the 1.82-km (6,000ft) limit would be too far away from the waste panels to be of
label: BODY

text: consequence to the WIPP (see, for example, Brausch et al. 1982).  This is corroborated by the
label: BODY

text: results of PA discussed in Section 6.2.5.1; and Appendix PA, Attachment SCR, FEP 56.
label: BODY

text: Consequently, as the result of the DOE’s acquisition activities, there are no producing
label: BODY

text: hydrocarbon wells within the volumetric boundary defined by the land withdrawal (T22S, R31E,
label: BODY

text: S15-22, 27-34).  Two active wells were drilled to tap the oil and gas resources on the leases
label: BODY

text: beneath Section 31.  The James Ranch #13, drilled in 1982, is a gas well, and the James Ranch
label: BODY

text: #27, drilled in 2000, is an oil well.  Both wells are located on surface leases outside the WIPP
label: BODY

text: site boundary.  Both wells enter Section 31 below a depth of 1.82 km (6,000 ft) beneath ground
label: BODY

text: level.  Except for the leases in Section 31, the LWA prohibits all drilling into the controlled area
label: BODY

text: unless such drilling is in support of the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: Grazing leases have been issued for all land sections immediately surrounding the WIPP facility.
label: BODY

text: Grazing within the WIPP site lands occurs within the authorization of the Taylor Grazing Act of
label: BODY

text: 1934, the Federal Land Policy and Management Act (FLPMA), the Public Rangelands
label: BODY

text: Improvement Act of 1978, and the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act of 1973.
label: BODY

text: The responsibilities of DOE include supervision of ancillary activities associated with grazing
label: BODY

text: (for example, wildlife access to livestock water development), tracking of water developments
label: BODY

text: inside WIPP lands to ensure that they are configured according to the regulatory requirements,
label: BODY

text: and ongoing coordination with respective allottees.  Administration of grazing rights is in
label: BODY

text: cooperation with the BLM according to the memorandum of understanding (MOU) and the
label: BODY

text: coinciding Statement of Work through guidance established in the East Roswell Grazing
label: BODY

text: Environmental Impact Statement.  The WIPP site is composed of two grazing allotments
label: BODY

text: administered by the BLM:  the Livingston Ridge (No. 77027), and the Antelope Ridge
label: BODY

text: (No. 77032) (see Figure 7-2).
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
