text: 2.3.2.3 History and Archaeology
label: BODY

text: From about 10,000 B.C. to the late 1800s, the WIPP site and surrounding region were inhabited
label: BODY

text: by nomadic aboriginal hunters and gatherers who subsisted on various wild plants and animals.
label: BODY

text: From about A.D. 600 onward, as trade networks were established with Puebloan peoples to the
label: BODY

text: west, domesticated plant foods and materials were acquired in exchange for dried meat, hides,
label: BODY

text: and other products from the Pecos Valley and Plains.  In the late 1500s, the Spanish
label: BODY

text: Conquistadors encountered Jumano and Apachean peoples in the region who practiced hunting
label: BODY

text: and gathering and engaged in trade with Puebloans.  After the Jumanos abandoned the southern
label: BODY

text: Plains region, the Comanches became the major population of the area.  Neighboring populations
label: BODY

text: with whom the Comanches maintained relationships ranging from mutual trade to open warfare
label: BODY

text: included the Lipan, or Southern Plains Apache, several Puebloan Groups, Spaniards, and the
label: BODY

text: Mescalero Apaches.
label: BODY

text: The best documented indigenous culture in the WIPP region is that of the Mescalero Apaches,
label: BODY

text: who lived west of the Pecos.  The lifestyle of the Mescalero Apaches represents a transition
label: BODY

text: between the full sedentism of the Pueblos and the nomadic hunting and gathering of the
label: BODY

text: Jumanos.  In 1763, the San Saba expedition encountered and camped with a group of Mescaleros
label: BODY

text: in Los Medaños.  Expedition records indicate the presence of both Lipan and Mescalero Apaches
label: BODY

text: in the region.
label: BODY

text: A peace accord reached between the Comanches and the Spaniards in 1786 resulted in two
label: BODY

text: historically important economic developments:  (1) organized buffalo hunting by Hispanic and
label: BODY

text: Puebloan ciboleros, and (2) renewal and expansion of the earlier extensive trade networks by
label: BODY

text: Comancheros.  These events placed eastern New Mexico in a position to receive a wide array of
label: BODY

text: both physical and ideological input from the Plains culture area to the east and north and from
label: BODY

text: Spanish-dominated regions to the west and south.  Comanchero trade began to mesh with the
label: BODY

text: Southwest American trade influence in the early nineteenth century.  However, by the late 1860s,
label: BODY

text: the importance of Comanchero trade was cut short by Texan influence.
label: BODY

text: The first cattle trail in the area was established along the Pecos River in 1866 by Charles
label: BODY

text: Goodnight and Oliver Loving.  By 1868, Texan John Chisum dominated much of the area by
label: BODY

text: controlling key springs along the river.  Overgrazing, drought, and dropping beef prices led to
label: BODY

text: the demise of open-range cattle ranching by the late 1880s.
label: BODY

text: Following the demise of open-range livestock production, ranching developed using fenced
label: BODY

text: grazing areas and production of hay crops for winter use.  Herd grazing patterns were influenced
label: BODY

text: by the availability of water supplies as well as by the storage of summer grasses for winter
label: BODY

text: feeding.
label: BODY

text: The town of Carlsbad was founded as Eddy in 1889 as a health spa.  In addition to ranching, the
label: BODY

text: twentieth century brought the development of the potash, oil, and gas industries that have
label: BODY

text: increased the population eightfold in the last 50 years.
label: BODY

text: Although technological change has altered some of the aspects, ranching remains an important
label: BODY

text: economic activity in the WIPP region.  This relationship between people and the land is still an
label: BODY

text: important issue in the area.  Ranch-related sites dating to the 1940s and 1950s are common in
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: parts of the WIPP area.  These will be considered historical properties within the next several
label: BODY

text: years, and thus will be treated as such under current law.
label: BODY

text: The National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA) (16 USC Part 470 et seq.) was enacted to protect
label: BODY

text: the nation’s cultural resources in conjunction with the states, local governments, Indian tribes,
label: BODY

text: and private organizations and individuals.  The policy of the federal government includes:
label: BODY

text: (1) providing leadership in preserving the prehistoric and historic resources of the nation,
label: BODY

text: (2) administering federally owned, administered, or controlled prehistoric resources for the
label: BODY

text: benefit of present and future generations, (3) contributing to the preservation of nonfederally
label: BODY

text: owned prehistoric and historic resources, and (4) assisting state and local governments and the
label: BODY

text: national trust for historic preservation in expanding and accelerating their historic preservation
label: BODY

text: programs and activities.  The act also established the National Register of Historic Places
label: BODY

text: (National Register).  At the state level, the State Historic Preservation Officer (SHPO)
label: BODY

text: coordinates the state’s participation in implementing the NHPA.  The NHPA has been amended
label: BODY

text: by two acts:  the Archeological and Historic Preservation Act (16 USC Part 469 et seq.), and the
label: BODY

text: Archeological Resource Protection Act (16 USC Part 470aa et seq.).
label: BODY

text: To protect and preserve cultural resources found within the WIPP site boundary, the WIPP
label: BODY

text: submitted a mitigation plan to the New Mexico SHPO describing the steps to either avoid or
label: BODY

text: excavate archaeological sites.  A site was defined as a place used and occupied by prehistoric
label: BODY

text: people.  In May 1980, the SHPO made a determination of “no adverse effect from WIPP facility
label: BODY

text: activities” on cultural resources.  The Advisory Council on Historic Preservation concurred that
label: BODY

text: the WIPP Mitigation Plan is appropriate to protect cultural resources.
label: BODY

text: Known historical sites (more than 50 years old) in southeastern New Mexico consist primarily of
label: BODY

text: early twentieth century homesteads that failed, or isolated features from late nineteenth century
label: BODY

text: and early twentieth century cattle or sheep ranching, or military activities.  To date, no Spanish
label: BODY

text: or Mexican sites have been identified.  Historic components are rare but are occasionally noted
label: BODY

text: in the WIPP area.  These include features and debris related to ranching.
label: BODY

text: Since 1976, cultural resource investigations have recorded 98 archaeological sites and numerous
label: BODY

text: isolated artifacts within the 41km2 (16mi2) area enclosed by the WIPP site.  In the central
label: BODY

text: 10.4km2 (4mi2) area, 33 sites were determined to be eligible for inclusion on the National
label: BODY

text: Register as archaeological districts.  Investigations since 1980 have recorded an additional 14
label: BODY

text: individual sites outside the central 10.4km2 (4mi2) area that are considered eligible for inclusion
label: BODY

text: on the National Register.  The following major cultural resource investigations to date are broken
label: BODY

text: out in the list that follows.  Additional information can be found in the bibliography of CCA
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2.

label: BODY

label: HH2

text: and a railroad right-of-way for Bechtel, Inc.  The survey encountered two sites and 12 isolated

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: All of the aforementioned archeological investigations received determinations of “No Adverse
label: BODY

text: Affect” from the OCA and the SHPO.  This determination serves as a clearance to proceed with
label: BODY

text: work.
label: BODY

text: The Delaware Basin has been used in the past for an isolated nuclear test.  This test, Project
label: BODY

text: Gnome, took place in 1961 at a location approximately 13 km (8 mi) southwest of the WIPP.
label: BODY

text: The primary objective of Project Gnome was to study the effects of an underground nuclear
label: BODY

text: explosion in salt.  The Gnome experiment involved the detonation of a 3.1-kiloton nuclear device
label: BODY

text: at a depth of 361 m (1,200 ft) in the bedded salt of the Salado (Rawson et al. 1965).  The
label: BODY

text: explosion created a cavity of approximately 28,000 m3 (1,000,000 ft3) and caused surface
label: BODY

text: displacements over an area of about a 360m (1,200ft) radius.  Fracturing and faulting caused
label: BODY

text: measurable changes in rock permeability and porosity at distances up to approximately 100 m
label: BODY

text: (330 ft) from the cavity.  No earth tremors were reported at distances over 40 km (25 mi) from
label: BODY

text: the explosion.  Project Gnome was decommissioned in 1979.
label: BODY

text: 2.4 Background Environmental Conditions
label: HH2

text: Background environmental conditions at and near the WIPP site were characterized prior to the
label: BODY

text: initiation of the operation of the facility and are described in CCA Section 2.4.  Because
label: BODY

text: background characterization focuses on environmental conditions existing prior to operations, it
label: BODY

text: is not meaningful to redefine background environmental conditions after operations began.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, information presented in CCA Section 2.4 is not repeated and updated in this
label: BODY

text: recertification application.
label: BODY

text: 2.5 Climate and Meteorological Conditions
label: HH2

text: The DOE did not consider climate directly in its site selection process, although criteria such as
label: BODY

text: low population density and large tracts of federally owned land tend to favor arid and semi-arid
label: BODY

text: areas in the western United States.  The semi-arid climate around the WIPP is beneficial since it
label: BODY

text: is a direct cause of the lack of a near surface water table and the minimization of radiation
label: BODY

text: exposure pathways that involve surface or groundwater.  Data used to interpret paleoclimates in
label: BODY

text: the American southwest come from a variety of sources and indicate alternating arid and subarid
label: BODY

text: to subhumid climates throughout the Pleistocene.  The information in this section was taken from
label: BODY

text: Swift (1992), and included in CCA Appendix CLI and references therein.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.1 Historic Climatic Conditions
label: HH2

text: Prior to 18,000 years ago, radiometric dates are relatively scarce, and the record is incomplete.
label: BODY

text: From 18,000 years ago to the present, however, the climatic record is relatively well constrained
label: BODY

text: by floral, faunal, and lacustrine data.  These data span the transition from the last full-glacial
label: BODY

text: maximum to the present interglacial period; given the global consistency of glacial fluctuations
label: BODY

text: described below, they can be taken to be broadly representative of extremes for the entire
label: BODY

text: Pleistocene.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Early and middle Pleistocene paleoclimatic data for the southwestern United States are
label: BODY

text: incomplete and permit neither continuous reconstructions of paleoclimates nor direct correlations
label: BODY

text: between climate and glaciation prior to the last glacial maximum, which occurred 22,000 to
label: BODY

text: 18,000 years ago.  Stratigraphic and soil data from several locations, however, indicate that
label: BODY

text: cyclical alternation of wetter and drier climates in the Southwest had begun by the Early
label: BODY

text: Pleistocene.  Fluvial gravels in the Gatuña exposed in the Pecos River Valley of eastern New
label: BODY

text: Mexico suggest wetter conditions 1.4 million years ago and again 600,000 years ago.  The
label: BODY

text: Mescalero caliche, exposed locally over much of southeastern New Mexico, suggests drier
label: BODY

text: conditions 510,000 years ago, and loosely dated spring deposits in Nash Draw west of the WIPP
label: BODY

text: imply wetter conditions occurring again later in the Pleistocene.  The Blackwater Draw
label: BODY

text: Formation of the southern High Plains of eastern New Mexico and western Texas, correlating in
label: BODY

text: time to both the Gatuña Formation and the Mescalero caliche, contains alternating soil and eolian
label: BODY

text: sand horizons that show at least six climatic cycles beginning more than 1.4 million years ago
label: BODY

text: and continuing to the present.
label: BODY

text: Data used to construct the more detailed climatic record for the latest Pleistocene and Holocene
label: BODY

text: come from six independent lines of evidence dated using carbon-14 techniques:  plant
label: BODY

text: communities preserved in packrat middens throughout the southwest, including sites in Eddy and
label: BODY

text: Otero counties, New Mexico; pollen assemblages from lacustrine deposits in western New
label: BODY

text: Mexico and other locations in the southwest; gastropod assemblages from western Texas;
label: BODY

text: ostracod assemblages from western New Mexico; paleolake levels throughout the southwest; and
label: BODY

text: faunal remains from caves in southern New Mexico.
label: BODY

text: Prior to the last glacial maximum 22,000 to 18,000 years ago, evidence from faunal assemblages
label: BODY

text: in caves in southern New Mexico, including the presence of species such as the desert tortoise
label: BODY

text: that are now restricted to warmer climates, suggests hot summers and mild, dry winters.
label: BODY

text: Lacustrine evidence confirms the interpretation of a relatively dry climate prior to and during the
label: BODY

text: glacial advance.  Permanent water did not appear in what was later to become a major lake in the
label: BODY

text: Estancia Valley in central New Mexico until some time before 24,000 years ago, and water
label: BODY

text: depths in lakes at higher elevations in the San Agustin Plains in western New Mexico did not
label: BODY

text: reach a maximum until sometime between 22,000 and 19,000 years ago.  Ample floral and
label: BODY

text: lacustrine evidence documents cooler, wetter conditions in the southwest during the glacial peak.
label: BODY

text: These changes were not caused by the immediate proximity of glacial ice.  None of the
label: BODY

text: Pleistocene continental glaciations advanced farther southwest than northeastern Kansas, and the
label: BODY

text: most recent, late-Wisconsinan ice sheet reached its limit in South Dakota, approximately 1,200
label: BODY

text: km (750 mi) from WIPP.  Discontinuous alpine glaciers formed at the highest elevations
label: BODY

text: throughout the Rocky Mountains, but these isolated ice masses were symptoms, rather than
label: BODY

text: causes, of cooler and wetter conditions and had little influence on regional climate at lower
label: BODY

text: elevations.  The closest such glacier to WIPP was on the northeast face of Sierra Blanca Peak in
label: BODY

text: the Sacramento Mountains, approximately 220 km (135 mi) to the northwest.
label: BODY

text: Global climate models indicate that the dominant glacial effect in the southwest was the
label: BODY

text: disruption and southward displacement of the westerly jet stream by the physical mass of the ice
label: BODY

text: sheet to the north.  At the glacial peak, major Pacific storm systems followed the jet stream
label: BODY

text: across New Mexico and the southern Rocky Mountains, and winters were wetter and longer than
label: BODY

text: either at the present or during the previous interglacial period.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Gastropod assemblages at Lubbock Lake in western Texas suggest mean annual temperatures 5º
label: BODY

text: C (9º F) below present values.  Both floral and faunal evidence indicate that annual precipitation
label: BODY

text: throughout the region was 1.6 to 2.0 times greater than today’s values.  Floral evidence also
label: BODY

text: suggests that winters may have continued to be relatively mild, perhaps because the glacial mass
label: BODY

text: blocked the southward movement of arctic air.  Summers at the glacial maximum were cooler
label: BODY

text: and drier than at present, without a strongly developed monsoon.
label: BODY

text: The jet stream shifted northward following the gradual retreat of the ice sheet after 18,000 years
label: BODY

text: ago, and the climate responded accordingly.  By approximately 11,000 years ago, conditions
label: BODY

text: were significantly warmer and drier than previously, although still dominated by winter storms
label: BODY

text: and still wetter than today.  Major decreases in total precipitation and the shift toward the
label: BODY

text: modern monsoonal climate did not occur until the ice sheet had retreated into northeastern
label: BODY

text: Canada in the early Holocene.
label: BODY

text: By middle Holocene time, the climate was similar to that of the present, with hot, monsoon-
label: BODY

text: dominated summers and cold, dry winters.  The pattern has persisted to the present, but not
label: BODY

text: without significant local variations.  Soil studies show that the southern High Plains were drier
label: BODY

text: from 6,500 to 4,500 years ago than before or since.  Gastropod data from Lubbock Lake indicate
label: BODY

text: the driest conditions from 7,000 to 5,000 years ago (precipitation, 0.89 times present values;
label: BODY

text: mean annual temperature, 2.5º C [4.5º F] higher than present values), with a cooler and wetter
label: BODY

text: period 1,000 years ago (precipitation, 1.45 times present values; mean annual temperature, 2.5º C
label: BODY

text: [4.5º F] lower than present).  Plant assemblages from southwestern Arizona suggest steadily
label: BODY

text: decreasing precipitation from the middle Holocene to the present, except for a brief wet period
label: BODY

text: approximately 990 years ago.  Stratigraphic work at Lake Cochise (the present Willcox playa in
label: BODY

text: southeast Arizona) shows two mid-Holocene lake stands, one near or before 5,400 years ago and
label: BODY

text: one between or before 3,000 to 4,000 years ago; however, both were relatively short-lived, and
label: BODY

text: neither reached the maximum depths of the Late Pleistocene high stand that existed before
label: BODY

text: 14,000 years ago.
label: BODY

text: Inferred historical precipitation indicates that during the Holocene, wet periods were relatively
label: BODY

text: drier and shorter in duration than those of the late Pleistocene.  Historical records over the last
label: BODY

text: several hundred years indicate numerous lower-intensity climatic fluctuations, some too short in
label: BODY

text: duration to affect floral and faunal circulation.  Sunspot cycles and the related change in the
label: BODY

text: amount of energy emitted by the sun have been linked to historical climatic changes elsewhere in
label: BODY

text: the world, but the validity of the correlation is uncertain.  Correlations have also been proposed
label: BODY

text: between volcanic activity and climatic change.  In general, however, causes for past short-term
label: BODY

text: changes are unknown.
label: BODY

text: The climatic record presented here should be interpreted with caution because its resolution and
label: BODY

text: accuracy are limited by the nature of the data used to construct it.  Floral and faunal assemblages
label: BODY

text: change gradually and show only a limited response to climatic fluctuations that occur at
label: BODY

text: frequencies that are higher than the typical life span of the organisms in question.  For long-lived
label: BODY

text: species such as trees, resolution may be limited to hundreds or even thousands of years.
label: BODY

text: Sedimentation in lakes and playas has the potential to record higher-frequency fluctuations,
label: BODY

text: including single-storm events, but only under a limited range of circumstances.  Once water
label: BODY

text: levels reach a spill point, for example, lakes show only a limited response to further increases in
label: BODY

text: precipitation.
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: With these observations in mind, three significant conclusions can be drawn from the climatic
label: BODY

text: record of the American southwest.  First, maximum precipitation in the past coincided with the
label: BODY

text: maximum advance of the North American ice sheet.  Minimum precipitation occurred after the
label: BODY

text: ice sheet had retreated to its present limits.  Second, past maximum long-term average
label: BODY

text: precipitation levels were roughly twice the present levels.  Minimum levels may have been
label: BODY

text: 90 percent of the present levels.  Third, short-term fluctuations in precipitation have occurred
label: BODY

text: during the present relatively dry, interglacial period, but they have not exceeded the upper limits
label: BODY

text: of the glacial maximum.
label: BODY

text: Too little is known about the relatively short-term behavior of global circulation patterns to
label: BODY

text: accurately predict precipitation levels over the next 10,000 years.  The long-term stability of
label: BODY

text: patterns of glaciation and deglaciation, however, do permit the conclusion that future climatic
label: BODY

text: extremes are unlikely to exceed those of the late Pleistocene.  Furthermore, the periodicity of
label: BODY

text: glacial events suggests that a return to full-glacial conditions is highly unlikely within the next
label: BODY

text: 10,000 years.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2 Recent Climatic Conditions
label: HH2

text: Recent climatic conditions are provided to allow for the assessment of impacts of these factors
label: BODY

text: on the disposal unit and the site.  Data are taken from the WIPP environmental monitoring
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2.1 General Climatic Conditions
label: BODY

text: The climate of the region is semiarid, with generally mild temperatures, low precipitation and
label: BODY

text: humidity, and a high evaporation rate.  Winds are mostly from the southeast and moderate.  In
label: BODY

text: late winter and spring, there are strong west winds and dust storms.  During the winter, the
label: BODY

text: weather is often dominated by a high-pressure system situated in the central portion of the
label: BODY

text: western United States and a low-pressure system located in north-central Mexico.  During the
label: BODY

text: summer, the region is affected by a low-pressure system normally situated over Arizona.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2.2 Temperature Summary
label: BODY

text: Temperatures are moderate throughout the year, although seasonal changes are distinct.  The
label: BODY

text: mean annual temperature in southeastern New Mexico is 63º F (17º C).  In the winter (December
label: BODY

text: through February), nighttime lows average near 23º F (-5º C), and maxima average in the 50s.
label: BODY

text: The lowest recorded temperature at the nearest Class-A weather station in Roswell was -29º F
label: BODY

text: (-34º C) in February 1905.  In the summer (June through August), the daytime temperature
label: BODY

text: exceeds 90EF (32º C) approximately 75 percent of the time.  The National Weather Service
label: BODY

text: documented 122º F (50º C) at the WIPP site as the record high temperature for New Mexico.
label: BODY

text: This temperature was recorded on June 27, 1994.  Table 2-14 shows the annual average,
label: BODY

text: maximum, and minimum temperatures from 1990 through 2002.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2.3 Precipitation Summary
label: BODY

text: Precipitation is light and unevenly distributed throughout the year, averaging 28.2cm (11.1in.)
label: BODY

text: per year from 1995 through 2002.  Winter is the season of least precipitation, averaging less than
label: BODY

text: 1.5 cm (0.6 in.) of rainfall per month.  Snow averages about 13 cm (5 in.) per year at the site and
label: BODY

text: seldom remains on the ground for more than a day. Approximately half the annual precipitation
label: BODY

text: comes from frequent thunderstorms in June through September.  Rains are usually brief but
label: BODY

text: occasionally intense when moisture from the Gulf of Mexico spreads over the region.  Monthly
label: BODY

text: average, maximum, and minimum precipitations recorded at the WIPP site from 1990 through
label: BODY

text: 2002 are summarized in Figure 2-48.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2.4 Wind Speed and Wind Direction Summary
label: BODY

text: The frequencies of wind speeds and directions are depicted by wind roses in Figures 2-49
label: BODY

text: through 2-56 for the WIPP site.

text: Seismology
label: BODY

text: The DOE used tectonic activity as a siting criterion.  The intent was to avoid tectonic conditions
label: BODY

text: such as faulting and igneous activity that would jeopardize waste isolation over the long term
label: BODY

text: and to avoid areas where earthquake size and frequency could impact facility design and
label: BODY

text: operations.  The WIPP site met both aspects of this criterion fully.  Long-term tectonic activity is
label: BODY

text: discussed in Section 2.1.5.  The favorable results of the seismic (earthquake) studies are
label: BODY

text: discussed here.  The purpose of the seismic studies is to build a basis from which to predict
label: BODY

text: ground motions that the WIPP repository may be subjected to in the near and distant future.  The
label: BODY

text: concern about seismic effects in the near future, during the operational period, pertains mainly to
label: BODY

text: the design requirements for surface and underground structures for providing containment during
label: BODY

text: seismic events.  The concern about effects occurring over the long term, after the repository has
label: BODY

text: been decommissioned and sealed, pertains more to relative motions (faulting) within the
label: BODY

text: repository and possible effects of faulting on the integrity of the salt beds and/or shaft seals.
label: BODY

text: Updated seismic activity information is provided in Figures 2-57 and 2-58.  In this discussion,
label: BODY

text: the magnitudes are reported in terms of the Richter scale, and all intensities are based on the
label: BODY

text: 2.6.1 Seismic History
label: HH2

text: Seismic data are presented in two time frames, before and after the time when seismographic
label: BODY

text: data for the region became available.  The earthquake record in southern New Mexico dates back
label: BODY

text: only to 1923, and seismic instruments have been in place in the state since 1961.  Various
label: BODY

text: records have been examined to determine the seismic history of the area within 180 mi (288 km)
label: BODY

text: of the site.  With the exception of a weak shock in 1926 at Hope, New Mexico (approximately 64
label: BODY

text: km [40 mi] northwest of Carlsbad), and shocks in 1936 and 1949 felt at Carlsbad, all known
label: BODY

text: shocks in the region before 1961 occurred to the west and southwest of the site more than
label: BODY

text: 160 km (100 mi) away.
label: BODY

text: The strongest earthquake on record occurring within 288 km (180 mi) of the site was the
label: BODY

text: Valentine, Texas earthquake of August 16, 1931.  It has been estimated to have been of
label: BODY

text: magnitude 6.4 on the Richter scale (Modified Mercalli Intensity of VIII).  The Valentine
label: BODY

text: earthquake was 208 km (130 mi) south-southwest of the site.  Its Modified Mercalli Intensity at
label: BODY

text: the site is estimated to have been V; this is believed to be the highest intensity felt at the site in
label: BODY

text: this century.
label: BODY

text: In 1887, a major earthquake occurred in northeast Sonora, Mexico.  Although about 536 km
label: BODY

text: (335 mi) west-southwest of the site, it is indicative of the size of earthquakes possible in the
label: BODY

text: eastern portion of the Basin and Range Province, west of the province containing the site.  Its
label: BODY

text: magnitude was estimated to have been 7.8 (VIII to IX in Modified Mercalli Intensity).  It was
label: BODY

text: felt over an area of 1.3 million km2 (0.5 million mi2) (as far as Santa Fe to the north and Mexico
label: BODY

text: City to the south); fault displacements near the epicenter were as large as 18 m (26 ft).
label: BODY

text: Since 1961, instrumental coverage has become comprehensive enough to locate most of the
label: BODY

text: moderately strong earthquakes (local magnitude >3.5) in the region.  Instrumentally determined
label: BODY

text: shocks that occurred within 288 km (180 mi) of the site between 1961 and 1994 are shown in
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-57.  The distribution of these earthquakes may be biased by the fact that seismic
label: BODY

text: stations were more numerous and were in operation for longer periods north and west of the site.
label: BODY

text: Pre-1961 earthquakes can be found in CCA Appendix GCR, Figure 5.2-1.
label: BODY

text: Except for the activity southeast of the site, the distribution of epicenters since 1961 differs little
label: BODY

text: from that of shocks before that time.  There are two clusters, one associated with the Rio Grande
label: BODY

text: Rift on the Texas-Chihuahua border and another associated with the Central Basin Platform in
label: BODY

text: Texas near the southeastern corner of New Mexico.  The latter activity was not reported before
label: BODY

text: 1964.  It is not clear from the record whether earthquakes were occurring in the Central Basin
label: BODY

text: Platform before 1964, although local historical societies and newspapers tend to confirm their
label: BODY

text: absence before that time.
label: BODY

text: The April 14, 1995, earthquake near Marathon, Texas, was located 240 km (150 mi) south of the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site.  The USGS estimated that moment magnitude for this event was 5.7.  At a distance of
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-57.  Regional Earthquake Epicenters Occurring between 1961 and 2002
label: HH2

text: 240 km (149 mi), an event of magnitude 5.7 would produce a maximum acceleration at the
label: BODY

text: WIPP site of less than 0.01 g (acceleration due to gravity).
label: BODY

text: The Marathon earthquake should not be considered an unanticipated event.  The shock occurred
label: BODY

text: in the Basin and Range Province, a seismotectonic province with evidence for 24 Quarternary
label: BODY

text: faults in West Texas and adjacent parts of Mexico.  Two of these faults had recent surface-
label: BODY

text: faulting events in the Holocene.  Strong earthquakes have occurred within the West Texas part of
label: BODY

text: the Basin and Range Province, most notably the MW = 6.4 (Richter) Valentine, Texas earthquake
label: BODY

text: on August 15, 1931.
label: BODY

text: The WIPP site is located within the Great Plains seismotectonic province, a region that has no
label: BODY

text: evidence of Quarternary faulting, even above major buried structures such as the Central Basin
label: BODY

text: Platform.  Because the Great Plains seismotectonic province is geologically distinct from the
label: BODY

text: Basin and Range Province and lacks evidence for recent faulting, the maximum possible or
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: credible earthquake for this region would be substantially smaller than that for the Basin and
label: BODY

text: Range Province of West Texas.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2 Seismic Risk
label: HH2

text: Procedures exist that allow for formal determination of earthquake probabilistic design
label: BODY

text: parameters.  In typical seismic risk analyses of this kind, the region of study is divided into
label: BODY

text: seismic source areas within which future events are considered equally likely to occur at any
label: BODY

text: location.  For each seismic source area, the rate of occurrence of events above a chosen threshold
label: BODY

text: level is estimated using the observed frequency of historical events.  The sizes of successive
label: BODY

text: events in each source are assumed to be independent and exponentially distributed; the slope of
label: BODY

text: the log number versus frequency relationship is estimated from the relative frequency of
label: BODY

text: different sizes of events observed in the historical data.  This slope, often termed the b value, is
label: BODY

text: determined either for each seismic source individually or for all sources in the region jointly.
label: BODY

text: Finally, the maximum possible size of events for each source is determined using judgement and
label: BODY

text: the historical record.  Thus, all assumptions underlying a measure of earthquake risk derived
label: BODY

text: from this type of analysis are explicit, and a wide range of assumptions may be employed in the
label: BODY

text: analysis procedure.
label: BODY

text: In this section, the particular earthquake risk parameter calculated is peak acceleration expressed
label: BODY

text: as a function of annual probability of being exceeded at the WIPP site.  The particular analysis
label: BODY

text: procedure applied to the calculation of this probabilistic peak acceleration is taken from a
label: BODY

text: computer program written by McGuire (1976).  In that program, the seismic source zones are
label: BODY

text: modeled geometrically as quadrilaterals of arbitrary shape.  Contributions to site earthquake risk
label: BODY

text: from individual source zones are integrated into the probability distribution of acceleration, and
label: BODY

text: the average annual probability of exceedence then follows directly.
label: BODY

text: In the analysis, the principal input parameters are as follows:  site region acceleration
label: BODY

text: attenuation, source zone geometry, recurrence statistics, and maximum magnitudes.  Based on
label: BODY

text: these parameters, several curves showing probabilistic peak acceleration are developed, and the
label: BODY

text: conclusions that may be drawn from these curves are considered.  The data treated in this way
label: BODY

text: are used to arrive at a general statement of risk from vibratory ground motion at the site during
label: BODY

text: its active phase of development and use.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2.1 Acceleration Attenuation
label: BODY

text: The first input parameters considered have to do with acceleration attenuation in the site region
label: BODY

text: as a function of earthquake magnitude and hypocentral distance.  The risk analysis used in this
label: BODY

text: study employs an attenuation law of the form
label: BODY

text: a = b1 exp(b2ML)R-b3 ,
label: BODY

text: where a is acceleration in cm/s2, ML is Richter local magnitude, and R is the distance in km.  The
label: BODY

text: particular formula used in this study is based on a central United States model developed by
label: BODY

text: Nuttli (1973).  The formula coefficients b1 = 17, b2 = 0.92, and b3 = 1.0 were selected.  A
label: BODY

text: justification for this assumption can be found in CCA Appendix GCR, Section 5.3.2.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2.2 Seismic Source Zones
label: BODY

text: Geologic, tectonic, and seismic evidence indicates that three seismic source zones may be used
label: BODY

text: to adequately characterize the region.  These are well approximated by the Basin and Range
label: BODY

text: subregion, the Permian Basin subregion exclusive of the Central Basin Platform, and the Central
label: BODY

text: Basin Platform itself.  Specific boundaries are taken from a 1976 study by Algermissen and
label: BODY

text: Perkins (1976) of earthquake risks throughout the United States.  Additional details on this study
label: BODY

text: are in CCA Appendix GCR, Section 5.3.2.
label: BODY

text: Site region seismic source zones are shown in Figure 2-58.  Superposed on these zones are the
label: BODY

text: earthquake epicenters of Figure 2-57.  The zonation presented generally conforms with historical
label: BODY

text: seismicity.  The source zonation of Figure 2-58 has no explicit analog to the Permian Basin
label: BODY

text: subregion exclusive of the Central Basin Platform.  This is considered part of the broad
label: BODY

text: background region.
label: BODY

text: For the purposes of this study, some minor modifications of the Algermissen and Perkins (1976)
label: BODY

text: source zones were made.  Geologic and tectonic evidence suggests that the physiographic
label: BODY

text: boundary between the Basin and Range and Great Plains provinces provides a good and
label: BODY

text: conservative approximation of the source zones (CCA Appendix GCR).  In addition, information
label: BODY

text: from the Kermit seismic array (Appendix to Rogers and Malkiel 1979) indicates that the
label: BODY

text: geometry used to model the limits of the Central Basin Platform source zone may be modified
label: BODY

text: somewhat from the original analogous Algermissen and Perkins (1976) zone.  These
label: BODY

text: modifications are shown in Figure 2-59 and constitute the preferred model for the WIPP site
label: BODY

text: region seismic source zones in this study.  This model is preferred because it more completely
label: BODY

text: considers geologic and tectonic information, as well as seismic data, and because it results in a
label: BODY

text: more realistic development of risks at the WIPP facility.
label: BODY

text: With regard to earthquake focal depth, there is little doubt that the focal depths of earthquakes in
label: BODY

text: the WIPP facility region should be considered shallow.  Early instrumental locations were
label: BODY

text: achieved using an arc intersection method employing travel-time-distance curves calculated from
label: BODY

text: a given crustal model, and the assumption of focal depths of 5 km (3.1 mi), 10 km (6.2 mi), or,
label: BODY

text: for later calculations, 8 km (5 mi).  Good epicentral locations could generally be obtained under
label: BODY

text: these assumptions.  For conservatism, a focal depth of 5 km (3.1 mi) is used in all source zones
label: BODY

text: of this study including that of the site.  For smaller hypocentral distances, the form of the
label: BODY

text: attenuation law adopted here severely exaggerates the importance of small, close shocks in the
label: BODY

text: estimation of probabilistic acceleration at the WIPP site.  Additional discussion is included CCA
label: BODY

text: Appendix GCR, Chapter 5.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2.3 Source Zone Recurrence Formulas and Maximum Magnitudes
label: BODY

text: The risk calculation procedure used in this study requires that earthquake recurrence rates for
label: BODY

text: each seismic source zone be specified.  This is done formally by computing the constants a and b
label: BODY

text: in the equation
label: BODY

text: log N = a - bM ,
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-58.  Seismic Source Zones
label: BODY

text: where N is the number of earthquakes of magnitude greater than or equal to M within a specified
label: BODY

text: area occurring during a specified period.
label: BODY

text: For the WIPP facility region, three formulas of this type are needed:  one for the province west
label: BODY

text: and southwest of the site (the Basin and Range subregion or Rio Grande Rift source zone),
label: BODY

text: another for the province of the WIPP facility exclusive of the Central Basin Platform (the
label: BODY

text: Permian Basin subregion or background source zone), and a final one for the Central Basin
label: BODY

text: Platform.  In practice, the difficulties in finding meaningful recurrence formulas for such small
label: BODY

text: areas in a region of low historical earthquake activity are formidable.
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231
label: BODY

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: Figure 2-59.  Alternate Source Geometries
label: BODY

text: DOE/WIPP 2004-3231

text: March 2004

text: Title 40 CFR Part 191 Subparts B and C Compliance Recertification Application 2004
label: BODY

text: The formulas have been determined to be
label: BODY

text: • log N = 2.43 - MCORR
label: BODY

text: Site source zone (background)
label: BODY

text: • log N = 3.25 - MCORR
label: BODY

text: Basin and Range subregion
label: BODY

text: • log N = 3.19 - 0.9 MCORR
label: BODY

text: Central Basin Platform
label: BODY

text: The rationale for their development and the relationship used to determine MCORR can be found
label: BODY

text: in CCA Appendix GCR, Section 5.3.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2.4 Design Basis Earthquake
label: BODY

text: The term Design Basis Earthquake (DBE) is used for the design of surface confinement
label: BODY

text: structures and components at the WIPP facility.  As used here, the DBE is equivalent to the
label: BODY

text: design earthquake used in Regulatory Guide 3.24 (Nuclear Regulatory Commission [NRC]
label: BODY

text: 1974).  That is, in view of the limited consequences of seismic events in excess of those used as
label: BODY

text: the basis, the DBE is such that it produces ground motion at the WIPP facility with a recurrence
label: BODY

text: interval of 1,000 years.  In practice, the DBE is defined in terms of the 1,000-year acceleration
label: BODY

text: and design response spectra.
label: BODY

text: The generation of curves expressing probability of occurrence or risk as a function of peak WIPP
label: BODY

text: facility ground acceleration is discussed in detail in CCA Appendix GCR, Section 5.3, for a
label: BODY

text: number of possible characterizations of WIPP facility region source zones and source zone
label: BODY

text: earthquake parameters.  The most conservative (and the least conservative) risk curves are shown
label: BODY

text: in Figure 2-60.
label: BODY

text: From this figure, the most conservative calculated estimate of the 1,000-year acceleration at the
label: BODY

text: WIPP facility is approximately 0.075 g.  The geologic and seismic assumptions leading to this
label: BODY

text: 1,000-year peak acceleration include the consideration of a Richter magnitude 5.5 earthquake at
label: BODY

text: the site, a 6.0 magnitude earthquake on the Central Basin Platform, and a 7.8 magnitude
label: BODY

text: earthquake in the Basin and Range subregion.  These values, especially the first two, are
label: BODY

text: considered quite conservative, as are the other parameters used in the 0.075g derivation.  For
label: BODY

text: additional conservatism, a peak design acceleration of 0.1 g is selected for the WIPP facility
label: BODY

text: DBE.  The design response spectra for vertical and horizontal motions are taken from Regulatory
label: BODY

text: Guide 1.60 (NRC 1973) with the high-frequency asymptote scaled to this 0.1g peak acceleration
label: BODY

text: value.
label: BODY

text: This DBE and the risk analysis that serves an important role in its definition are directly
label: BODY

text: applicable to surface confinement structures and components at the WIPP facility.  Underground
label: BODY

text: structures and components are not subject to DBE design requirements because according to
label: BODY

text: Pratt et al. (1979), mine experience and studies on earthquake damage to underground facilities
label: BODY

text: show that tunnels are not damaged at sites having peak surface accelerations below 0.2 g.
label: BODY
